text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Percocet / Robaxin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia, lower urinary tract symptoms and 
bladder stone
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laser cystolitholapaxy of bladder stone greater than 2.5 cm, 
transurethral resection of the prostate.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ male with hematuria, gross, first noted in ___. 
He saw his PCP and ___ renal/bladder US was obtained showing a 
bladder stone and mild
left hydronephrosis. This has happened before -- kidney stone 
___ and hematuria ___ years ago. There were no clots associated 
with this. There was no flank pain associated with this. He 
denies history of UTI and has previously been seen by colleague 
Dr. ___ for his stones. 
 
Past Medical History:
CECAL CARCINOMA                                                 
DEPRESSION                                                      
DIVERTICULAR BLEED                                              
DIVERTICULITIS                                                  
GENITAL RASH                                                    
R HIP PAIN                                                      
RECTAL BLEEDING                                                 
BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERTROPHY                                    

Colon resection ___
B TKA
R THA

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
FAMILY HISTORY is negative for the following:
Nephrolithiasis
Malignant Hyperthermia
Renal Cell CA
Testisa CA
Prostate CA
Bladder CA
 
Physical Exam:
WDWN, NAD, AVSS
Abdomen soft, non-distended 
Foley in place, secured to medial thigh. 
Bilateral lower extremities w/out edema, pitting or pain to deep 
palpation of calves
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:55AM BLOOD WBC-9.6 RBC-4.11*# Hgb-11.9*# Hct-36.0*# 
MCV-88 MCH-29.0 MCHC-33.1 RDW-14.9 RDWSD-48.0* Plt ___

___ 05:55AM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-11 Creat-0.9 Na-138 
K-4.3 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-10

___ 12:22PM OTHER BODY FLUID STONE ANALYSIS-PND

___ 12:01 pm URINE     Site: CYSTOSCOPY      CYSTOSCOPIC. 
                            **FINAL REPORT ___
   URINE CULTURE (Final ___:    NO GROWTH
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to urology service after laser 
cystolitholapaxy of bladder stone greater than 2.5 cm, 
transurethral resection of the prostate. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. He patient received ___ antibiotic 
prophylaxis. Mr. ___ postoperative course was uncomplicated. 
He received intravenous antibiotics and continuous bladder 
irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued and Foley 
catheter was removed with an active vodiding trial.  Post void 
residuals were checked. His urine was clear and and without 
clots. He remained a-febrile throughout his hospital stay.  At 
discharge, Mr. ___ had pain well controlled with oral pain 
medications, was tolerating regular diet, ambulating without 
assistance, and voiding without difficulty.  He was given oral 
pain medications on discharge and explicit instructions to 
follow up in clinic with Dr. ___ in about ___ weeks for 
post void residual check and follow up. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. BuPROPion 100 mg PO BID 
2. Zolpidem Tartrate 5 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 
3. Lansoprazole Oral Disintegrating Tab 15 mg PO DAILY 
4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
5. tadalafil 5 mg oral DAILY:PRN 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. BuPROPion 100 mg PO BID 
2. Zolpidem Tartrate 5 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. Lansoprazole Oral Disintegrating Tab 15 mg PO DAILY 
5. tadalafil 5 mg oral DAILY:PRN 
6. Senna 8.6 mg PO DAILY Duration: 2 Doses 
7. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID dysuria/urethral discomfort 
Duration: 3 Days 
RX *phenazopyridine [Pyridium] 100 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth 
Q8HRS Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
9. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth 
twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Benign prostatic hyperplasia.
2. Bladder stone.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
These steps can help you recover after your procedure. 
Drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. 
Avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat fiber-containing 
foods and avoid foods that can cause constipation. Ask your 
doctor if you should take a laxative if you do become 
constipated. 
Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says 
it's OK. 
Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for 
four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. 
Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual 
activity in about four to six weeks. 
Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can 
drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking 
prescription pain medications. 
 
-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You 
should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.  

Should you HOLD ASPIRIN? Unless otherwise advised;  If the urine 
is still pink, hold the aspirin until it has been clear/yellow 
for at least three days. 

-If prescribed; complete the full course of antibiotics.

-You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative

- AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up 
bleeding.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
participate in high intensity physical activity for a minimum of 
four weeks or until you are cleared by your Urologist in 
follow-up

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-IF YOU HAVE A PRESCRIPTION FOR DITROPAN/OXYBUTININ: YOU MUST 
STOP at least 24hours before planned foley removal and void 
trial.

-DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your 
surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only 
for short-term periods for when leaving the house.

-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Left sided weakness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
The pt is a ___ year-old right-handed man with a history of
prostate cancer who presents with left sided weakness.  He was
reportedly last seen normal around 11:15 pm on ___.  Around 3am
his wife awoke to find him lying on the floor next to the bed,
not moving his left arm or leg, with a left facial droop.  EMS
was called, and he was initially taken to ___, 
where
he was noted to have a right gaze preference, left facial droop,
and left arm and leg weakness.  He was then Medflighted to 
___,
where a Code Stroke was called.
  
___ Stroke Scale score was 14:  
1a. Level of Consciousness: 1  
1b. LOC Question: 1  
1c. LOC Commands: 0  
2. Best gaze: 2  
3. Visual fields: 1  
4. Facial palsy: 3  
5a. Motor arm, left: 3  
5b. Motor arm, right: 0  
6a. Motor leg, left: 2  
6b. Motor leg, right: 0  
7. Limb Ataxia: x  
8. Sensory: 1  
9. Language: 0  
10. Dysarthria: 0  
11. Extinction and Neglect: 1  
 
  

 
Past Medical History:
- Prostate cancer.  Per patient he is s/p prostatectomy ___
years ago. 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother died at age ___ of CAD, father died at ___ of CAD

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: P: 71  R: 16  BP: 128/56  SaO2: 99% on RA
General: Awake, cooperative, NAD.  Lying with head and eyes
rotated to the right. 
HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in
oropharynx 
Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity 
Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W 
Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted 
Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or
organomegaly noted. 
Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses
bilaterally. 
Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. 
 
Neurologic: 
-Mental Status: Alert, oriented x to name, and ___.  Thinks 
he
is at ___, and can't decide if it is
___ or ___.  Thinks it is ___, but can correctly
name the president.  Language is fluent with intact repetition
and comprehension.  Normal prosody.  There were no paraphasic
errors.  Pt. was able to name both high and low frequency 
objects
(though had some difficulty seeing them).  Able to read though
only reads scattered words on the right side of the page.  
Speech
was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular
commands using his right arm. Left sided neglect.

-Cranial Nerves: 
I: Olfaction not tested.  
II: PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk.  Decreased blink to threat on the
left. 
III, IV, VI: Right gaze preference.  Also squeezes right eye
tightly closed, and will only look out of the left (though 
denies
diplopia when right eye is opened, but appears very
uncomfortable)
V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. 
VII: Left sided facial droop. 
VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally.  
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.  
XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. 
XII: Tongue protrudes in midline.
 
-Motor: Unable to hold left arm antigravity.  No adventitious
movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. 
  Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ 
R  5    ___   ___  5   5    4  5     5     5   5 
On left side is unable to perform formal testing.  Upper
extremity can extend at the shoulder, but otherwise has has no
movement.  He is able to briefly lift the left leg off the bed,
but can not sustain this.  Also some element of withdrawal vs.
triple flexion in his left leg in response to stimuli, but is
unable to perform similar movements voluntarily (even when told
to look at the limb).

-Sensory: No deficits cold sensation, vibratory sense 
throughout.
Decreased proprioception bilaterally in his lower extremities.
Reports that he can feel light touch and pinprick when touched 
on
the right arm and leg, but is unable to localize. Extinguishes 
to
DSS on the left. 
 
-DTRs: 
  Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach 
L  3  3    3    3   2 
R  2  2    2    2   1 
Plantar response was extensor on the left, flexor on the right 
 
-Coordination: Unable to perform FNF
 
-Gait: Deferred.

 
Pertinent Results:
CT/CTA: ___. Complete occlusion of the right internal carotid artery 
starting in its proximal segment and extending into the proximal 
right middle cerebral artery. There is abnormal blood flow, 
blood volume, and mean transit time in the right  MCA 
distribution, however on the CTA there are robust pial 
collaterals, and therefore the perfusion abnormalities are less 
cortical and more central. 
2. No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage.  
  
MRI: ___
Acute right basal ganglia and posterior temporal lobe infarcts 
in 
the MCA territory. Chronic watershed infarcts in the frontal and 
the parietal  regions. No hemorrhage. Absence of flow void in 
the right internal carotid artery indicative of occlusion. 

C: ___. No interval change since CT of ___ with presence 
of cytotoxic edema in the right basal ganglia and right 
posterior temporal lobe compatible with infarct seen on MRI 
performed on ___. No additional areas of territorial 
infarction noted. 
2. Unchanged hyperdensity in the right basal ganglia, compatible 
with 
petechial hemorrhage. 
3. Minimal mass effect without midline shift or evidence of 
herniation point. 
4. Redemonstration of right ICA/MCA compatible with occlusion. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old right-handed man with a
history notable for a prostate cancer and remote smoking who
presented with sudden onset left sided face, arm and leg 
weakness
after raking leaves the day before admission.  

He initially went to ___, and then Medflighted to
___, where his ___ Stroke Scale score was 14. Onset was deemed
to be > 6 hours ago. 

NCHCT:  CT/ CTA showed a dense right MCA, a complete occlusion 
of
the right ICA from the origin and MCA. He also has a right
carotid dissection. CTP showed that his MTT is prolonged,
predominantly in the right inferior division with a diminished
CBV at the right M2 level. 

His examination is remarkable at discharge for his right gaze 
preference (but
crosses the midline), motor neglect on the left (though he
recognizes his left hand). There is a left facial droop and
distal weakness in the left arm and leg.

We felt that he had had a right ICA dissection with a RIGHT ACA 
stroke (A2 occlusion) and RIGHT MCA hyperdense sign and a 
subsequent M2 stroke. We started a heparin drip. Once his MCA 
symptoms became stable and with his A2 ACA occluded, we decided 
to stop hep drip in the ligh tof a minor hemorrhagic conversion 
in the M2 stroke. He remained on coumadin, though. We have a 
goal INR of ___. In addition, we provided him with Ritalin in an 
attempt to stimulate his arousal systems with a good clinical 
response.   
and work him out (including TTE), though a cardiac source seems
unlikely in this context. 

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain, fever.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.  
4. polyvinyl alcohol-povidone 1.4-0.6 % Dropperette Sig: ___ 
Drops Ophthalmic PRN (as needed) as needed for dry eyes.  
5. warfarin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Once Daily at 4 
___.  
6. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12 
hours).  
7. methylphenidate 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QAM AND 
QNOON ().  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
RIGHT carotid disection with RIGHT MCA hyperdense sign and 
subsequent M2 stroke and mild hemorrhagic transformation. RIGHT 
ACA A2 segment occlusion and stroke. 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have had a disection in your carotid artery that has 
triggered two strokes in the right side of your brain. 

You need to remain on blood thinners (Coumadin) for 3 to 6 
months. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

extremity can extend at the shoulder, but otherwise has has no
movement. He is able to briefly lift the left leg off the bed,
but can not sustain this. Also some element of withdrawal vs.
triple flexion in his left leg in response to stimuli, but is
unable to perform similar movements voluntarily (even when told
to look at the limb).
-Sensory: No deficits cold sensation, vibratory sense
throughout.
Decreased proprioception bilaterally in his lower extremities.
Reports that he can feel light touch and pinprick when touched
on
the right arm and leg, but is unable to localize. Extinguishes
to
DSS on the left.
-DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach
L 3 3 3 3 2
R 2 2 2 2 1
Plantar response was extensor on the left, flexor on the right
-Coordination: Unable to perform FNF
-Gait: Deferred.
Pertinent Results:
CT/CTA: ___. Complete occlusion of the right internal carotid artery
starting in its proximal segment and extending into the proximal
right middle cerebral artery. There is abnormal blood flow,
blood volume, and mean transit time in the right MCA
distribution, however on the CTA there are robust pial
collaterals, and therefore the perfusion abnormalities are less
cortical and more central.
2. No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage.
MRI: ___
Acute right basal ganglia and posterior temporal lobe infarcts
in
the MCA territory. Chronic watershed infarcts in the frontal and
the parietal regions. No hemorrhage. Absence of flow void in
the right internal carotid artery indicative of occlusion.
C: ___. No interval change since CT of ___ with presence
of cytotoxic edema in the right basal ganglia and right
posterior temporal lobe compatible with infarct seen on MRI
performed on ___. No additional areas of territorial
infarction noted.
2. Unchanged hyperdensity in the right basal ganglia, compatible
with
petechial hemorrhage.
3. Minimal mass effect without midline shift or evidence of
herniation point.
4. Redemonstration of right ICA/MCA compatible with occlusion.
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old right-handed man with a
history notable for a prostate cancer and remote smoking who
presented with sudden onset left sided face, arm and leg
weakness
after raking leaves the day before admission.
He initially went to ___, and then Medflighted to
___, where his ___ Stroke Scale score was 14. Onset was deemed
to be > 6 hours ago.
NCHCT: CT/ CTA showed a dense right MCA, a complete occlusion
of
the right ICA from the origin and MCA. He also has a right
carotid dissection. CTP showed that his MTT is prolonged,
predominantly in the right inferior division with a diminished
CBV at the right M2 level.
His examination is remarkable at discharge for his right gaze
preference (but
crosses the midline), motor neglect on the left (though he
recognizes his left hand). There is a left facial droop and
distal weakness in the left arm and leg.
We felt that he had had a right ICA dissection with a RIGHT ACA
stroke (A2 occlusion) and RIGHT MCA hyperdense sign and a
subsequent M2 stroke. We started a heparin drip. Once his MCA
symptoms became stable and with his A2 ACA occluded, we decided
to stop hep drip in the ligh tof a minor hemorrhagic conversion
in the M2 stroke. He remained on coumadin, though. We have a
goal INR of ___. In addition, we provided him with Ritalin in an
attempt to stimulate his arousal systems with a good clinical
response.
and work him out (including TTE), though a cardiac source seems
unlikely in this context.
Medications on Admission:
None
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every
6 hours) as needed for pain, fever.
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
3. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a
day) as needed for constipation.
4. polyvinyl alcohol-povidone 1.4-0.6 % Dropperette Sig: ___
Drops Ophthalmic PRN (as needed) as needed for dry eyes.
5. warfarin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Once Daily at 4
___.
6. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H (every 12
hours).
7. methylphenidate 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QAM AND
QNOON ().
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
RIGHT carotid disection with RIGHT MCA hyperdense sign and
subsequent M2 stroke and mild hemorrhagic transformation. RIGHT
ACA A2 segment occlusion and stroke.
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or
wheelchair.
Discharge Instructions:
You have had a disection in your carotid artery that has
triggered two strokes in the right side of your brain.
You need to remain on blood thinners (Coumadin) for 3 to 6
months.
Followup Instructions:
___

___ G4P3 @ ___ presents with increasing left leg swelling
and pain. Pt was seen on ___ and had ___ which was

pain with ambulation. No personal or family hx of DVT. Denies

especially at night. No VB, LOF. +AFM.

erythema.

___ 06:20PM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-2.8 Mg-1.9

___ 05:50PM URINE Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___
___ 05:50PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG 
Glucose-150 Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG

RADIOLOGY
BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS Study Date of ___ 3:15 ___ 
INDICATION: Left inguinal and thigh pain. 
COMPARISON: Ultrasound from ___. 
FINDINGS: Waveforms at the common femoral veins show appropriate 
respiratory variability and response to Valsalva maneuvers on 
the right, and absent flow on the left. Echogenic material is 
visualized within the vein on the left and there is no evidence 
of flow on color Doppler analysis. Similar echogenic material is 
seen along the length of the superficial femoral vein which is 
noncompressible. Additionally, material seen in the popliteal 
vein, which is also non-compressible, which has no evidence of 
flow on color Doppler analysis. Echogenic material is also seen 
within the posterior tibial and peroneal vein on the left. In 
the right lower extremity, the common femoral, proximal greater 
saphenous, superficial femoral, and popliteal veins are all 
appropriately compatible. Note is made however of slightly 
isoechoic appearance to the internal contents, which was seen in 
real time to represent slow moving blood. Wall-to-wall flow is 
also noted in the posterior tibial and peroneal veins in the 
calf. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Extensive deep venous thrombosis in the left lower extremity 
extending 
from the common femoral vein into the posterior tibial and 
peroneal veins in the calf. 2. No evidence of deep venous 
thrombosis in the right lower extremity, however note is made of 
slow flow. 
  
SOFT TISSUE US Study Date of ___ 3:15 ___ 
INDICATION: Left leg and buttock pain. 
COMPARISON: None available. 
FINDINGS: Spot sonographic images obtained over the left buttock 
at the site of insulin injection revealed no subjacent 
abnormality, specifically no evidence of subjacent abscess.   
IMPRESSION: Normal ultrasound. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted for extensive left lower extremity 
DVT (please see radiology report) and was started on enoxaparin 
80mg BID subcutaneous injections.  A Factor Xa was checked at 
the appropriate time and its result was noted to be in 
therapeutic range.  She was evaluated by vascular surgery and 
physical therapy, who agreed with medical therapy as initiated, 
and provided crutches and recommended ambulation respectively.  

Of note, she has type 1 diabetes, for which the endocrine 
service was consulted.  Her insulin regimen was titrated to 
improve her blood glucose control.  

Fetal well being was affirmed with BPP ___ and AFI 20.  Fetal 
monitoring was continued with NST twice daily, which were all 
reassuring. 

She was discharged home on HD#2 in good condition with follow up 
appointments with primary obstetrician and endocrinologist.  She 
will have postpartum appointments with vascular surgery and 
hematologist.  
 
Medications on Admission:
Novolog ___ humalin ___ PNV
 
Discharge Medications:
1. B Complex-Vitamin C-Folic Acid 1 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Cap 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Enoxaparin 80 mg/0.8 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe 
Subcutaneous Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*60 syringes* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every four (4) hours as needed for pain: do not exceed 4g of 
acetaminophen in 24hours.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. NPH Insulin Human Recomb 100 unit/mL Suspension Sig: see 
separate sheet  Subcutaneous ASDIR (AS DIRECTED).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left lower extremity deep vein thrombus
type 1 diabetes

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your obstetric doctor, if you have regular, painful 
contractions, leak of fluid, vaginal bleeding, do not feel the 
baby move.  Please call your

Please keep all your follow up appointments.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
prolapse 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ROBOTIC ASSISTED LAPAROSCOPIC SUPRACERVICAL HYSTERECTOMY 
BILATERAL SALPINGO-OOPHORECTOMY; SACROCERVICOPEXY, SUBURETHRAL 
SLING;  AND CYSTOSCOPY 

 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ yo Gravida 4 Para 4 who presents with 
primary complaint of urinary incontinence and vaginal prolapse. 
She is complaining of mixed incontinence. Her symptoms have been 
present for approximately ___ years. She believes that they are 
now worse. She reports ___ incontinence events per day 
characterized as mixed (Urge>stress). She voids ___ times per 
day and ___ times per night. She uses ___ pads per day. She 
admits to some urgency, she denies any dysuria and reports 
bladder emptying with normal flow. She denies any hematuria, 
UTI's, kidney stones or pyelonephritis. Mrs. ___ also admits 
to some vaginal pressure and palpable prolapse. She also admits 
to constipation. She is sexually active and does not experience 
dyspareunia. She admits to vaginal dryness.

She underwent pessary fitting, that she wore for approximately 
15 months. However, she continued to be symptomatic from her 
prolapse and then her pessary fell out. She was also treated 
with oxybutynin for her urinary incontinence with minimal 
improvement in her symptoms. She was counseled regarding her 
options for management and elected to proceed with definitive 
surgical management. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Fibromyalgia, GERD, Hypercholesterolemia, Insomnia, ? HTN
PSH: BTL
ObHx: SVDx4
GynHx: Denies abnl paps, STIs. Postmenopausal since age ___. 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On day of discharge:
VS: wnl
Gen: well-appearing, NAD
CV: RRR
Pulm: CTAB
Abd: soft, mildly distended, mildly and appropriately tender to 
palpation in lower quadrants, no rebound or guarding, incisions 
with steri strips appear clean/dry/intact except for scant dried 
staining on steri strips, 2 suprapubic incisions with dermabond 
appear clean/dry/intact
GU: pad with minimal staining
Ext: no calf tenderness, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
N/A
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing robotic assisted supracervical hysterectomy, 
bilateral salpingoophrectomy, sacrocervicopexy, sub-urethral 
sling and cystoscopy. Please see the operative report for full 
details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. 
Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with IV Dilaudid 
and Toradol. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was 
adequate so her foley was removed. She passed a voidig trial and 
was able to void spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without 
difficulty and she was transitioned to oral pain meds 
(oxycodone, tylenol, ibuprofen). She was continued on her home 
medications for fibromyalgia and GERD. By the afternoon of 
post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding 
spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled 
with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable 
condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
anise tea, chlorthalidone prn BP, ciclopirox cream, gabapentin 
300mg three times daily, ibuprofen 600mg twice daily, linzess 
290mg daily, omeprazole 20mg daily, align

1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H Duration: 3 Doses 
Do not take >4000mg acetaminophen in 24h.

daily. Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*1
3. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 
4. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
Take with food to avoid GI upset.

#*60 Tablet Refills:*1
5. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
Do not drive or combine with alcohol. 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*0

Home

Cystocele

 
Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after your 
procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office 
with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions 
below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.
* The dermabond glue over your two lower incisions will dissolve 
on its own over the next few weeks. 

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: SURGERY

Chief Complaint:
GIST tumor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
lap gastric wedge resection - ___ ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ w/ hx of HTN who is presenting
here to clinic for evaluation of GIST in gastric fundus. She
recently underwent a CT A/P on ___ for evaluation of pelvic
pain and was found to have uncomplicated sigmoid diverticulitis
(which was managed outpatient w/ PO abx) and a 2 cm mass in
gastric fundus was incidentally noted. She then underwent 
EGD/EUS
___ which showed a 1.8 x 1.4 cm submucosal lesion in gastric
fundus, bx of which was c/w GIST. She had some tarry stools 
which
she attributed to her PO abx for diverticulitis and some mild
lower abd pain, but o/w has no other sx, including f/c/s, abd
distension, n/v, or BRBPR; ROS is o/w -ve except as noted 
before.

 
Past Medical History:
See OMR
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Fam Hx: father - esophageal cancer

 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NAD, AxOx3
Card: RRR
Pulm: no respiratory distress
Abd: Soft, mild appropriate-tender, non-distended, normal bs.  
Wounds: c/d/I. dressings removed
Ext: No edema, warm well-perfused
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented on ___ for a laparoscopic gastric wedge 
resection. There were no adverse events in the operating room; 
please see the operative note for details. Post-operatively the 
patient was taken to the PACU until stable and then transferred 
to the wards until stable to go home.  
 #SURGICAL COURSE:
 #NEURO: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was initially managed with IV medications 
prior to transition to PO medications on POD1. Pain was very 
well controlled.  
 #CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.  
 #PULMONARY: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.  
 #GI/GU/FEN: The patient had a foley placed intra-operatively, 
which was removed post-surgery on POD with autonomous return of 
voiding. The patient was tolerating a regular diet prior to 
discharge.  
 #ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs 
of infection, of which there were none.  
 #HEME: Patient received BID SQH for DVT prophylaxis, in 
addition to encouraging early ambulation and Venodyne 
compression devices.  
 --------------------  
 At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating diet as 
above per oral, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without 
services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.  

 
Medications on Admission:
See OMR
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q4hr prn Disp #*10 
Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line  
5.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
6.  Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  
7.  Chlorthalidone 25 mg PO DAILY  
8.  Losartan Potassium 100 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
GIST

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
 Dear Ms ___,  
 It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___. You were admitted to our hospital for 
a laparascopic gastric wedge resection on ___. You tolerated 
the procedure well and are ambulating, tolerating a regular 
diet, and your pain is controlled by pain medications by mouth. 
You are now ready to be discharged to home. Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery.  
 ACTIVITY:  
 - Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.  
 - You may climb stairs. You should continue to walk several 
times a day.  
 - You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.  
 - You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
Slowly increase your activity back to your baseline as 
tolerated.  
 - Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first.  
 - No heavy lifting (10 pounds or more) until cleared by your 
surgeon, usually about 6 weeks.  
 - You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told 
you otherwise.  
 HOW YOU MAY FEEL:  
 - You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.  
 - You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during the surgery.  
 YOUR BOWELS:  
 - Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicine such as oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool 
softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such 
as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of 
these medicines without a prescription.  
 - If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.  
 - After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get 
diarrhea, don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of 
fluids and see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is 
severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon.  
 PAIN MANAGEMENT:  
 - You are being discharged with a prescription for oxycodone 
for pain control. You may take Tylenol as directed, not to 
exceed 3500mg in 24 hours. Take regularly for a few days after 
surgery but you may skip a dose or increase time between doses 
if you are not having pain until you no longer need it. You may 
take the oxycodone for moderate and severe pain not controlled 
by the Tylenol. You may take a stool softener while on narcotics 
to help prevent the constipation that they may cause. Slowly 
wean off these medications as tolerated.  
 - Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 
 
 If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:  
 - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours  
 - chest pain, pressure, squeezing, or tightness  
 - cough, shortness of breath, wheezing  
 - pain that is getting worse over time or pain with fever  
 - shaking chills, fever of more than 101  
 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain  
 - nausea and vomiting, inability to tolerate fluids, food, or 
your medications  
 - if you are getting dehydrated (dry mouth, rapid heart beat, 
feeling dizzy or faint especially while standing)  
 -any change in your symptoms or any symptoms that concern you  
 MEDICATIONS:  
 - Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently.  
 - If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon.  
 WOUND CARE:  
 -You may shower with any bandage strips that may be covering 
your wound. Do not scrub and do not soak or swim, and pat the 
incision dry. If you have steri strips, they will fall off by 
themselves in ___ weeks. If any are still on in two weeks and 
the edges are curling up, you may carefully peel them off.  
 -Do not take baths, soak, or swim for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team.  
 -Notify your surgeon if you notice abnormal (foul smelling, 
bloody, pus, etc) or increased drainage from your incision site, 
opening of your incision, or increased pain or bruising. Watch 
for signs of infection such as redness, streaking of your skin, 
swelling, increased pain, or increased drainage.  
 Please call with any questions or concerns. Thank you for 
allowing us to participate in your care. We hope you have a 
quick return to your usual life and activities.  
 -- Your ___ Team  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

a diagnosis of ___ disease for approximately eight and a 
half years.  The patient states that she had initial symptoms of 
right upper extremity tremor as well
as foot cramping on the right.  She initially sought medical 
attention with her PCP.  She then saw a neurologist, who made 
the diagnosis of ___ disease.  She was given a trial of 
Levodopa, which helped her symptoms.  She has done well with the 
medications, though Compton needed to be added later on as well 
as Ropinirole.  She remains Levodopa responsive, but is now 
suffering with on and off fluctuations with severe cramping in 
the off state.  She denies any significant dyskinesias in the 
on-state.  She also denies any difficulties with falls or 
cognitive issues.  She states that sometimes she sees some 
shadows, but she has no true hallucinations and of late, she has 
had some new irritability.  Because of her on and off 
fluctuations, you referred her for possible ___ brain 
stimulation surgery.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Dr. ___ Brain ___ 

Surgery
· You underwent Stage I and will need to contact the office to 
confirm the date for your Stage II surgery. Your staples/ 
sutures will be removed at that time. 

Activity
· You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we 
recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours.
· Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise 
should be avoided for ten (10) days.
· You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much too soon.
· Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for fourteen 
(14) days after your procedure.
·  The dressing covering your head incision(s) may be removed 
after 48 hours. You may use a damp washcloth to remove any dried 
blood or iodine from your skin but do not get your head wet in 
the shower until your staples or sutures are removed.
·  The incision on your chest has absorbable sutures and skin 
sealant. You may take a shower and get your chest wet after 5 
days.

Medications
· Resume your normal ___ medications. The neurologist 
programming your device may adjust your medications once 
programming begins. 
· Take any new medications (i.e. pain medications) as directed.
· If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (Clopidogrel), or Aspirin, do not take this until cleared 
by your Neurosurgeon. 
· Do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, 
Aspirin, Advil, or Ibuprofen etc. until follow up.
· You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
· Mild tenderness along the incisions. 
· Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
· Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
 

Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
· Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
· Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
· Severe Constipation
· Blood in your stool or urine
· Nausea and/or vomiting
· Extreme sleepiness
· Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
· Seizures
· Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
· Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

This is a ___ on coumadin for DVT prophylaxis who was 
transferred to ___ for management of an RP bleed.  She had a L 
hip ORIF ___ at ___, was discharged to rehab in good 
condition, and was found to have a hct of 21.3 today down from 
28 two days ago.  She was also noted to have a large L flank
ecchymosis.  She was taken to ___, where CT showed a 
large L bleed in the psoas muscle.  Cannot determine active

spinal stenosis

hx diveritulitis

bodies of T12 and L1, likely old compression fractures

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: Alert but hard of hearing, NAD   
CV: RRR  
PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R  
ABD: Soft, nondistended, LLQ tenderness is improving, echymosis 
is improving.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:29PM   WBC-12.8* RBC-3.42*# HGB-10.0*# HCT-28.3*# 
MCV-83 MCH-29.3 MCHC-35.5* RDW-15.7*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female w/p L hip ORIF on ___ at ___, 
recently discharged to rehab on coumadin for DVT prophylaxis, 
was found to have a HCT of 21.3 down from 28 two days prior. She 
was noted to have a large L flank ecchymosis and CT at ___- 
___ revealed a large bleed in the left psoas muscle. It was 
unclear whether she had active bleeding. Her INR was noted to be 
elevated at 2.4. At ___, she initially received 2 units of 
FFP, 2 units of PRBCs, and 10 of vitamin K. She was taken to 
interventional radiology where they could not find any active 
bleeding. She received an additional 2 units of blood, and was 
having hematocrits followed every 6hrs. Her hematocrits were 
stable and she was sent to the floor. Her hematocrits are stable 
on the floor, she is tolerating a regular diet, and is stable to 
go back to her rehab. She was on coumadin when she had this 
bleed, we are holding this. Instead we placed her on lovenox 
because this will be easier to reverse if she has another bleed. 
We are discharging her with this and instructions to follow up 
with her primary orthopaedic surgeon within the week to discuss 
anticoagulation.  

 
Medications on Admission:
coumadin (by orthopedics for ___ weeks post ORIF), ciprofloxacin 
for UTI until ___, tylenol ___ TID prn,oxycodone 5mg q6h prn

 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day).  
2. ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 2 days.  
3. Lovenox 30 mg/0.3 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous once 
a day for 1 months.  
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
spontaneous retroperitoneal bleed

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital because of severe anemia 
coming from a spontaneous retroperitoneal.
* You required blood transfusions and your blood thinner 
medication was stopped to avoid further bleeding.
* Currently your blood count is stable and you are being 
transferred back to rehab so that you can continue with Physical 
Therapy for your hip.
*You were on coumadin after your hip surgery. We are holding the 
coumadin. In place of this we have started lovenox, because this 
is easier to reverse in case you have another bleed. You should 
follow up with your orthopaedic surgeon within 1 week to discuss 
this issue as well.

Name: ___. Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: F Service: MEDICINE Allergies: shellfish derived Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Increased confusion Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: None History of Present Illness: Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a history of dementia residing in a memory unit and recurrent UTIs who presents with acute onset of confusion. Patient is noncommunicative, so history is taken from son ___, chart review, and discussion with ___. Patient was sleepy yesterday, but otherwise was communicative and interactive. This AM apparently very unresponsive. She was also having difficulty breathing. She does have COPD and was a lifelong smoker, but never had a admission before for a COPD exacerbation. Apparently no cough or SOB. Her symptoms are consistent with prior UTIs. She was evaluated in the ED on ___nd altered mental status. CT head and cervival spine were normal. While there, urine culture grew alpha hemolytic strep. No antibiotics were given. She was treated for a UTI in ___ with ciprofloxacin. She has not been hospitalized in ___ years, since she had her ORIF. In the ED, patient was apparently wheezing and hypoxic, with an elevated lactic acid. A CXR was read there as concerning for aspiration PNA. She was given 2.5 liters NS, vancomycin, cefepime, and IV clindamycin, as well as duonebs and methylprednisolone, and admitted to medicine for a PNA versus COPD exacerbation. Past Medical History: Dementia Hearing loss Recurrent UTIs COPD -- no prior hospitalizations, unknown severity Social History: ___ Family History: FAMILY HISTORY: Reviewed and found to be not relevant to this illness/reason for hospitalization. Physical Exam: DISCHARGE EXAM: VITALS: Afebrile and vital signs stable (see eFlowsheet) GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate CV: Heart regular, no murmur but there is significant JVD 4 cm below the angle of the jaw RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation anteriorly. GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation. Bowel sounds present. GU: No suprapubic fullness or tenderness to palpation MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect NEUROLOGIC: MENTATION: alert and cooperative. She did seem nonsensical when asked for her name. This is baseline per the family. Pertinent Results: ___ Imaging CHEST (PORTABLE AP) TECHNIQUE: Single portable view of the chest. COMPARISON: Chest x-ray from ___. FINDINGS: There is biapical scarring as seen previously. Calcified granulomas noted in the right lung. There is no focal consolidation worrisome for infection. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits. No acute osseous abnormalities. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. COMPLETE BLOOD COUNT WBC RBC Hgb Hct MCV MCH MCHC RDW RDWSD Plt Ct ___ 06:50 8.3 4.00 12.4 38.1 95 31.0 32.5 14.7 51.8* 330 RENAL & GLUCOSE Glucose UreaN Creat Na K Cl HCO3 AnGap ___ 06:50 961 19 0.5 144 3.8 101 32 112 ___ 9:45 am URINE **FINAL REPORT ___ URINE CULTURE (Final ___: PRESUMPTIVE GARDNERELLA VAGINALIS. >100,000 CFU/mL. Brief Hospital Course: TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -Patient will complete a 10 day course of cipro for the UTI, last day to take is on ___ -Of note she had elevated JVD on exam. It is reasonable to presume she has CHF, with unknown EF. She appeared comfortable and stable on a daily exam, and is likely at euvolemia. She had SOB earlier in her stay resolved with treatment of COPD, so it was unlikely due to CHF exacerbation. But, given her COPD history, she may very well have predominant right sided heart failure. This should be followed up as an outpatient. She should have consideration for outpatient echocardiogram, with low threshold to initiate diuretic therapy if signs or symptoms of hypervolemia occur. She should have daily weights to monitor this as well. If her weight exceeds 3 pounds from a baseline weight, her PCP should be notified. HOSPITAL COURSE: Ms. ___ is a ___ female with past medical history of dementia residing in a memory unit and recurrent UTIs who presented with acute onset of confusion found to have sepsis without septic shock, most likely from a urinary source. She presented with UTI with now resolved sepsis from admission. Her confusion also returned to baseline mental status as confirmed by the family. The UCx disappointingly did not isolate specific pathogenic bacteria. It did isolate presumptive gardnerella vaginalis. She has been transitioned to cipro PO from IV CTX earlier in her stay, for planned 10 day course of antibiotics. However, this would be ineffective at treating gardnerella, which was probably not pathogenic as the cause of her UTI, given her improvement on cipro alone. It is reasonable to continue cipro course for organisms not isolated in the UCx as the presumed true cause of her UTI, given her improvement. But she should be given metronidazole if sign/symptoms of treatment failure occurs for the gardnerella. During her stay, she did have empiric IV methylprednisolone and nebulizers in the ED briefly for hypoxic respiratory failure requiring supplemental oxygen, but it was not continued as she had little evidence of true exacerbation of COPD on exam. It's more likely that the patient initially presented with hypoxia from somnolence and hypoventilation versus aspiration pneumonitis. There was no evidence of secondary infection of aspirate, so antibiotic coverage for an aspiration pneumonia was not necessary. text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Lower extremity weakness 

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: L2-5 posterior laminectomies
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female hx of diabetes, htn, osteoarthritis presents 
with lower extremity weakness. Patient states approximately 5 
days ago she developed lower extremity weakness. She states she 
developed lower back pain with difficulty with moving her legs 
and difficulty ambulating. These symptoms progressively worsened 
and developed burning sensation and pain to bilateral lower 
extremities. The weakness was profound and she sustained a fall. 
At baseline she ambulates without assisted devices and she had 
to use walker to get around. Patient was concerned and was seen 
by her PCP who referred her to orthopedic
surgery for possible cortisone injection to left knee. Patient 
states she felt her symptoms might be related to osteoarthritis 
as she needs a knee replacement. She was evaluated by orthopedic 
MD who recommended MRI lumbar spine. MRI lumbar spine was 
scheduled for ___ and her family was concerned regarding her 
lower extremity weakness and brought her to the ED. On 
presentation she denies urinary or fecal incontinence, 
parasthesias or numbness.  Patient was code corded in ED and MRI 
lumbar spine revealed L3-4 severe lumbar stenosis with cord 
compression. Neurosurgery consulted for further evaluation. 
 
Past Medical History:
Type 2 diabetes 
Hypertension 
Hiatal hernia 
Left knee osteoarthritis 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge: ___
============================

General:
___ 0737 Temp: 98.2 PO BP: 95/58 L Lying HR: 62 RR: 18 O2
sat: 94% O2 delivery: Ra 

Exam:
Opens eyes: [x]spontaneous [ ]to voice [ ]to noxious

Orientation: [x]Person [x]Place [x]Time

Follows commands: [ ]Simple [x]Complex [ ]None

Pupils: PERRLA

EOM: [x]Full [ ]Restricted

Face Symmetric: [x]Yes [ ]No

Motor: 
TrapDeltoidBicepTricepGrip
IPQuadHamATEHLGast
___

Wound: 
[x]Clean, dry, intact. Staples in place and intact. No active
drainage noted, no erythema or edema. 

 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent lab and imaging data. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ who presented to the emergency department 
for bilateral lower extremity weakness. MRI and clinical 
findings were concerning and warranted surgical intervention. 
She underwent L2-5 posterior laminectomies on ___ and 
tolerated the procedure well. Post-operatively she was 
extubated, recovered in the PACU and transferred to the floor 
once stable. Post-operatively her physical exam noted minimal 
improvement with persistent foot drop thought to be unrelated to 
the spinal pathology seen intra-operatively. She was tolerating 
a diet, ambulating with assistance on POD #1, had adequate pain 
control on oral medications and voiding on her own at the time 
of discharge. Patient remained neurologically stable throughout 
her hospitalization. Social work was consulted on POD #1 given 
recent significant family loss and effective coping strategies/ 
support. ___ saw the patient on POD 1 and determined appropriate 
to discharge to rehab, case management made aware and began 
working with patient regarding placement options. Patient was 
started on ___ 24 hours post-operatively for DVT prophylaxis. 
Patient's surgical dressing was removed on POD #2, surgical 
incision CDI, no erythema, edema or drainage noted, incision 
closed with staples. Initially incision was left OTA, however 
per patient request her incision was dressed lightly with gauze 
and tape. Patient was discharged to rehab on ___ with 
instructions for follow up. Patient in agreement with discharge 
plan. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Atenolol 25mg daily; atorvastatin 80mg QHS; metformin 500mg QAM; 
naproxen 500mg BID; omeprazole 20mg BID; quinapril 20mg daily; 
ASA 81mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN for fever or pain 
Do not exceed more than 4G per day.  
2.  Diazepam 1 mg PO Q12H:PRN muscle spasm  
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
4.  Heparin 5000 UNIT SC BID  
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Partial fill upon request.   
6.  Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS  
7.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
8.  Atenolol 25 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM  
10.  MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO DAILY  
11.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO Q12H  
12.  Quinapril 20 mg PO DAILY  
13.  Triamterene-HCTZ (37.5/25) 1 CAP PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Spine Surgery without Fusion

Surgery
°Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery, 
this has been removed while inpatient. 
°Your incision is closed with staples. You will need staple 
removal. Please keep your incision dry until staple removal, if 
your incision becomes wet pat dry. 
°Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
°Please avoid swimming for two weeks after staple removal.
°       Please continue to monitor your incision daily for signs 
and symptoms of infection such as; redness, swelling or 
drainage. 
°Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
°We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
°You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
°No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
°No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
°***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
        - You have been restarted on your home Aspirin. You may 
continue to take this daily as prescribed. 
°*** You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
°You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
°It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
°Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
°Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
°New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

driver who suffered low speed collision vs. cement wall.  
Initially taken to OSH where initial GCS 15, however, patient 
proceeded to display large volume hematemesis, and thus, was 
intubated there due to concern for airway protection.  Pan-scan

hematemesis is subsequently felt to have been the result of 
bloody run down from his epistaxis.  Patient was then

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male who presents as trauma 
following motor vehicle collision against a cement wall while 
intoxicated.  Per report, patient was intoxicated. He was 
intubated at an outside hospital for hematemesis which was later 
determined to have been the result of his epistaxis. He was 
transferred to ___ and admitted 
to the Trauma Surgical ICU due to intubation. After admission, 
plastic surgery was consulted for management of nasal fracture 
with overlying complex nasal laceration. The laceration was 
repaired successfully. The patient was subsequently extubated on 
hospital day 2 and subsequently transferred to the floor where 
he remained throughout the rest of his hospitalization. He 
remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable throughout.

At the time of discharge, he was tolerating a regular diet. His 
pain was controlled with oral medications alone. He was voiding 
without difficulty and ambulating without assistance. He was see 
by social work who counseled him on options for alcohol 
cessation; however, the patient refused additional help. He was 
given the appropriate discharge instructions and will follow-up 
with plastic surgery shortly on ___ for suture 
removal and to see Dr. ___ in clinic. He will be discharged on 
a few days of Duricef to complete a 1 week course of 
antibiotics. He received a tetanus shot while in the ED. 
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM
3. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY
4. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY
5. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO BID
 
Discharge Medications:

6. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not drink or drive while taking pain medications.

Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
Take with meals. Stop for loose or watery stools.

RX *cefadroxil 1 gram 1 tablet(s) by mouth DAILY Disp #*5 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
nasal laceration
nasal bone and maxillary sinus fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ after 
being involved in a motor vehicle accident. You sustained nasal 
laceration and nasal/maxillary bone fracture. You were seen by 
the plastic surgery service who repaired your nasal laceration, 
but are now recovered and ready for discharge. Please follow the 
instructions below to continue your recovery.

DIET: Continue your diet at home. There are no restrictions.

MEDICATIONS: 
- Continue taking your medications at home. 
- You will be prescribed an antibiotic that you should take for 
5 more days to prevent infection. 
- You may take over the counter acetaminophen/Tylenol (extra 
strength) for pain, but do not exceed 3000 mg a day. We will 
give you a prescription for oxycodon, a narcotic pain medication 
for severe pain. Do not drink or operate machinery while taking 
this medication. It may cause dizziness or drowsiness. It may 
also cause constipation, for which you should taken an over the 
counter stool softener or laxative to help.

ACTIVITY: You may resume your normal activities at home. Avoid 
activities that may cause further injury to your face. You may 
shower and let soapy water run over your face, but avoid 
scrubbing the laceration. Do not soak your face in water. 

If you experience fever > 101, chills, nausea, vomiting, or pain 
not relieved by pain medications, please call the plastic 
surgery office or return to the emergency department.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Tylenol OD

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with a PMH s/f substance abuse, who ingested 
150 500mg tables of Tylenol at 1pm on ___. She was taken to 
an OSH ED where her Tylenol level was noted to be 424 at approx 
2pm. She was started on NAC but infused at the incorrect dose. 
She was transferred to ___ ED where her Tylenol level was 450 
at 7:30pm. It is unclear if she recieved charcol in the first 
four hours s/p ingestion.  
.  
In the ED, initial vs were: VS 87 112/62 20 98% RA. Patient was 
reloaded with NAC at 150mg/kg over 1 hr, then continued on 
50mg/kg over 4 hours. She was initially admitted to the floor, 
but given concerns for her impending liver failure she was 
admitted to the ICU. She endorses N/V.  
 
Past Medical History:
1. Migraine headaches
2. Substance abuse- Narcotics 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals - T:99.1 BP:116/65 HR:97 RR:24 02 sat:97% RA  
GENERAL: Young, healthy appearing young woman, cooperative and 
pleasant.  
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No conjunctival pallor. No 
scleral icterus. PERRLA/EOMI. MMM. OP clear. Neck Supple, No 
LAD, No thyromegaly.  
CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs, 
rubs or ___. 
LUNGS: CTAB, good air movement biaterally.  
ABDOMEN: NABS. Soft, NT, ND. No HSM. Abdominal striae.  
EXTREMITIES: No edema or calf pain, 2+ dorsalis pedis/ posterior 
tibial pulses.  
SKIN: No rashes/lesions, ecchymoses. Multiple tattoos.  
NEURO: A&Ox3. Appropriate. CN ___ grossly intact. Preserved 
sensation throughout. ___ strength throughout.  
PSYCH: Listens and responds to questions appropriately, 
pleasant.  Occasionally tearful. 

 
Pertinent Results:
Peak ALT/AST on admission (___)- 101/67, trended down to 
___ on ___.
.
Total bilirubin remained within normal limits
.
Peak acetaminophen level on ___ was 450, cleared by 
___
.
INR peaked at 1.4 on ___, and normalized to 1.0 on 
___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was initially admitted to the Medical ICU out of 
concern for possible liver failure after ingesting ~75g of 
acetaminophen in an attempt to commit suicide.  She was started 
on the appropriate dose of N-acetylcysteine, using an 
intravenous protocol secondary to nausea and vomiting.  She 
tolerated this well, and her transaminases, acetaminophen 
levels, and coagulation parameters normalized by hospital day 
#4, at which point the NAC was discontinued.  She was maintained 
on a 1:1 sitter, and was co-managed with psychiatric 
consultation.  She agreed to the plan of care recommended by 
both the medicine and psychiatric teams, which was inpatient 
psychiatric care.

She developed menstrual cramps during her hospital stay, which 
was managed with ibuprophen.  For anxiety and insomnia, she was 
written for 0.5mg lorazepam as needed at bedtime.

 
Medications on Admission:
Oral contraceptive pills
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Nicotine 21 mg/24 hr Patch 24 hr Sig: One (1) Patch 24 hr 
Transdermal DAILY (Daily).  
2. Promethazine 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for nausea.  
3. Lorazepam 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime) as needed for insomnia.  
4. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acetaminophen overdose- medically cleared for inpatient 
psychiatric care

 
Discharge Condition:
Normal mental status, stable vital signs, ambulatory.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after a tylenol overdose.  You tolerated 
treatment with a medication called "N-acetylcysteine" very well 
with no complications.  Your liver function improved, as you 
cleared the tylenol.  We are recommending inpatient psychiatric 
care to help initiate management of your anxiety.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

catheter).

The patient is a ___ Caucasian male who had sudden onset 
of dyspnea and chest discomfort 2 days prior to admission. He 
had noted such symptoms while playing basketball yesterday, and 
at 4 am the pain became sharp and right sided. He thought 
nothing of the pain, and early in the morning he syncoped in the 
stairwell of his partment building and was brought to the ED by 
ambulance. This has never happened before. CXR on admission 
showed a ___ rib apical pneumothorax on the right side 
consistent with primary spontaneous pneumothorax for which a 
right sided chest tube/dart placement ___ pneumothorax 
catheter).

 
Past Medical History:
Denies. Knee surgery ___ years prior
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No history of lung, colonic or esophageal malignancy.
 
Physical Exam:
General: NAD
Cardiac: RRR normal S1,S2 no murmur/gallop or rub
Resp. clear breath sounds throughout
GI: benign
Extr: warm no edema
Neuro: non-focal
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-7.1 RBC-5.11 Hgb-15.9 Hct-46.4 MCV-91 MCH-31.1 
MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.1 Plt ___

___ ___ PTT-22.1 ___

___ Glucose-110* UreaN-19 Creat-1.1 Na-142 K-4.0 Cl-108 
HCO3-24 

___ cTropnT-<0.01

___ Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.2 Mg-2.2

___ D-Dimer-439

CXR
___ The patient is status post chest tube placement for 
right apical 
pneumothorax. No residual pneumothorax is seen. The lungs are 
clear. No 
pleural effusion or pulmonary edema is seen. The heart, 
mediastinal, hilar, and pleural surface contours are normal. 

___: 1. Almost complete interval resolution of right apical 
pneumothorax, with right chest tube in place with tip at the 
right lung apex.  
2. Subcutaneous emphysema along right neck and right chest wall, 
projecting anteriorly on the lateral view. 

___:  Status post pleural catheter removal without evidence 
of residual pneumothorax. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ED with chest pain and shortness 
of breath.  A chest x-ray was done and showed a right apical 
pneumothorax.  A right pigtail was placed, placed to pneumovac 
with complete re-expansion of the lung.  He was admitted with a 
pigtail to water-seal for 24 hrs, follow-up chest film showed 
residual pneumothorax.  The pigtail was placed to suction, 
follow-up chest film showed 1. Almost complete interval 
resolution of right apical pneumothorax, with  right chest tube 
in place with tip at the right lung apex.  Subcutaneous 
emphysema along right neck and right chest wall, projecting  
anteriorly on the lateral view. 
He remained on suction for 24 hrs placed to water seal with 
resolution of right apical pneumothorax. The chest tube was 
removed without evidence of residual 
pneumothorax. He was discharged to home and will follow-up as an 
outpatient.

 
Medications on Admission:
None. Patient denied.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

 
Discharge Condition:
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
-Fevers > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, cough or chest pain
-Chest tube site remove dressing ___ and cover site with a 
bandaid until healed.
-You may shower.  No swimming or tub bathing until site healed

 
Followup Instructions:
___

HCO3-27

CXR:
___: There may be a minimal residual pneumothorax. The 
lungs are otherwise clear with no pneumonia or vascular 
congestion. 
___: There is slight interval decrease in the subcutaneous 
air within the right chest wall. There is no apparent evidence 
of pleural effusion. There is minimal apical pneumothorax noted 
on the right. The left lung is 
unremarkable. 
___: The current study demonstrates no appreciable apical 
pneumothorax.  Subcutaneous air is unchanged. There is no 
evidence of basal pneumothorax.  The aeration of the lungs is 
preserved. The chest tubes are in unchanged position. 
___: The extent of the right apical pneumothorax is 
constant. No evidence of tension. Unchanged normal size of the 
cardiac silhouette. Unchanged normal appearance of the left 
lung. 
___: At the right lung apex, there is a 
small-to-moderate apical pneumothorax. There is no mediastinal 
shift to 
suggest tension. Lungs are otherwise clear without consolidation 
or pleural effusion.. There is no left-sided pneumothorax. The 
heart size is normal. There is no hilar or mediastinal 
enlargement. Pulmonary vascularity is normal. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ for recurrent spontaneous 
right apical pneumothorax. On ___ he was taken to the 
operating room for right video-assisted blebectomy with 
mechanical and chemical pleurodesis.  He was extubated in the 
operating room, monitored in the PACU prior transfer to the 
floor.

Respiratory.  he titrated off oxygen with saturations 94% on 
room air with ambulation and incentive spirometer.

Chest-tube: 2 right ___ drains were to suction for 48hrs 
transitioned to water-seal subsequently removed.

Chest-film: followed by serial chest films see above reports.

Cardiac: hemodynamically stable in sinus rhythm

GI; benign.  tolerated a regular diet

Renal: normal good urine output

Pain: well controlled with IV and PO narcotics.

Disposition: On ___ he was discharged to home with his wife 
and will follow-up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain .

Discharge Disposition:
Home

Recurrent Spontaneous Right Pneumothorax

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
-Fevers > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, cough or chest pain
-Chest tube site removed dressing ___, Cover site with a 
bandaid until healed.

-No tub bathing or swimming until incision healed
-No driving while taking narcotics.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/Pneumoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was not required.  Physical therapy 
was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  Hospital course 
was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of discharge the patient 
was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain 
control and tolerating a regular diet.
 
Medications on Admission:
Oxycodone PRN
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Diazepam ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN spasm 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
Hold for sedation, RR<12 or altered mental status
 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L4-5 and L5-S1 Herniated Discs

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
Alert
Ambulating

 
Discharge Instructions:
Microdiscectomy

You have undergone the following operation: Minimally Invasive 
Microdiscectomy

 

Immediately after the operation:

     Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs 
for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or 
stand more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

 

     Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 

___           ___ times a day you should go for a walk for 
___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as 
you can tolerate. 

___           Limit any kind of lifting.

 

     Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery. 

 

     Brace: You do not need a brace.

 

     Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the 
incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

 

     You should resume taking your normal home medications.

 

     You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions 
(oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.  In addition, 
we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days 
from the date of surgery.

 

     Follow up: 

___           Please Call the office and make an appointment 
for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been 
done already.

___           At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may 
at that time start physical therapy.

___           We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day 
of the operation and at that time release you to full activity.

 

 

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
N/V, flank pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: ___ y/o M with no sig PMHx here with 1d of LLQ/flank pain 
and N/V. Nonbloody emesis. No f/chills. Denies any dysuria or 
pain with urination.  
.  
In the ED, VS were stable. He was given Zofran 4mg x1, Toradol 
30mg IV x1, MS 4mg IV x2, Cipro 400mg IV x1. A CT abd 
demonstrated a L UVJ obstructing stone c/b 
hydroureter/hydronephrosis and L kidney stranding. He was seen 
by urology and admitted to medicine for further w/u.  

 
Past Medical History:
1) Acne  
2) Hx of GIB, hosp for 5d. Had (-) EGD, c-scope, pill endoscopy, 
Meckel's scan. No source ever isolated.  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C
 
Physical Exam:
 
T:99.8 BP:134/76 P:84 RR:24 O2 sats:100%RA  
Gen: Well appearing, nontoxic.  
HEENT: Anicteric  
CV: RRR  
Resp: CTAB  
Abd: Soft. NTND. no HSM  
Back: Mild CVAT on left  
Guaiac: (-) per ED report  
Ext: no edema  
Neuro: AAOx3.  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-10.1 RBC-4.10* Hgb-12.2* Hct-35.0* MCV-86 Plt 
___
___ Glucose-94 UreaN-9 Creat-1.3* Na-142 K-4.0 Cl-110* 
HCO3-25 
___ URINE Blood-LG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-TR 
Ketone-50 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.0 Leuks-NEG
___ URINE ___ ___ Yeast-NONE Epi-0
. 
IMAGING: 
CTU ___: 
1. 2-mm obstructing left ureterovesicular junction stone with 
moderate left- sided hydronephrosis resulting.
2. Apparent minimal thickening of the descending colonic wall, 
though underdistended. If the patient has lower GI symptoms, 
this could be reassessed with a study including better oral 
prepration.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: ___ y/o M with no sig PMHx here with ___ kidney stone  
.  
# Nephrolithiasis  
First episode of kidney stone in patient without previous 
history. Seen by urology in ED who recommended symptomatic 
treatment and f/u with urology.  He was given morphine & Zofran 
IV overnight and treated with aggressive IVF hydration.  His 
pain improved in the AM and he was tolerating PO fluids without 
requiring pain medications.  He was to finish a 1 week course of 
Flomax, and given Percocet for pain control prn.  He will f/u 
with urology (Dr. ___ in 2 weeks. He was instructed to 
continue to strain his urine and if he is able to isolate the 
stone to submit it to his PCP/urologist for stone analysis. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Doxy 100 bid 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Doxycycline Hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
Q12H (every 12 hours).  
2. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime) for 1 weeks.
Disp:*7 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for 5 doses.
Disp:*5 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Nephrolithiasis

 
Discharge Condition:
Tolerating PO fluids, stable for discharge home

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a kidney stone.  Please continue to take 
fluids and strain your urine for the next day to try to isolate 
the kidney stone so it can by analyzed.
. 
Please take medications as instructed below. 
. 
If you develop worsening nausea or vomiting, inability to take 
fluids, severe abdominal pain, pain or burning with urination, 
bloody urine or any other concerning symptoms, please contact 
your doctor or report to the nearest ED.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

UTI
