None

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI:  Pt is a ___ with a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis
who presents POD 2 from left laser lithotripsy of an 8mm left 
UPJ
stone with stent placement with nausea, vomitting, and ___ 
left
flank and groin pain.  The pt reports feeling well immediately
after surgery, but the evening of, once she got home, began to
have intense left back pain.  ___ night the pt recorded a
temperature of 102.  Today she presents with a temp of 100.8 and
continues left flank and LLQ pain with n/v such that she cannot
keep food down.  She reports hematuria, but denies dysuria.  

PMH: Nephrolithiasis
PSH:  ___ Left laser litho and stent placement, ___ 
Right
percutaneous nephrostolithotomy, Right ureteral stent placement,
Right antegrade nephrostogram. Cholecystectomy and a C-section.
Med: None
All: morphine
Soc: denies IVDA, tob, occ etoh
FH:  NC

Labs:   Ch 7
141  ___    
3.8  25  0.9  
 
CBC: 13.1 / 34 / 332, no bands
UA: pH 8.0, mod leuk, nitrite neg, large bld
  
PE:
VS: 100.8  116  122/82  18  99RA
NAD, dry oral mucus membranes
Tachy, reg rhythm
CTAB
Abdomen soft, tender to plapation in LLQ and left flank.  No
right CVAT, no rebound.

 
Physical Exam:
NAD
afebrile
soft, nt, nd, no CVAT
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted ot Urology service with UTI and stent in place 
following laser lithotripsy, possible pyelonephritis. She 
received IV abx, IVF resuscitation, and symptomatic treatment. 
Cultures were drawn but were not insightful for abx guidance, 
laboratory studies and clinical improvement were followed and on 
HD3 she had been afebrile for > 24hrs. She was tolerating a 
house diet, ambulating, and has tolerated Bactrim in the past. 
She will complete 7 more days of abx and have her stent removed 
in the office next week by Dr. ___.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain, fever.  
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Bactrim DS 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day.
Disp:*16 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for pain: Take with food.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
UTI 

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take motrin, tylenol, and narcotic for pain control

-You may shower any time.

-No heavy lifting for 2 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

-Follow up in 1 week for stent removal by Dr. ___. Please 
take all of your antibiotic pills as directed.

-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain 
medications.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
postpartum dilation and curettage for retained products of 
conception

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ s/p SVD on ___ who presented to ED 
___ with increased vaginal bleeding and low-grade fever. She 
had a benign pre-natal course and delivery.  There was no 
concern that the placenta was not delivered intact at the time 
of the delivery. Her postpartum course was complicated only by 
separated pubic symphysis.

VS on arrival Temp 100.0 97 115/62 16 95%RA.
 
Past Medical History:
POBHx:
- SVD ___ 38 weeks per HPI
- SVD ___ 38 weeks  3200g
- VAVD ___ 37 weeks 3000g

PGynHx: Denies.  Denies abnl Paps, STIs.
PMH: Denies
PSH: Denies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VS: 100.2  
Gen: NAD, anxious
Card: RRR
Resp: CTAB
Abd: soft, mildly tender on uterine fundus 1-2cm below umb, ND
Pelvic: Deferred, min blood on peripad
Ext: NT, NE

TAUS: heterogeneous material within endometrium w/ vascularity
concerning for RPOC, 3.3cm stripe

 
Pertinent Results:
Labs:
CBC: 10.8>32.6<208 (85% PMNs)
U/A: neg
Chem7: wnl except for Cl 110

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ is a ___ yo ___ s/p SVD (___) who presented on 
___ with low grade fevers and profuse vaginal bleeding. 

#) Retained Products of Conception
The patient had an ultrasound which showed heterogeneous 
material within the endometrium with vascularity that was 
concerning for retained products of conception.  The decision 
was made to proceed with Dilation and Curettage. 
Intraoperatively a moderate amount of retained clot and tissue 
suctioned from the uterus. Atony and hemorrhage were noted after 
D&C. Uterotonics were given including 60 units of Pitocin, 0.2 
mg Methergine IM, 0.25 mg of Hemabate given x 2, and 1000 mcg 
Cytotec given PR.  A bakri balloon was placed in the uterus 
intraoperatively. 
The patient's hematocrit on presentation was noted to be 32.6. 
Postoperatively her Hct trended down to 21.6 but she denied 
symptoms of blood loss anemia. Her vital signs were stable. she 
was offered a blood transfusion but declined. The bakri foley 
output was minimal. It was kept in place for 24 hours and then 
taken out without difficulty. At discharge her vaginal bleeding 
was minimal and she had no signs or symptoms of blood loss 
anemia.

#) Endometritis
Her fevers were concerning for endometritis in the setting of 
retained products.Her white blood cell count on admission was 
10.8 and 85% neutrophils. The patient had a negative UA. In the 
PACU after her procedure she was febrile to 101.6. For two days 
she continued to have low grade fevers in the 100.4-100.6 range 
but her fever curve trended down. She received Kefzol prior to 
the procedure. Postoperatively she was treated with Gentamycin 
and Clindamycin for presumed endometritis until ___ at which 
time she was afebrile for 24 hours. At discharge her fundus was 
firm and minimally tender to palpation and she had no signs or 
symptoms of infection. Blood cultures had no growth.
 
Medications on Admission:
pre-natal vitamin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every ___ hours as needed for Pain.
Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
postpartum hemorrhage
endometritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
routine postpartum instructions
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Low back pain, Leg pain, failure of conservative therapy
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - ALIF L4-S1
___ - PSF L4-S1

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman who presents with
progressive lower back pain and disc degeneration.  She has had
previous lumbar microdiscectomy in ___ by Dr. ___ 
lumbar radiculopathy and L foot drop.  She has difficulty
walking distances and running.  Her strength is otherwise intact
in both lower extremities.  She complains of severe back and leg
discomfort and sciatica. Her most recent scan from six months 
ago
reveals a chronic disc herniation with disc space collapse at
L4-5 and L5-S1.

 
Past Medical History:
History of spontaneous vaginal delivery
History of steroid injections x3  
Lumbar disc herniation
L4-S1 microdiscectomy in ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Former user - stopped more than ___ year ago
Alcohol?  Occasionally     
Recreational Drugs?  No
Lives w/Spouse and two children
Employment status: ___
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:06AM   WBC-11.4* RBC-4.51 HGB-13.2 HCT-39.0 MCV-87 
MCH-29.3 MCHC-33.9 RDW-13.2
___ 10:06AM   PLT COUNT-215
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted from home to the orthopaedic spine 
surgery service on ___. The patients admitted complaint was 
low back and left leg pain and she was taken to the operating 
room for two staged ALIF L4-S1, PSF L4-S1, which the patient 
tolerated well (for full details please see the separately 
dictated operative report). The patient was taken from the OR to 
the PACU in stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia 
was transferred to the floor.  The patient was initially given 
IV fluids and an epidural pain catheter, and progressed to a 
regular diet and oral medications during the hospitalization. 
The patient was given perioperative antibiotics and DVT 
prophylaxis with TEDs/SCDs per routine.  The patients home 
medications were continued throughout this hospitalization.  The 
patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was 
appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.

 

At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable 
vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well 
controlled with oral medications, incisions were 
clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. A brace was placed for comfort and stability.  
The patient will follow up in 10 days with Dr. ___ 
routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and 
all questions were answered prior to discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar disc degeneration

 
Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, Ms. ___ was ambulating with assist, 
tolerating a regular diet, was A&Ox3 and pain was controlled 
without anesthesia.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Anterior and 
posterior lumbar instrumentation and fusion L4-S1 
 
Immediately after the operation:
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
for comfort when you are walking. You may take it off when 
sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.
 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 
-You should resume taking your normal home medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Fever
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ s/p SVD on ___ that was complicated by post-partum 
hemorrhage and retained products of conception requiring D&C, 
presented on ___ with fevers for 3 days. She denied 
vaginal bleeding or unusual discharge, and noted only
mild lower quadrant discomfort. She denied breast tenderness or 
erythema. She reported discomfort with urination and some 
difficulty voiding, but no urgency or frequency, and she was 
able to void. No N/V, no cough/SOB/CP, no
diarrhea/constipation, no other localizing symptoms on review of
systems. Of note, she was also treated for endometritis with her
PPH. She was seen in Gyn Triage for fevers on ___, but was
afebrile on arrival and with a benign exam. 
 
Past Medical History:
POBHx:
- SVD ___ 38 weeks per HPI
- SVD ___ 38 weeks  3200g
- VAVD ___ 37 weeks 3000g

PGynHx: Denies.  Denies abnl Paps, STIs.
PMH: Denies
PSH: Denies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
General: in  bed, no apparent distress
VS: Temp 98.6, BP 82/48, P 60, RR 20.
Cardiac: RRR, no m/g/r
Pulm: CTA all posterior lung fields
Abdomen: bowel sounds present, soft, minimally tender over 
uterine fundus. 
Ext: no edema, no pain with calf palpation
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:40PM   WBC-9.8 RBC-3.49*# HGB-10.7*# HCT-32.4* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.5 MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.5
___ 07:40PM   NEUTS-76.4* ___ MONOS-4.0 EOS-0.5 
BASOS-0.7

___ urine culture: Group A streptococcus.
___ blood cultures No growth after 4 days 
___ 07:40PM BLOOD WBC-9.8 RBC-3.49*# Hgb-10.7*# Hct-32.4* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.5 MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.5 Plt ___
___ 12:05AM BLOOD WBC-4.4# RBC-3.23* Hgb-10.0* Hct-30.4* 
MCV-94 MCH-30.9 MCHC-32.9 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 07:40PM BLOOD Neuts-76.4* ___ Monos-4.0 Eos-0.5 
Baso-0.7
___ 12:05AM BLOOD Neuts-62.0 ___ Monos-3.8 Eos-1.8 
Baso-0.8
___ 07:40PM BLOOD Glucose-136* UreaN-10 Creat-0.6 Na-134 
K-3.1* Cl-98 HCO3-24 AnGap-15
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was treated with ampicillin, gentamicin, and 
clindamycin for presumed endometritis. However she continued to 
have febrile temperature spikes despite broad spectrum 
antibiotic coverage. Imaging was used to search for a source 
infection. A pelvic ultrasound revealed no evidence of 
tubo-ovarian abscess or vascular retained products of 
conception. ___ chest x-ray was negative. ___ CT of abdomen 
and pelvis revealed no abdnormalities, and no evidence of septic 
pelvic thrombophlebitis. Cultures of blood and urine were made 
and revealed small Group A strep in urine and no growth of blood 
cultures after 4 days. 

An infectious disease consult was made on ___. The 
recommendations included continuing broad spectrum coverage 
until culture data could add more information.

Ms. ___ remained non-toxic throughout the course. She was 
discharged on ___ in good condition with the remaining 
antibiotic regimen for presumed endometritis. 
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amoxicillin 250 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO Q8H (every 
8 hours) for 2 days.
Disp:*12 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Clindamycin HCl 150 mg Capsule Sig: Three (3) Capsule PO Q6H 
(every 6 hours) for 2 days.
Disp:*24 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Endometritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call if you have increasing abdominal pain or temp > 100.4.  
Take antibiotics as prescribed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Tar colored stool
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD
 
History of Present Illness:
___ male with history of upper GI bleed ___ prior with neg 
work up presents after having multiple episodes of tar colored 
stool yesterday and today.  Pt reports feeling somewhat 
lightheaded on arrival which has since resolved.  No nausea, 
vomiting, fevers, chills.  Pt denies any syncopal episodes.  
During his last episodes at OS___ patient had coffee ground emesis 
followed by melanotic stool.  He underwent EGDx2, capsule 
endoscopy, meckel's scan, and colonscopy which were all 
negative.  He required 4U PRBCs during this hospital admission 
per patient but has been asymptomatic since.  
.
In the ED patient's vital signs were, 99, 100, 137/94, 16, 
100%/RA and orthostatic.  He received 2L NS and 40mg of IV 
protonix

 
Past Medical History:
1) Acne

# Melana: In the ED patient was tachycardic and orthostatic.  
These symptoms resolved with 2L IVF.  NGT was attempted to be 
placed for NG lavage but was unsuccessful x3.  On the floor 
Q6hour Hct were checked. Hct were always stable.  Patient was 
treated with IVF, Protonix drip, and kept NPO for EGD.  On HD#2 
patient underwent endoscopy which demonstrated polyp in the 
cardia, erosion in the stomach body which may represent a 
Dieulofoy's lesion.  The lesion was clipped.  24hours of Q6hour 
Hct were stable.  GI then recommended CT angiogram to 
investigate other possible causes of bleeding.  CT angiogram of 
the abd and pelvis was normal.  Patient remained hemodynamically 
stable and was discharge to home.  Patient will follow up as an 
outpatient with GI.

doxycycline

none

Home

GI Bleed

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

You were admitted for GI bleeding.  During your hospital course 
you underwent endsocopy which revealed erosion in the stomach 
body that may represent a Dieulofoy's lesion.  We then did a 
follow up CT Angiography of your abdomen which was normal.
.
Please call or return your nearest emergency room if you have 
tar or black colored stool, bright red blood in your stool, 
vomit with blood or coffee ground colored vomit.  Please call if 
you faint, feel dizzy, or have abdominal pain.  
.
Please keep your follow up appointments as outlined below

text:
Name:  ___.                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
renal hematoma, new renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ healthy F presented to PCP with ___ flank pain since 8am last 
AM accompanied by nausea and discovered to have a L renal mass 
4x4 nonenhancing with perinephric hematoma on CT.  Constrast 
phase does not demonstrate active bleed or enhancement of mass 
mass and there is no obstruction or extrav from the L sided 
urinary tract.  No obvious history of trauma although she was 
lifting heavy boxes full of books.  No hematuria.

She is hemodyanmically stable with HCT 36, no RBC in UA.  WBC 
10; Creat 1.1 in setting of poor PO intake.  She is in ___ pain 
but dosent want to take pain meds.

 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
afvss
abd soft, nt/nd, no CVAT
ext w/w/p
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:37PM   HCT-30.3*
___ 04:25AM   GLUCOSE-97 UREA N-10 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-137 
POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-103 TOTAL CO2-24 ANION GAP-14
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ service from 
the ___ ED for observation, serial abdominal exams, serial 
Hcts, pain control, and IV fluids. She was maintained on strict 
bedrest on HD ___, while her Hct remained stable. Her diet was 
slowly advanced on HD#2 and she continued to remaain stable. At 
discharge, HD3, patient's pain well controlled with oral pain 
medications, Hct was syable at 31, she was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating without assistance, and voiding without 
difficulty. She is given explicit instructions to call Dr. 
___ follow-up. She is instructed to avoid any 
heavy/strenuous/or sporting acitivities until cleared by Dr. 
___.
 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for pain.  
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day: 
take along with narcotic pain medications to prevent 
constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
renal hematoma, ? new renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
condition: good
mental status: alert & oriented x3
ambulatory status: independant

 
Discharge Instructions:
-No vigorous physical activity for ___ weeks!!! don't lift 
anything heavier than a phonebook for 2 weeks! NO contact sports 
such as volleyball until cleared by Dr. ___!

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)

-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated 

-You may shower and bathe normally. 

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.

-Resume all of your home medications, unless otherwise noted.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___.                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Nickel
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
left renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
robotic assisted left laparoscopic partial nephrectomy, Dr. 
___, ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ healthy F presented to PCP with ___ flank pain since 8am last
AM accompanied by nausea and discovered to have a L renal mass
4x4 nonenhancing with perinephric hematoma on CT. F/U MRI showed 
renal mass concerning for RCC.
 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD
no resp distress
abd soft nondistended approp tender
incisions c/d/i
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:20AM BLOOD WBC-8.5# RBC-3.22* Hgb-10.4* Hct-30.9* 
MCV-96 MCH-32.2* MCHC-33.5 RDW-12.4 Plt ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Glucose-117* UreaN-8 Creat-0.8 Na-137 
K-3.9 Cl-104 HCO3-27 AnGap-10
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing laparoscopic 
left partial nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events 
occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. The 
patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The 
patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable 
condition.  On POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated 
for urine output >30cc/hour, and provided with pneumoboots and 
incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, the patient 
ambulated, restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel 
and complete blood count were checked, pain control was 
transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a 
clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and urethral 
catheter (foley) were removed without difficulty (foley first 
then JP after output remained low) and diet was advanced as 
tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was relatively 
unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, 
eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without 
difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, 
incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit 
instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___ in 3 weeks.

 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for break through pain only (score 
>4) .
Disp:*35 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, oriented, ambulating

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your incision.
 
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up
 
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
 
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
 
-change drain incision site dressing as needed
 
Followup Instructions:
___

MCV-85 MCH-29.8 MCHC-35.1* RDW-12.9 Plt ___

___ blood culture x2: no growth
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the general surgery service on 
___ with the diagnosis of perforated appendicitis.  She was 
started on ampicillin, gentamicin and flagyl IV for treatment 
and was kept NPO with IV fluids.  Her pain was well controlled 
with morphine IV and she received compazine PR/IV for nausea.  
She continued to clinically improve and was started on clear 
liquids on hospital day ___, ___.  Her diet was advanced slowly 
over the next several days and began a regular diet on ___.  
Throughout her hospitalization her pain was well controlled, she 
had mild occasional nausea which was controlled with compazine.  
She continued to do well and reported no pain on hospital day 6. 
 She was transitioned to oral antibiotics, Augmentin and Flagyl 
on ___.  She was discharged home on ___ in good condition 
and will continue oral antibiotics for 3 weeks and follow up 
with Dr. ___ she returns from vacation or sooner if 
there are any problems.  
 
Medications on Admission:
Avapro, prilosec, lipitor, MVI, calcium and vitamin D, Aspirin 
162mg
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three 
times a day for 20 days.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Amoxicillin-Pot Clavulanate 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO twice a day for 20 days.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.  
4. Avapro 20mg qd
5. prilosec 40mg qd
6. lipitor 10mg qd
7. multivitamin qd
8. Calcium and vitamin D daily
9. Aspirin 162mg daily
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
perforated appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
Continue the antibiotics as directed for 3 weeks.  
Continue your home medications. 

Call your doctor or return to the emergency department for any 
increased abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting, fever >101.5F or 
anything else that concerns you.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

abd soft nttp

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had left lower extremity liposuction of lipedema.  
The patient tolerated the procedure well. 
 .
 Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received IV pain 
medication with good effect and adequate pain control. When 
tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to oral 
pain medications. 
 .
 CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
 .
 Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
 .
 GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake.  Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
 .
 Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
 .
 At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Her left lower extremity was wrapped in ace 
bandages with very mild leaking through dressings.  Her left 
medial thigh was softly bruised.

text:
Name:  ___         Unit No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  F

Service:  MED


Ms ___ was admitted on ___ because of increasing
depressive symptoms of a neurovegetative nature, as well as
suicidal ideation with planned overdose.  She presented with
these feelings during her intake interview with a new
psychiatrist, and was sent to our hospital and admitted.
While on the unit, she adjusted well, tolerated sertraline 50
mg daily, which was started here just after having been off
medications for at least a year.  She attended some groups,
but felt "cooped up", was not hopeless, was entirely future
oriented, and eager to return to live with family members and
continue looking for work.

She was quite cooperative and engaged, and was emphatically
nonsuicidal by the time of discharge.  She had an intake
appointment with her new psychiatrist at ___
shortly after discharge, and will be discharged on sertraline
50 mg daily.

WORKING DIAGNOSIS:  Recurrent major depressive disorder.

CONDITION:  Improved on discharge.

History of Present Illness:
Briefly, Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a psychiatric
history notable for PTSD and major depressive disorder with
multiple past suicide attempts and psychiatric hospitalizations
who was BIBA on a ___ from an outpatient psychiatrist's
office due to suicidal ideation.
The patient has experienced multiple depressive episodes in the
past but says that "this one is different". Asked to elaborate,
she states that she feels "lost" and as though "everything is
out
of order" since her mother's passing in ___ of this year.
In
addition to poor sleep, energy, appetite, and anhedonia she
feels
she has become paralyzed by lack of motivation and inability to
concentrate. She attempts to visit the gym each day but her
activities are otherwise limited to "sitting on the couch". She
explains that it takes her several days to plan an outing, such
as to the library, and that she rarely follows through.
With regard to suicidal ideation, the patient confirms her
desire
to "erase her existence", describing her plan to inject herself
with insulin or overdose on medications such as lisinopril,
tramadol (confirmed 30 day supply of 120 pills per ___ filled
___, and glyburide, to name ___ few, as well as insulin, which
she no longer uses but continues to have access to. She is not
tearful, but appears exhausted, and though cooperative does tell
this writer that "[she doesn't] know what else to say", having
shared her story with a number of providers this evening. Per
Dr. ___ note the patient has collected various forms
of identification in order to destroy them, effectively
destroying evidence of her existence. Having only recently
relocated from ___ she denies social supports or current
treaters. She was seen by a new psychiatrist the morning prior
to her presentation but has not been followed for a year and a
half.
Past Medical History:
Hypertension, essential
- Coronary atherosclerosis of native coronary artery (s/p
angioplasty with stent)
- Hypercholesterolemia
- Sleep apnea
- DE QUERVAIN'S DISEASE, left foot
- Leiomyoma of uterus
- DM (diabetes mellitus) type II uncontrolled with eye
manifestation
- Obesity, morbid s/p gastric bypass ___ years ago
- Premature atrial contractions

___

suicide at age ___. Two other siblings are disabled by mental

brothers.

Ms ___ was admitted on ___ because of increasing
depressive symptoms of a neurovegetative nature, as well as
suicidal ideation with planned overdose. She presented with
these feelings during her intake interview with a new
psychiatrist, and was sent to our hospital and admitted.
While on the unit, she adjusted well, tolerated sertraline 50
mg daily, which was started here just after having been off
medications for at least a year. She attended some groups,
but felt "cooped up", was not hopeless, was entirely future
oriented, and eager to return to live with family members and
continue looking for work.
She was quite cooperative and engaged, and was emphatically
nonsuicidal by the time of discharge. She had an intake
appointment with her new psychiatrist at ___
shortly after discharge, and will be discharged on sertraline
50 mg daily.
WORKING DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent major depressive disorder.

distal ileum with mild adjacent inflammation of the cecum. Small 
free fluid in the pelvis may be related or may be physiologic.  
Differential diagnosis includes infection and inflammatory bowel 
disease.   
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ old, otherwise healthy, woman who presents with 
abdominal pain, fever, and nonbloody diarrhea. Imaging studies 
showed terminal ileitis extending proximally along the distal 
ileum with mild adjacent inflammation of the cecum. She was 
started empirically on ciprofloxacin and flagyl and admitted for 
further care; unfortunately, stool studies were not obtained 
prior to the initiation of antibiotics. Labs were notable for 
mild pancytopenia with iron studies suggestive a mixed anemia of 
iron deficiency and inflammation. CRP was 93, ESR was ordered 
but not reported, CMV was negative, stool cultures obtained on 
the ___ are still pending at discharge. Labs from At___ are 
negative for hepatitis A, B, and C, HIV 1+2, syphilis, 
quatiferon TB gold, and H. pylori.

She was seen in consultation by Gastroenterology who felt that 
her presentation was most likely infectious, and that she should 
complete a 2-week course of antibiotics and follow-up with 
gastroenterology for elective colonoscopy with intubation of the 
terminal ileum for assessment of potential IBD or indolent 
infection.

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female who presents with abdominal
pain that began approximately 8 days.  The patient says last
___ she was awoken from sleep with vague abdominal pain,
nausea, and emesis nonbloody nonbilious.  She reports feeling
fevers, chills, lightheadedness at this time.  She also endorses
decreased PO intake at this time.  Her nausea and vague 
abdominal
pain continued and she also experienced diarrhea.  She denies
melena or bright red blood per rectum.  She was seen in urgent
care mid week and diagnosed with norovirus.  She began to feel
better until she got acutely worse yesterday morning.  She says
the pain progressed she was seen in urgent care and told to get 
a
CT scan, which was done and showed an 11 mm appendix.

Of note the patient is a ___ and has worked in a house with a
family that is sick with a GI bug, experiencing nausea vomiting
and diarrhea.

Here the patient is tender in the right lower quadrant, has a
white count to 17.4 and upon review of her CT abdomen pelvis
without oral contrast it appears that the patient's appendix is
dilated.

Review of systems: Positive as above, positive as in past 
medical
history, otherwise negative

 
Past Medical History:
IBS, antibiotics for small intestine bacterial overgrowth this 
summer, bicuspid aortic valve

___: CT Abdomen/Pelvis:
1. Lack of intra-abdominal fat and oral contrast makes 
assessment slightly 
suboptimal.  However, findings are concerning for appendicitis.  
Apparently blind-ending tubular structure in the right lower 
quadrant measures 11 mm in diameter and demonstrates wall edema, 
worrisome for appendicitis.  No drainable fluid collection seen. 
 If clinical picture does not correlate, consider repeat CT of 
the lower abdomen and pelvis following oral contrast 
administration/long prep. 
2. Left ovarian corpus luteum. 
3. Small amount of pelvic free fluid.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with pmh IBS, who presented 
to ___ with abdominal pain.  She was seen in urgent care and 
they recommended a CT scan which showed an 11 mm appendix. She 
was had a leukocytosis of 17.4.  She was admitted to the Acute 
Care Surgery team and was made NPO with IVF for hydration, and 
she was started on ciprofloxacin and metronidazole.  On HD2, her 
abdominal pain improved and she was hungry.  WBC decreased to 
5.9 and she was advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated.  
She was started on oral ciprofloxacin and metronidazole. 

The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; 
pain was managed without pain medication.  She remained stable 
from a cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint.  Patient's 
intake and output were closely monitored. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this 
stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.
 

 
Medications on Admission:
None prescribed, takes tumeric, D3, Echinacea, and
digestive enzyme
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H  
2.  MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg PO Q8H 
do NOT drink alcohol while taking this medication   
3.  Digestive Enzyme (acidoph,pec) (digestive 
8-L.acidoph-pectin) 50 million cell-100 mg oral DAILY:PRN  
4.  echinacea 125 mg oral DAILY:PRN  
5.  turmeric 400 mg oral DAILY  
6.  Vitamin D 4000 UNIT PO EVERY OTHER DAY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis 
(inflammation of the appendix).  You were treated 
non-operatively with antibiotics and you were initially 
restricted from eating to promote bowel rest.  Your abdominal 
pain improved and your white blood cell count (a marker of 
infection and inflammation) which was initially high at 
admission, returned to normal range.  You are now tolerating a 
regular diet and your pain has improved.  You will be discharged 
home on a course of oral antibiotics to treat any ongoing 
infection and to prevent recurrence.  

You are now ready to be discharged home to continue your 
recovery.  Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with pmh IBS, who presented
to ___ with abdominal pain. She was seen in urgent care and
they recommended a CT scan which showed an 11 mm appendix. She
was had a leukocytosis of 17.4. She was admitted to the Acute
Care Surgery team and was made NPO with IVF for hydration, and
she was started on ciprofloxacin and metronidazole. On HD2, her
abdominal pain improved and she was hungry. WBC decreased to
5.9 and she was advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated.
She was started on oral ciprofloxacin and metronidazole.
The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization;
pain was managed without pain medication. She remained stable
from a cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint. Patient's
intake and output were closely monitored. The patient received
subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this
stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as
possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
and hemodynamically stable. The patient was tolerating a diet,
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and
agreement with the discharge plan.
Medications on Admission:
None prescribed, takes tumeric, D3, Echinacea, and
digestive enzyme
Discharge Medications:
1. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H
2. MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg PO Q8H
do NOT drink alcohol while taking this medication
3. Digestive Enzyme (acidoph,pec) (digestive
8-L.acidoph-pectin) 50 million cell-100 mg oral DAILY:PRN
4. echinacea 125 mg oral DAILY:PRN
5. turmeric 400 mg oral DAILY
6. Vitamin D 4000 UNIT PO EVERY OTHER DAY
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis
(inflammation of the appendix). You were treated
non-operatively with antibiotics and you were initially
restricted from eating to promote bowel rest. Your abdominal
pain improved and your white blood cell count (a marker of
infection and inflammation) which was initially high at
admission, returned to normal range. You are now tolerating a
regular diet and your pain has improved. You will be discharged
home on a course of oral antibiotics to treat any ongoing
infection and to prevent recurrence.
You are now ready to be discharged home to continue your
recovery. Please note the following discharge instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea,
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern
you.
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have R ankle fx and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery 
service.  The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ 
for ORIF R ankle, which the patient tolerated well (for full 
details please see the separately dictated operative report). 
The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after recovery from anesthesia was transferred to 
the floor.  The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV 
pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral 
medications by POD#1. The patient was given perioperative 
antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine.  The patients home 
medications were continued throughout this hospitalization.  The 
patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to acute 
rehab was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was 
otherwise unremarkable.
 
At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable 
vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well 
controlled with oral medications, incisions were 
clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. The patient is non weight bearing in the right 
lower extremity.  The patient will follow up in two weeks per 
routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and 
all questions were answered prior to discharge.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN Constipation 
3. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO TID 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. Vitamin D 400 UNIT PO DAILY 
6. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q4hrs Disp #*80 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R ankle fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.
 
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks
 
WOUND CARE:
- No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet
 
ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
Please remain non weight bearing on your right leg in the short 
leg, split cast. 
Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Activity as tolerated
 Right lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
Encourage turn, cough and deep breathe q2h when awake

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Erythromycin Base / Percocet / Tylenol-Codeine #3 / Azithromycin 
/ Vicodin / Opioids-Morphine & Related / Prednisone / 
methylprednisolone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Menometrorrhagia, uterine fibroids
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total Laparascopic Hysterectomy, Bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, Cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a ___ yo P1 black F who has been on Ortho Evra patch 
for ___ years for medical management of menorrhagia symptoms as 
well as perimenopausal vasomotor symptoms. For the past ___ 
months, she has been experiencing heavy vaginal bleeding that 
lasts for several weeks at a time. She also reports
pelvic cramping during these bleeding episodes. She feels that 
the abnormal menstrual bleeding significantly interferes with 
her quality of life and ability to work. She has expressed 
desire to proceed with definitive surgical management with 
hysterectomy. She declines alternative therapies such as uterine 
fibroid embolization, Lupron, and other medical options.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH:
1) migraine headaches
2) neck pain
3) vertigo
4) GERD

PSH:
1) anterior cervical disctectomy and fusion, C5-6

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
mother with ovarian cancer and HTN; sister with ovarian cancer 
(Dx age ___

 
Physical Exam:
Physical Examination was performed by Dr. ___

___  146 lbs   BP  134/91   HR 102
General appearance: in NAD
Psych: alert and oriented x 3, mood and affect appropriate
Neck: No masses; no thyromegaly or nodules
Lymphatic: no palpable neck or groin lymphadenopathy
Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally, good inspiratory 
effort bilaterally, no wheezing
CV: RRR, no murmurs/rubs/gallops
Abd:  soft, non-tender, non-distended, no hepatosplenomegaly 
appreciated, no hernias; palpable fibroid uterus 2 cm below 
umbilicus
Extremities: no venous disease, no lesions, good perfusion, no 
edema
Skin: intact, no skin changes or lesions detected

Pelvic:
Normal external female genitalia
Urethral meatus normal in appearance
Bladder and urethra normal in appearance
Normal vaginal mucosa, no vaginal lesions
Cervix without abnormal discharge or lesions, midline
Bimanual: uterus enlarged, irregular contour, 18 cm in size; no
adnexal masses or tenderness appreciated; uterosacral ligaments
without nodularity or tenderness; no levator or obturator muscle 
tenderness
Rectovaginal: deferred

 
Pertinent Results:
Pelvic u/s from ___ showed:
Transabdominal and transvaginal scans of the pelvis were 
obtained. The vaginal scan was performed to better assess the 
endometrium and adnexa. The uterus is enlarged and heterogeneous 
with multiple masses consistent with fibroids. The overall 
___ of the uterus are 12.9 x 7.5 x 8.4 cm. The largest 
focal fibroid is intramural on the right measuring 4 cm in 
greatest dimension. The endometrium is distorted by the fibroids 
and where seen measures 6mm. Right ovary normal. Left ovary not 
seen.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted into the gynecology service for routine 
post-operative care following her surgery. She did very well. 
Her only complaint was for a headache of which she was given a 
prescription for excedrin. She was discharged on post-operative 
day 1 with adequate pain control, tolerating a regular diet and 
medications by mouth, voiding and ambulating without difficulty.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Demerol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every eight (8) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Excedrin Extra Strength 250-250-65 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet PO every six (6) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Uterine Fibroids

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Take your medications as prescribed
-- do not drive while taking narcotics
You may shower 24 hours after surgery
-- do not scrub incisions, let water run over incisions and pat 
dry
-- no tub baths/ hot tubs x 6 weeks
No heavy lifting or strenuous activity x 6 weeks (or until 
cleared by Dr. ___.  Otherwise, activity as tolerated.
Nothing in your vagina x 12 weeks ( no sex, no tampons)

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: The patient is a ___ year old woman with PMH of back pain,
HLD, depression/anxiety presenting with arm weakness.

Patient states that she was in her usual state of health until
this ___.  She said she woke up ___ and was having left
neck and shoulder pain.  She described this as feeling like she
might have had a pinched nerve.  She states that there is a
uncomfortable sharp pulling sensation in that area.  And also
states states that it felt like she had a really bad stiff neck.

EPIDURAL COLLECTION: None 
OTHER: Tiny focus of T2 hyperintensity at the odontoid, may be 
subchondral 
cystic changes due to mild degenerative disease. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ due to recent onset of L 
neck/shoulder pain progressing into proximal LUE weakness. On 
exam she was found to have weakness in her deltoids as well as 
infraspinatus concerning for involvement of cervical spine or 
brachial plexus. She underwent MRI C-Spine which did not show 
any remarkable pathology and pt was admitted to Neurology 
service for further management. Upon repeat evaluation at 
bedside pt continued to have similar weakness. There were no 
sensory or cranial nerve deficits. Reflexes were brisk but not 
pathologic (no Babinski, no ___, positive jaw-jerk). Her 
symptoms were thought to be most consistent with 
parsonage-turner syndrome. HbA1c was 5.4. Cervical spine and 
brachial plexus MRI were unremarkable. Less likely to be 
brachial-pharyngeal GBS. Lyme antibodies were sent. Will 
follow-up with ___ clinic and PCP. While inpatient, she was 
provided NSAIDs, Tylenol, and Tramadol for pain management. 

 
Medications on Admission:
lexapro 10 mg daily
MVI
atorvastatin 10 mg qhs
bupropion 150 mg daily
fexofenadine 180 mg daily
fluticasone 50 mg daily
gabapentin 400 mg BID
motrin PRN
ativan 0.5 mg BID
melatonin 3 mg qhs
methocarbamol 500 mg BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Moderate  
2.  Atorvastatin 10 mg PO QPM  
3.  BuPROPion XL (Once Daily) 150 mg PO DAILY  
4.  Escitalopram Oxalate 10 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Fexofenadine 60 mg PO BID  
6.  Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU DAILY  
7.  Gabapentin 400 mg PO BID  
8.  LORazepam 0.5 mg PO BID:PRN anxiety  
9.  Methocarbamol 500 mg PO BID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Parsonage Turner syndrome

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  
 
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of arm pain and weakness 
concerning for a neurologic condition. You were evaluated at 
bedside by the Neurology service and underwent laboratory workup 
and MRI imaging to investigate for an underlying cause to your 
symptoms. The MRI evaluating the nerves in your neck look 
normal.
 
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician.  

 
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  
 
Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Depression

Pertinent Results:
___ 06:35AM BLOOD WBC-7.4 RBC-2.75*# Hgb-9.7* Hct-27.4* 
MCV-100* MCH-35.3* MCHC-35.4* RDW-14.8 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the service of Dr. ___ for a 
laminectomy and cyst removal.  He was informed and consented and 
elected to proceed.  Please see Operative Note for procedure in 
detail.  
Post-operatively he was given antibiotics and pain medication.  
A hemovac drain was placed intra-operatively and this was 
removed POD 2.  His bladder catheter was removed POD 3 and his 
diet was advanced without difficulty.  He was able to work with 
physical therapy for strength and balance.  He was discharged in 
good condition and will follow up in the Orthopaedic Spine 
clinic.

 
Medications on Admission:
fluoxetine
percocet
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Oxycodone 20 mg Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr PO Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*60 Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
6. Diphenhydramine HCl 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H 
(every 6 hours) as needed.  
7. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Chewable PO QID (4 times a day) as needed.  
8. Simethicone 80 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Chewable PO TID (3 times a day) as needed for gas.  
9. Diazepam 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar intradural hematoma/cyst

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please continue to take your pain medication with an over the 
counter laxative.  Call the clinic should you experience any 
redness, swelling or discharge at the incision site.  Call the 
clinic if you experience a temperature greater than 101 degrees. 
 
Do not smoke.  Do not lifting anything greater than a gallon of 
milk.
Call the clinic for any additional concerns.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

feeling dizzy, then blacking out. However, per police report 
from
video surveillance, the patient appeared to have been throwing
himself against hard objects in the holding cell and appeared to
be self-inflicting injury. He reported jaw pain and inability to
open or close mouth. He also does report some posterior right
sided neck pain. He was initially taken to an outside hospital
where CT head/C-spine were negative, but CT max/face was concern
for mandibular fracture. He was therefore transferred to ___
for further ___ eval. ___ evaluated patient in ED and
determined would likely need admission for operative fixation.

MANDIBLE SERIES INCLUD PANOREXStudy Date of ___ 10:41 ___
IMPRESSION: 
 
Nondisplaced mandibular fracture and comminuted left mandibular 
condyle
fracture are better appreciated on outside hospital 
maxillofacial CT from ___.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was admitted to the hospital after sustaining trauma 
to the jaw on ___. CT scan of her mandible showed that he had 
sustained bilateral mandibular Fx, ___ service was consulted 
who performed a closed reduction of bilateral mandible fractures 
on ___. He did well after surgery and came to the floor after 
an uneventful stay in the PACU. 

On POD1 he was tolerating a FLD, on oral pain meds, passing gas 
and in no excessive pain. A tertiary survey was performed which 
revealed no additional injuries. 

Psych service was consulted due to the reports that the 
patient's injuries were self inflicted to probe any self harm 
tendencies and address them prior to discharge. Psychiatry 
service cleared the patient for discharge. 

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a IV narcotic 
and then transitioned to oral oxycodone once tolerating a diet. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
GI/GU/FEN: Patient's intake and output were closely monitored. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ 
dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
Medications: none
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen (Liquid) 650 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Mild 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Patient is NPO or unable to 
tolerate PO 
2.  Chlorhexidine Gluconate 0.12% Oral Rinse 15 mL ORAL BID 
Duration: 14 Days 
RX *chlorhexidine gluconate 0.12 % 15 ml twice a day Refills:*0 
3.  OxycoDONE Liquid 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg/5 mL 5 ml by mouth every six (6) hours 
Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Mandibular Fx

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent closed reduction ___ mandibular fx. You are recovering 
well and are now ready for discharge. Please follow the 
instructions below to continue your recovery:

- Full liquid diet x2 weeks, until follow-up appointment. Diet
restrictions will be re-evaluated at follow-up 
- Maintain good oral hygiene. Brush teeth BID. Discharge with
Chlorhexidine Oral Rinse BID x 14 days. 
- Discharge with wirecutters to be used only in emergency
- If you feel your wires come loose, and he is able to open
his mouth at all, he should call our clinic to make an
appointment to come in sooner than his scheduled follow-up 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. 
Upon admission, he was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, and 
underwent imaging. Cat scan imaging showed a distal small bowel 
obstruction with bowel wall thickening.  The patient underwent 
serial abdominal examinations. His white blood cell count was 
monitored.  Because of the cat scan findings, the GI service was 
consulted and recommended a MRE which showed wall edema with 
enhancement of mid ileal bowel loops without evidence of 
obstruction. Stool cultures were reported as normal. 

The patient's abdominal pain resolved with bowel rest.  He 
resumed a regular diet without recurrence of discomfort.  His 
vital signs were stable and he was afebrile. His white blood 
cell count normalized.  He was ambulatory and voiding without 
difficulty. 

An appointment for a repeat MRE was made for 6 weeks per 
recommendations of the GI service.  The patient reported that he 
would be returning to ___ in 3 weeks and will not be returning 
here.  The MRE was cancelled. If a cancellation becomes 
available, the GI service will see the patient prior to his 
departure to ___ and provide recommendations for care.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with lower abdominal pain.  
You underwent a cat scan of the abdomen and you were noted to 
have small bowel obstruction with thickened bowel walls.  You 
were evaluated by the GI service who recommended additional 
testing which showed swelling of the bowel walls, but no 
obstruction.  Your pain has resolved and you have been 
tolerating a regular diet.  You are preparing for discharge.  A 
repeat MRE/ colonoscopy was recommended.  You should try to 
schedule it with your primary care once you return to ___.  
Please do not hesitate to call us or return to the emergency 
room if you have recurrence of your abdominal pain.  You are 
being discharged with the following instructions:  

You have a recurrence of abdominal pain.

You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

underwent imaging. Cat scan imaging showed a distal small bowel
obstruction with bowel wall thickening. The patient underwent
serial abdominal examinations. His white blood cell count was
monitored. Because of the cat scan findings, the GI service was
consulted and recommended a MRE which showed wall edema with
enhancement of mid ileal bowel loops without evidence of
obstruction. Stool cultures were reported as normal.
The patient's abdominal pain resolved with bowel rest. He
resumed a regular diet without recurrence of discomfort. His
vital signs were stable and he was afebrile. His white blood
cell count normalized. He was ambulatory and voiding without
difficulty.

would be returning to ___ in 3 weeks and will not be returning

departure to ___ and provide recommendations for care.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Prostate cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy - ___ - Dr. 
___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a very pleasant ___ gentleman who noted any 
increased PSA to 6.2. Dr. ___ a biopsy, which 
unfortunately revealed ___ 7 prostate cancer in the left 
apex two cores up to 25% and two cores ___ 6 in the left 
mid section up to 66%. The cores on the right were negative.  He 
also complains of some weak stream, hesitancy, feelings of 
incomplete emptying and that he has to sit to void. His AUA 
symptom score is ___. He has what he considers severe erectile 
dysfunction and his sexual health inventory for men score 
corroborates this with a score ___. He denies any recent weight 
loss, back pain, or new bone pain. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH:  
1. CAD s/p MI and cardiac stents in ___  
2. LLE DVT and PE in ___  
3. DM II, recently diagnosed  
---
PSH:  
1. Vein stripping  
2. Basal cell carcinoma removal ___ 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
prostate cancer in his father who underwent brachytherapy by Dr. 
___ in ___. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted to Urology after undergoing laparoscopic radical 
prostatectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; 
please see dictated operative note for details. He received 
ancef for perioperative prophylaxis. He was transferred to the 
floor from the PACU in stable condition.  On POD0, his pain was 
well controlled on PCA and toradol, hydrated for urine output 
>30cc/hour, provided with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry 
for prophylaxis, and ambulated once. On POD1, he was restarted 
on his home medications, basic metabolic panel and complete 
blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned from PCA 
to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a regular diet with 
start of colace. JP removed POD1 without difficulty. The 
remainder of the hospital course was relatively unremarkable. He 
was discharged in stable condition on POD1, ambulating 
independently, eating well, and with pain control on oral 
analgesics. On exam, his incision was clean, dry, and intact, 
with no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. He was 
given explicit instructions to ___ in clinic with Dr. 
___ in 1 week, and that the urethral catheter (foley) would 
be removed during the ___ appointment.  He was instructed 
to start 3 day course of Ciprofloxacin on day prior to Foley 
removal.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Carvedilol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): 
continue  your home dose.  
2. Losartan 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Vytorin ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO daily 
().  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4-6H () as needed for breakthrough pain only(score>4): for 
breakthrough pain only.  Primary pain med should be ibuprofen.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day): to prevent constipation while taking percocet.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Bacitracin 500 unit/g Ointment Sig: One (1) Appl Topical TID 
(3 times a day): to penile meatus while foley in place.
Disp:*1 tube* Refills:*2*
4. Carvedilol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): 
continue  your home dose.  
5. Losartan 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Vytorin ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO daily 
().  
7. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for pain: take as firstline pain med.  Percocet 
for backup.
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 3 days: start the day before catheter removal and finish 
all six pills.
Disp:*6 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Prostate cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may take motrin and narcotic together for pain control. Use 
tylenol and motrin first, replace tylenol with narcotic for 
backup.

-You may shower 2 days after surgery, but do not tub bathe, 
swim, soak, or scrub incision for 2 weeks. 

-Allow bandage strips to fall off over time, remove all 
remaining dressings in 2 days

-No heavy lifting for 4 weeks (no more than 10 pounds)

-___ medical attention for fevers (temp>101.5), worsening pain, 
drainage or excessive bleeding from incision, chest pain or 
shortness of breath.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check/foley removal

-Please do not drive or consume alcohol while taking pain 
medications.

-Take first dose of Ciprofloxacin 1 day prior to foley catheter 
removal and for subsequent 2 days.

- Wear Large foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

PF4 Heparin Antibody         0.17                 0.00 - 0.39    
     OD

___ EGD:
Impression: Thickening and congestion of gastric folds in the 
cardia and proximal body stomach body
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum 

___ EUS:
Impression: EUS was performed using a linear echoendoscope at 
___ MHz frequency: The head and uncinate pancreas were imaged 
from the duodenal bulb and the second / third duodenum. The body 
and tail [partially] were imaged from the gastric body and 
fundus. .
Pancreas parenchyma: The parenchyma in the uncinate, head and 
body of the pancreas was homogenous, with a normal salt and 
pepper appearance. No changes of chr pancreatitis were noted. 
The parenchyma in the tail of the pancreas was obscured by the 
cystic mass.
Pancreas duct: The pancreas duct measured 3 mm in maximum 
diameter in the head of the pancreas and 1.7 mm in maximum 
diameter in the body of the pancreas. The duct was normal in 
echotexture and contour. The duct was not seen in the tail of 
the pancreas.
In the region of the body of the pancreas there was > 3 cm 
ill-defined hypoechoic area. Several areas of air were noted 
within this structure - this caused artifact / shadowing and 
therefore this was very poorly imaged with EUS. The gastric wall 
in this area was markedly expanded. No discrete mass or cyst was 
noted.
Small varices were noted in the gastric cardia
Otherwise normal upper eus to third part of the duodenum 

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient with history of necrotizing pancreatitis s/p cyst 
jejunostomy was transferred from OSH and admitted to the General 
Surgical Service. The OSH CT scan was concerning for perigastric 
fluid collection and Gastroenterology was consulted for EGD/EUS. 
On admission patient was afebrile with slightly elevated WBCs. 
Patient's WBC returned within normal limit on HD 2 without any 
intervention. He was noticed to have thrombocytopenia and HIT 
panel was checked and returned back negative. On HD 3 patient 
underwent EGD and EUS. EGD revealed thickening and congestion of 
gastric folds in the cardia and proximal body stomach body. EUS 
revealed pancreatic body cyst, normal pancreatic ducts, no 
significant fluid collection (please see Radiology report for 
details). Post procedure patient's diet was advanced to clears 
and was well tolerated. On HD 4, diet was advanced to regular, 
patient remained afebrile with WBC within normal, pain free. 
Patient was discharged home in stable condition. 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

 

 
Medications on Admission:
Atorvastatin 10mg QD
Omeprazole 40mg QD
Tramadol 50-100mg prn QD
Trazodone 50mg qhs

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN mild pain 
do not exceed more then 3000 mg/day 
2. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 
3. TraMADol 50-100 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
4. TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Abdominal pain
2. Possible pancreatic cyst 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the surgery service at ___ for evaluation 
of new onset abdominal pain. CT scan revealed fluid collection 
in the lesser sac. EGD with EUS revealed pancreatic body 
pseudocyst. You pain is improved, you remained afebrile with 
normal WBC. You were discharged home, you scheduled for follow 
up with Dr. ___ on ***
.
Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ if you have any 
questions or concerns. 
.
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you experience 
the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
*Please resume all regular home medications , unless 
specifically advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, 
please take any new medications as prescribed.
*Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___
