text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
ITP
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - laparoscopic splenectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman with a history of low platelet count initially 
noted in ___.  She then had more symptoms and began treatment 
in ___.  Since then, she has received prednisone, rituximab 
without a great improvement.  She currently is on WinRho every 
three to five weeks to keep her platelet count elevated.  She 
has had some bruising of her lower extremities when her platelet 
count was under 20,000.  She has had no significant bleeds.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: ITP

PSH: C-sections x2, IUD placement
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Notable for brother with ITP, father with hypertension and 
mother with metastatic breast cancer.
 
Physical Exam:
Discharge day exam:
98.5  97.3  65  ___  98RA
Gen NAD
CV RRR
Chest CTAB
Abd S/NT/ND, incisions C/D/I
Ext WWP
 
Pertinent Results:
Postop Platelet count (___): 122 (from 55 pre-op).
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted on ___ following her uncomplicated 
laparoscopic splenectomy.  Postoperatively her diet was advanced 
from clear liquids to solid foods however she did have some 
nausea on POD #1 which was likely related to narcotic pain 
medication on an empty stomach.  She received zofran and reglan 
for nausea with good effect.  She ambulated without difficutly 
and was able to urinate without difficutly.  She was discharged 
to home on POD #2 in good condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Multivitamin 1 tablet PO daily.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): Use while taking dilaudid to prevent constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Acetaminophen Extra Strength 500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets 
PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for headache: OVER THE COUNTER 
TYLENOL: Use as needed for pain to help reduce the need for 
dilaudid.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
ITP

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ or return to the ED if you 
experience fevers, chills, nausea/vomiting, increasing abdominal 
pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, yellowing of your skin, 
or increasing redness or foul-smelling drainage from incisions.

You may remove outer dressings from your incision sites on 
___.  Inner dressings (Steri-Strip surgical tape) will fall 
off on their own.

You may shower.  Please refrain from tub baths or swimming until 
your follow-up appointment.

No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until cleared by Dr. 
___.  Walking and light cardiovascular exercise 
is encouraged.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted on ___ from an outside hospital with CT 
evidence of portal vein thrombosis. A CT scan done here at ___ 
confirmed this finding. Pt was placed on a heparin drip which 
was titrated until therapeutic at a PTT between 50-70. PTT's 
were obtained every 6 hours while on the heparin drip to ensure 
therapeutic effect. Pt was initially monitored for liver damage 
with daily LFT's which were initially slightly elevated but 
returned to within normal range. Pt had some right sided 
abdominal pain on admission which resolved. She was ambulatory, 
tolerating a regular diet and had no evidence of respiratory 
compromise or hemodynamic instability while in the hospital. She 
was discharged home with instructions to have lovenox therapy 
while being bridged to coumadin. She will have her INR checked 
until it is between ___. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Multivitamin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Lovenox ___ mg/mL Syringe Sig: One Hundred (100) mg 
Subcutaneous once a day for 7 days.
Disp:*7 ml* Refills:*0*
2. Multivitamin
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
___ Diagnosis:
Portal Vein Thrombosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You will have daily Lovenox injections until you have been 
transitioned to coumadin daily. You will have your INR checked 
with a lab test daily until it is within therapeutic range of 
___.

Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.

General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous 
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 10 
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct 
you further regarding activity restrictions.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted on ___ from an outside hospital with CT
evidence of portal vein thrombosis. A CT scan done here at ___
confirmed this finding. Pt was placed on a heparin drip which
was titrated until therapeutic at a PTT between 50-70. PTT's
were obtained every 6 hours while on the heparin drip to ensure
therapeutic effect. Pt was initially monitored for liver damage
with daily LFT's which were initially slightly elevated but
returned to within normal range. Pt had some right sided
abdominal pain on admission which resolved. She was ambulatory,
tolerating a regular diet and had no evidence of respiratory
compromise or hemodynamic instability while in the hospital. She
was discharged home with instructions to have lovenox therapy
while being bridged to coumadin. She will have her INR checked
until it is between ___.
Medications on Admission:
Multivitamin
Discharge Medications:
1. Lovenox ___ mg/mL Syringe Sig: One Hundred (100) mg
Subcutaneous once a day for 7 days.
Disp:*7 ml* Refills:*0*
2. Multivitamin
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___
___ Diagnosis:
Portal Vein Thrombosis
Discharge Condition:
Stable.
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Discharge Instructions:
You will have daily Lovenox injections until you have been
transitioned to coumadin daily. You will have your INR checked
with a lab test daily until it is within therapeutic range of
___.
Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea,
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.
General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Please take any
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed. You
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic
medications. You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid strenuous
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 10
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct
you further regarding activity restrictions. Please also
follow-up with your primary care physician.
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R frontal SAH
L4 compression fx
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo Right handed man who presents with a
small traumatic R frontal SAH. 

The patient states having been in his USOH until Thurday morning
(___). At that time he was putting his pants on and lost his
balance, falling backwards. He believes that he hit his head in
the occipital area and also struck his right side. He had no LOC
and did not even have a headache afterwards. 

He started having right hip/back pain after the fall which
prompted him to take ___ and ___ off. He came to the ED
today because of increasing hip pain. Again he had no HA and
still does not. 

Of note, he is maintained on warfarin for Afib and his current
INR is 1.6.

 
Past Medical History:
1. pAF
2. HLD
3. DM
4. HTN

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C

 
Physical Exam:
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
Neck: Supple.
Lungs: CTA bilaterally.
Cardiac: RRR. S1/S2.
Abd: Soft, NT, BS+
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal
affect.
Orientation: Oriented to person, place, and date.
Recall: ___ objects at 5 minutes.
Language: Speech fluent with good comprehension and repetition.
Naming intact. No dysarthria or paraphasic errors.

Cranial Nerves:
I: Not tested
II: Pupils equally round and reactive to light, 3 to 2 mm
bilaterally. Visual fields are full to confrontation.
III, IV, VI: Extraocular movements intact bilaterally without
nystagmus.
V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric.
VIII: Hearing intact to voice.
IX, X: Palatal elevation symmetrical.
XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius normal bilaterally.
XII: Tongue midline without fasciculations.

Motor: Normal bulk and tone bilaterally. No abnormal movements,
tremors. Strength full power ___ throughout. No pronator drift

Reflexes: B T Br Pa Ac
Right     ___   1  1
Left      ___   1  1
Toes downgoing bilaterally

Coordination: normal on finger-nose-finger

___ 10:20PM BLOOD WBC-7.7# RBC-4.38* Hgb-13.1* Hct-38.9* 
MCV-89 MCH-29.8 MCHC-33.6 RDW-14.0 Plt ___
___ 10:20PM BLOOD Neuts-81.3* Lymphs-11.1* Monos-6.4 
Eos-0.8 Baso-0.4
___ 06:52AM BLOOD ___

K-4.6 Cl-102 HCO3-26 AnGap-15

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST
HISTORY:  ___ male status post fall while taking 
Coumadin, question 
intracranial hemorrhage. 
  
COMPARISON:  None. 
  
TECHNIQUE:  Axial CT images were acquired of the head without 
contrast and 
reformatted into coronal and sagittal planes. 
  
FINDINGS:  There is a small focus of right frontal subarachnoid 
hemorrhage 
layering within a right frontal sulcus.  No hemorrhage is seen 
elsewhere.  
Elsewhere, gray matter/white matter differentiation is 
preserved.  Ventricles 
and sulci are mildly prominent, consistent with age-appropriate 
atrophy.  
Periventricular white matter hypodensity is likely the result of 
chronic small 
vessel ischemic change.  There is no fracture of the calvaria.  
The visualized 
paranasal sinuses are clear.  The mastoid air cells are clear.  
A small amount 
of scalp hematoma is seen overlying the occiput. 
  
IMPRESSION:  Small focus of acute right frontal subarachnoid 
hemorrhage.  
These findings were discussed with Dr. ___ by phone at 11:55 
p.m.  A wet 
read was posted upon discovery of the findings at 11:08 p.m. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Neurologic Surgery Service for 
management of a subarachnoid hemorrhage and vertebral 
compression fracture. The patient was followed both clinically 
and radiographically and found to be stable. The patient was 
able to tolerate a diet and pain was controlled with PO pain 
meds.  The patient was discharged in stable condition with 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care.  All questions were answered 
prior to discharge and the patient expressed readiness for 
discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
Medications - Prescription
FUROSEMIDE -  (Prescribed by Other Provider) - furosemide 20 mg
tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
HYDROCORTISONE - hydrocortisone 2.5 % Topical Cream
apply to skin twice a day as needed for rash
INSULIN ASPART [NOVOLOG] - Novolog 100 unit/mL Sub-Q
inject ___ units pre meal
INSULIN GLARGINE [LANTUS] - Lantus 100 unit/mL Sub-Q
45 units subqutaneously once daily or as directed
LISINOPRIL - lisinopril 5 mg tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day at night
METFORMIN - metformin 1,000 mg tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day
POTASSIUM CHLORIDE -  (Prescribed by Other Provider) - potassium
chloride ER 10 mEq capsule,extended release
2 Capsule(s) by mouth once a day
ROSUVASTATIN [CRESTOR] - Crestor 10 mg tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
VARDENAFIL [LEVITRA] - Levitra 20 mg tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day as needed for prn
WARFARIN - warfarin 10 mg tablet
1 Tablet(s) by mouth qd as directed
 
Medications - OTC
ASPIRIN -  (Prescribed by Other Provider; ___) - aspirin 81 mg
tablet,delayed release
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
CHOLECALCIFEROL (VITAMIN D3) [VITAMIN D3] -  (Prescribed by 
Other
Provider) - Vitamin D3 1,000 unit capsule
1 Capsule(s) by mouth once a day
INSULIN SYRINGE-NEEDLE U-100 [BD INSULIN SYRINGE] - BD Insulin
Syringe 1 mL 28 x ___
use three times a day

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
4. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO BID 
5. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO DAILY 
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
 right frontal subarachnoid hemorrhage
 L4 compression fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
 Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
 Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
 Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
 You were on Coumadin (Warfarin) and Aspirin prior to your 
injury and you may safely resume taking this in 4 days. You 
should follow-up with your PCP or cardiologist who prescribes 
these medications for you to further discuss this.
 You are being discharged with a brace which you should wear at 
all times when you are out of bed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

3. Left chest tube placement

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ who presented after an MVC with abdominal pain and 
difficulty breathing. After a trauma eval, she was found to have 
multiple splenic lacs, a RML Pulmonary contusion, R basilar 
atelectasis/aspiration, R rib fx ___.   

 
Past Medical History:

PSH: abdominoplasty

non contrib

97.9, 84, 144/82, 20, 97% on NRB
anxious

neck: in C collar
Chest:R chest ttp, no crepitus, CTA B
CV:RRR
Abd: s/ND,RUQ ttp
Ext: moves all ext spontaneously

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:26PM   WBC-11.2* RBC-3.31* HGB-10.7* HCT-30.8* 
MCV-93 MCH-32.2* MCHC-34.6 RDW-17.1*
___ 11:20PM   WBC-7.8 RBC-3.94* HGB-12.7 HCT-38.6 MCV-98 
MCH-32.4* MCHC-33.0 RDW-14.5
___ 11:20PM   WBC-7.8 RBC-3.94* HGB-12.7 HCT-38.6 MCV-98 
MCH-32.4* MCHC-33.0 RDW-14.5
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted to the trauma sicu for close observation. She 
was on a non-rebreather mask to maintain O2 sats. Her CT scan 
showed splenic lacerations, and was monitored closely with 
serial hcts and abdominal exams. She was typed and crossed in 
case clinical evidence of intra-abdominal hemorrhage was 
suspected. The following day, she was underwent angio and 
successful coil embolization of a proximal splenic 
pseudoaneurysm to stasis. She tolerated the procedure well. He 
pain continued to be controlled on a fentanyl PCA. On ___, 
she was transfused 2 units for a hct of 20.7, and her blood 
counts responded appropriately. She was soon found to have a 
pneumothorax on serial imaging and a left sided chest tube was 
placed. She was put on bed rest over the ensuing days and after 
two trials of putting her chest tube to water seal with a new 
ptx, a thoracics consult was obtained. On ___, she was deemed 
stable enough for transfer to the floor. The next day, she was 
tolerating regular diet and was ambulating essential distances. 
___ worked with her and cleared her for home. Her CT was d/c'd on 
___, and her repeat CXRs were stable. On ___, she was 
deemed ready for discharge on adequate pain control.

 
Medications on Admission:
thyroid replacment 90
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
2. Thyroid 30 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Dapsone 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) as 
needed for dermatitis.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H:PRN: Please do not drive on this medication.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.  
6. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
7. Tramadol 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours).
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Splenic lacerations
R pneumothorax
RML Pulmonary contusion
R basilar atelectasis/aspiration
R rib fx ___

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please follow-up as instructed with either Dr. ___ your PCP 
depending on whether or not you will be in town. Please report 
any new fevers >101, new shortness of breath, or any difficulty 
breathing. Also report any new abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, 
or light-headedness. You have a small incision where your chest 
tube was, please monitor this daily for any new redness, 
purulent drainage, or increasing pain. 

Do not drive on narcotic pain medication.

text:
Name:  ___       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
presyncope
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PMHx of endometriosis but otherwise healthy who 
presents with a presyncopal episode and intermittent chest 
pressure & heaviness with breathing. She reports that she's had 
nasal congestion for the past 2 weeks and has been taking Afrin 
Severe Congestion with good effect. Denies any fevers, chills, 
cough, sore throat, or pleuritic chest pain, but notes that for 
the past 2 days, she's had intermittent chest 
discomfort/pressure and a sensation of heaviness when she tries 
to breathe. Not associated with shortness of breath or 
diaphoresis. Reports sensation like a pulled muscle which she 
feels in lower ribs and upper back. Also has had intermittent 
waves of nausea (but no vomiting), fatigue, and weakness. Today 
she was standing in the kitchen after dinner and had a 
presyncopal episode which she describes as a sensation of 
feeling heavy and "like she was weighted down". Denies any 
nausea or diaphoresis at the time, and states that she felt 
cold. Drank 4 cups of water because she thought she might be 
dehydrated. Reports that she's had vertigo in the past, and that 
this felt different, which concerned her, so she presented to 
the ED.  
 
In the ED, initial VS were 97.6 83 140/94 16 100% RA. Labs were 
significant for troponin was 0.04. CXR showed no acute process. 
Her PERC was negative. Patient was given aspirin 325mg. She was 
admitted for further evaluation. Vital signs on transfer were 
98.5 77 129/88 15 99%RA.  
On arrival to the floor, patient is laying in bed comfortably 
and states that she feels well.  

 
Past Medical History:
endometriosis
appy ___ yrs ago)
diagnostic laparascopy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
no IBD, no CA
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS: 98.6, 145/85, 84, 18, 99%RA  
GEN: A+Ox3, NAD  
HEENT: NCAT. EOMI. PERRL. MMM. no LAD. no JVD. neck supple.  
CV: RRR, normal S1/S2, no murmurs, rubs or gallops. no friction 
rub appreciated.  
LUNG: CTAB, no wheezes, rales or rhonchi  
ABD: soft, mild LLQ tenderness to moderate palpation, 
non-distended, hypoactive BS. no rebound or guarding. neg HSM.  
EXT: W/WP, no edema, no C/C. 2+ ___ pulses bilaterally.  
SKIN: W/D/I  
NEURO: CNs II-XII intact. ___ strength in U/L extremities. 
sensation intact to LT.  
PSYCH: appropriate affect  

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS: 98.6, 145/85, 84, 18, 99% RA
Orthostatics: sitting 132/88, 76; standing 128/82, 72
GEN: A&Ox3, NAD, pleasant, cooperative, appropriate
HEENT: NCAT, MMM, no JVD
CV: RRR, S1/S2, no m/r/g, no friction rub appreciated
LUNG: CTAB, no w/r/r
ABD: soft, NT/ND, hypoactive BS, no rebound or guarding. neg 
HSM.
EXT: WWP, 1+ edema up to bilateral ankles, no clubbing or 
cyanosis, 2+ ___ pulses b/l
NEURO: CNs II-XII intact, ___ strength symmetric in BLE/BUE, 
sensation intact to light touch

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:15PM BLOOD WBC-7.3 RBC-3.91* Hgb-12.6 Hct-38.2 
MCV-98 MCH-32.4* MCHC-33.1 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 07:25AM BLOOD WBC-6.0 RBC-3.59* Hgb-11.6* Hct-34.7* 
MCV-97 MCH-32.3* MCHC-33.5 RDW-12.6 Plt ___

___ 08:15PM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-13 Creat-0.6 Na-134 
K-3.8 Cl-97 HCO3-22 AnGap-19
___ 07:25AM BLOOD Glucose-87 UreaN-7 Creat-0.6 Na-139 
K-3.1* Cl-101 HCO3-27 AnGap-14

___ 08:15PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.04*
___ 07:25AM BLOOD CK-MB-2 cTropnT-0.04*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
# Presyncopal episode: presyncopal episode while standing after 
dinner in the setting of nasal congestion x 2 weeks.  While 
intermittently feeling lightheaded, never felt the sensation of 
being "weighed down" previously. Likely related to standing in 
hot kitchen baking in the setting of fatigue and ongoing viral 
illness, as well as taking HCTZ 50mg each of the last two days. 
Troponins stable at 0.04 twice 12 hours apart.  HCTZ dosing was 
decreased from 50mg to 25mg daily.

# Chest pain: intermittent chest discomfort/pressure and 
weightiness without associated shortness of breath or 
diaphoresis. Also reports sensation like a pulled muscle which 
she feels in lower ribs and upper back. ACS seems unlikely given 
clinical history, although patient did receive an aspirin 325mg 
in the ED. It is possible that patient could have a post-viral 
pericarditis leading to her positive troponin. Of note, ECG did 
not show PR depressions. Troponins stable at 0.04 twice 12 hours 
apart.

# Nasal congestion: states she often gets viral URI in ___. 
Asked patient to discontinue Afrin since she may be having 
rebound congestion after taking it for more than 3 days.  Asked 
her to consider flonase and/or nasal saline for symptomatic 
relief as needed.

# BLE edema: Stable, decreased HCTZ from 50mg to 25mg daily.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
- pt will call PCP for close ___ of viral illness and HCTZ 
dosing (decreased from 50mg to 25mg daily)
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Hydrochlorothiazide 50 mg PO DAILY 
2. Guaifenesin ___ mL PO Q6H:PRN congestion

Disp #*1 Bottle Refills:*0

Home

presyncope

 
Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a pleasure participating in your care at ___.  You were 
admitted for an episode of almost fainting, lightheadedness, and 
chest pressure.  Your EKG, chest X-ray, and blood work were 
reassuring.  

Please take a decreased dose of your hydrochlorothiazide from 
50mg to 25mg daily as needed for your leg swelling.

Please stop taking Afrin since it may cause your congestion to

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R hip wound inflammation and drainage
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Irrigation and debridement, ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ 2 weeks s/p right hip ___ with labral repair
by Dr. ___ with 1 day of chills and drainage from surgical
site. Yesterday she had chills. Today she noticed increasing
swelling at the groin incision. After removing the steristrips
she was able to express pus from the wound. She called the
surgeons office who had her come in to be seen. From there she
was sent to the ED. Dr. ___ is out of town and Dr. ___ 
is
aware of this patient. 
She has been on aspirin and been TDWB postop. 

 
Past Medical History:
DDH, right hip ___, breast biopsy, wisdom teeth
extraction
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
Well appearing in no acute distress  
Afebrile with stable vital signs  
Pain well-controlled  
Respiratory: CTAB  
Cardiovascular: RRR  
Gastrointestinal: NT/ND  
Genitourinary: Voiding independently  
Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits  
Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3  
Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity:  
* Incision healing well with staples
* Thigh full but soft  
* No calf tenderness  
* ___ strength  
* SILT, NVI distally  
* Toes warm

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for irrigation 
and debridement of her R hip surgical site infection, which the 
patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please 
see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was 
taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after 
satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the 
floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain 
medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral 
medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ 
anticoagulation per routine. Her hemovac drain was removed on 
POD1 as there was negligible output. Intra-operative cultures 
grew out methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. After 
consultation with the Infectious Disease service, the patient 
was discharged on PO Keflex ___ q6h for 2 weeks for 
antibiosis. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to home was appropriate. The ___ 
hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
___ PWB in the right lower extremity, and will be discharged on 
ASA 81mg qd for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with 
Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the 
patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge 
course including reasons to call the office or return to the 
hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also 
given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions 
and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed 
readiness for discharge.
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) 
hours Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 81 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*28 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
3.  Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN Constipation  
4.  Cephalexin 500 mg PO Q6H Duration: 2 Weeks 
RX *cephalexin 500 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*56 Capsule Refills:*0 
5.  Naproxen 500 mg PO Q12H 
RX *naproxen [Naprosyn] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every twelve 
(12) hours Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0 
6.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp 
#*10 Tablet Refills:*0 
7.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Superficial wound infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- ___ PWB RLE with slight anterior hip precautions

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take ASA 81mg daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Cat bite to left hand, ring finger

Incision and drainage of left ring finger

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ right-handed office worker who 
presents following a cat bite to her left hand yesterday around 
___.  She was trying to keep her cat from fighting with a dog 
and the cat bit her hand several times.  She washed the wounds 
thoroughly, but noticed worsening swelling throughout the ___ 
and went to ___ where she received Unasyn and was 
transferred for hand surgery evaluation.  She complains of pain 
and swelling in her left index finger and over the left ring MCP 
joint.

 
Past Medical History:
ACL repair

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T 98.6, HR 72, BP 126/67, RR 16, Sat 100% RA
General: Awake, alert, left hand elevated
Focused LUE exam: There is moderate erythema and swelling of the 
left index finger from the DIP to the MCP joint.  There are 
several small, scabbed wounds, one on the dorsal index finger 
distal to the PIP, one over the dorsal long MCP, and one on the 
volar ring MCP.  The index finger is diffusely tender, but there 
is no tenderness over the tendon sheath proximal to the MCP.  
She has some pain with extension, but more pain with flexion.  
There is good capillary refill and sensation to light touch is 
intact in all digits.  There is no erythema tracking up the arm.

 
Pertinent Results:

.

.

LEUKOCYTES. 
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN.

   ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Preliminary): 
.
___ 3:00 pm SWAB      VOLAR LEFT INDEX FINGER. 

   GRAM STAIN (Final ___: 
      1+    (<1 per 1000X FIELD):   POLYMORPHONUCLEAR 
LEUKOCYTES. 
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN. 

   WOUND CULTURE (Preliminary): 

   ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Preliminary): 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ for observation and treatment of a left hand ring 
finger cat bite.  The patient was brought to the OR on ___ 
for incision and drainage of the cat bite wound and tolerated 
the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Morphine IV with 
some effect and adequate pain control initially. Toward the 
morning of POD#1, the patient complained of finger 'burning' and 
of feeling 'fuzzy' on the morphine.  The morphine was 
discontinued and patient was offered oxycodone which she 
refused.  She was given Toradol IV and tylenol PO with good pain 
relief noted.  
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
.
ID: Upon admission to ___, the patient was started on IV 
Unasyn, then switched to augmentin PO for discharge home. Her ED 
swab culture had rare growth of gram positive cocci at 
discharge.  Her OR cultures will be followed until finalized and 
will check for sensitivities on the ED culture and make 
necessary antibiotic changes as an outpatient.  The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection during 
her admission.  
.
At the time of discharge on hospital ___ #3 and POD#1, the 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a 
regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain: Total dose of acetaminophen should 
not exceed ___ 
2. ibuprofen 800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every eight 
(8) hours as needed for pain for 7 days.
Disp:*21 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
___ for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cat bite left hand (index finger)

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Followup Instructions:

Brief Hospital Course:
1. Choledocolithiasis without obstruction, Hepatitis NOS, 
Transaminitis
- MRCP does not show an acute obstruction
- MRCP more consistent with an acute hepatitis, along with lab 
studies, however it is quite likely that he passed a stone as 
well
- His viral hepatitis serologies are still pending at time of 
discharge, and should be followed up by his PCP.
- Autoimmune hepatitis labs are pending at time of discharge, 
and should be followed up by his PCP.
- The ERCP team was consulted, and after MRCP results, felt that 
there was no indication for ERCP, given lack of obstruction
- No clear etiology for hepatitis, although acute viral would be 
most concerning. Also note anemia and leukopenia, which would be 
more concerning for acute viral hepatitis
- Scant ascites and paracholecystic fluid, along with sludge 
previously seen, make an evaluation by a general surgeon for 
eventual cholecystectomy a recommendation for the outpatient 
setting
- Lack of coagulopathy makes this more consistent with an acute 
change

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
s/p assault
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ G2P1 at ___ who was transferred from ED after 
presenting s/p physical assault this AM. She lives in a shelter 
but reports meeting her former boyfriend/FOB of her ___-month old 
son and this current pregnancy at a hotel this AM. She reports 
they got into an argument and he hit in in the left face, bit 
her on the right face and left leg, and pushed her down. She hit 
her left abdomen when she fell. 

Denies VB, LOF, ctxs. Initally had some cramping, but this has 
resolved. Does report DFM.

Pt does not believe FOB/boyfriend has access to lethal weapons. 
He does know where her shelter is, but is unaware of her current 
location at ___. Pt reports feeling safe in her shelter.

 
Past Medical History:
PNC: 
- ___ ___
- Rh pos/hep B surface antibody pos - surface antigen not in 
records/HIV neg/RPRNR/Rubella immune/VZ immune/GBS unknown
- Received Tdap ___ during last pregnancy
- Issues: DV

PMHx: denies

PSHx: breast lumpectomy
 
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
(on admission)
VS: 96/45, HR 86, T 98.7, RR 20
Gen: NAD, AxO x 3
HEENT: eccymoses on left face along cheek bone/orbit of eye, and 
trauma from bite noted on right cheek
Abdomen: soft, NTTP, no e/o trauma
Ext: bruise/eccymoses and skin laceration at site of bite on 
left thigh

FHR 150s
 
Pertinent Results:
none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ G2P1 admitted after episode of physical abuse by boyfriend 
___, with trauma to face and left leg. Given extent of 
violence and that perpetrator is aware of the location of her 
shelter, she was observed overnight. She received a dose of IV 
Ceftriaxone, and she will complete a 5 day course of Augmentin. 
She remained clinically stable and was discharged to home on 
HD#2. She was seen by social services and the ___ 
Violence and Prevention while she was here.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Cetirizine 10 mg PO QD-BID urticaria 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q12H 
RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875 mg-125 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth every 12 hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Cetirizine 10 mg PO QD-BID urticaria  
3.  Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Domestic violence, trauma to the face and left leg
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for domestic violence and 
trauma to the face and left leg. You were given 1 dose of 
ceftriaxone antibiotic and will continue with augmentin for 5 
days. You met with our social work team to make a safety plan. 
The social work team is planning to call you tomorrow after 
discharge to check on how you are doing. 
You and your baby have been monitored and we think it is now 
safe for you to go home. 

Please follow the instructions below: 
- Attend all appointments with your obstetrician and all fetal 
scans 
- Please call your OB, the police, or go to the emergency room 
if you have any concerns for your safety or the safety of your 
son
- Monitor for the following danger signs: 
- headache that is not responsive to medication
- abdominal pain
- increased swelling in your legs
- vision changes
- Worsening, painful or regular contractions
- Vaginal bleeding
- Leakage of water or concern that your water broke
- Nausea/vomiting
- Fever, chills
- Decreased fetal movement
- Other concerns
 
Followup Instructions:
___

trip
to ___ with pain and increasing swelling since then. She
then had a massage at the airport without relief. Also took
tylenol. She reports an episode of left calf pain x3 days last
week which resolved. She also endorses difficutly swallowing,
pain in her neck with deep inspiration. She denies any chest
pain, shortness of breath, n/v, abd pain, vaginal bleeding,
cramping, leg pain, leg swelling. 

Patient underwent single egg transfer with HCG trigger (___)
for this last cycle of IVF/ICSI. Embryo transfer on ___. She
then was diagnosed with moderate OHSS on ___. Patient had
declined lovenox in ___ when diagnosed with OHSS. She
underwent culdocentesis and received albumin on ___ as an
outpatient.

- ___ ___ by IVF dating c/w 6 wk u/s
- Labs ___

- Hx LEEP

- LEEP 
- Wisdom teeth

___

tender to palpation
CV: RRR

Ms. ___ was admitted to the antepartum service.  She was 
seen by ___ and vascular surgery in consultation.  Plan was made 
to anti-coagulate with Lovenox for 6 months and re-evaluate clot 
at that time.  She will have thrombophilia work-up as 
out-patient.  Prior to discharge Lovenox was titrated with the 
assistance of hematology.  Although a Factor Xa level was not 
therapeutic, hematology recommended continuing at this 
weight-based dose and follow-up with hematology as an 
out-patient.

extremity clot. You were started on Lovenox and admitted for 
observation. Your pain, swelling, and shortness of breath 
improved while you were here. You will continue taking the 
Lovenox at home (twice daily) and you will need repeat bloodwork 
on ___ to check your level. Continue taking tylenol or Roxicet 
as needed for pain.

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

___
Debridement and closure of left third toe ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ male presented with a history of 
worsening necrosis of L third toe and a several weeks of 
infection.  Pt states that the gangrene developed after he 
dropped a large metal siding on his foot at his workplace.  Pt 
was formerly evaluated and underwent surgery in ___ for 
fractures of the ___ digits.  Subsequently, the pt has 
visited the ER and the ___ clinic several times.  

He denies any fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, chest 
pain or SOB. He is c/o stabbing/burning pain to the plantar 
aspect of the foot.  
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
  AAO x 3, with interpreter, NAD
  RRR no MRG
  CTA b/L no RRW
  Soft,NT, ND, no masses, +BS
  LLE: no CCE, palpable pulses throughout, distal portion of 
third toe removed 
  RLE: no CCE, palpable pulses throughout

 
Pertinent Results:
Hematology 
COMPLETE BLOOD COUNT WBC RBC Hgb Hct MCV MCH MCHC RDW Plt Ct 
___ 09:05PM    6.6 4.71 14.5 42.4 90 30.9 34.3 12.8 269 
BASIC COAGULATION ___, PTT, PLT, INR) ___ PTT Plt Ct ___ 
___ 09:05PM        269   
___ 09:05PM    13.6* 23.8   1.2* 
 
Chemistry 
RENAL & GLUCOSE Glucose UreaN Creat Na K Cl HCO3 AnGap 
___ 09:05PM    109* 18 0.9 139 3.6 ___

___ 09:05PM          9.8 4.7* 2.1     
 
Urine 
GENERAL URINE INFORMATION Type Color ___ 
___ 11:00PM      Straw Clear 1.010 
DIPSTICK URINALYSIS Blood Nitrite Protein Glucose Ketone Bilirub 
Urobiln pH Leuks 
___ 11:00PM    NEG NEG NEG 1000 NEG NEG NEG 7.0 NEG 
 
 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admittedon ___ for necrosis of the L third toe.  
Antibiotics were begun and debridement was scheduled for the 
following day.  On ___, the debridement exposed the phalanx. 
 Cultures from the wound grew Staph aureus coag + and 
pseudomonas aeruginosa.  Podiatry was then consulted to assess 
the salvageability of the digit.  Podiatry recommended that the 
pt return to the OR for removal of the distal phalanx and the 
tip of the proximal phalanx.  The pt returned to the OR on 
___ and underwent a successful debridement and closure of 
the wound.  As pt was afebrile and stable on ___, pt was 
discharged on ciprofloxacin po and Bactrim DS po with followup 
with both podiatry and vascular surgery.  
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours) for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Bactrim DS 160-800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every ___ hours as needed for fever or pain for 30 doses.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Necrotic left ___ toe

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
Do not bear weight on the L foot
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the foot you were operated 
on:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks 

What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

 
Followup Instructions:
___

ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled.

none

none

Discharge Diagnosis:

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication. Please take any
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed. You
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic
medications. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
Avoid strenuous
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 10
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct
you further regarding activity restrictions. Please also
follow-up with your primary care physician.

___

Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Celebrex
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Bilateral varicose veins
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Varicose vein ligation and stripping on left side only.

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo female who recently presented to clinic 
for follow-up of her bilateral varicose veins. She continues to 
have significant swelling and pain in both legs although her 
symptoms are worse in the left leg. She has been   wearing 
compression stockings for the past month with minimal relief. 
She elevates her legs as much as possible but does quite a bit 
of standing for work.  She will be admitted and undergo varicose 
vein ligation and stripping.

 
Past Medical History:
Her past medical history is notable for diabetes.  She was
diagnosed with hypertension at one point, although she states
that she has been normotensive for years.

She has not had any prior surgery.

She is allergic to Penicillin, which causes hives.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Physical examination on discharge:

VS: Tm 98.5 Tc 97.5 HR 67 BP 101/60 RR 18 SpO2 99% RA UO 46 
cc/hr
Resp: no respiratory distress
CV: RRR
Ext: bilateral dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are 
palpable, compression dressing in place heel-to-thigh to remain 
until 72 hrs postop. No active bleeding, some bloody staining of 
dressings.

 
Pertinent Results:
Admit H/H: 39.0
Discharge H/H: 29.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Post-operatively the patient did well.  Her pain was well 
controlled.  She was tolerating a regular diet.  Her left leg 
remained wrapped from foot to upper thigh with curlex and coban. 
 It was elevated as much as possible.  There appeared to be 
little bleed through.  The patient was ambulatory without 
assistance.  

On the day of discharge, the patient is afebrile.  Her 
post-operative hct is 29.9.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
3. Glyburide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
4. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) 
sliding scale Injection ASDIR (AS DIRECTED): Please continue 
your original sliding scale.  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
3. Glyburide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
4. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) 
sliding scale Injection ASDIR (AS DIRECTED): Please continue 
your original sliding scale.  
5. Vicodin ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain: Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking 
this medication.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Senna 8.6 mg Capsule Sig: ___ Capsules PO twice a day as 
needed for constipation: Please take when you are taking pain 
medications to prevent constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
7. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day: 
Please take when taking pain medications to prevent 
constipation.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bilateral varicose veins.

 
Discharge Condition:
Good.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Wound care instructions: 
Please keep your current dressing in place until ___.
1) Curlex from foot to upper thigh
2) ACE wrap over curlex from foot to upper thigh
3) Elevation of leg as much as possible.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Chief Complaint:
Right Leg Varicose Veins
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - PROCEDURE:  Excision of varicosities from the right 
lower
extremity and stripping of the saphenous vein.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a woman with longstanding venous disease
of the lower extremity who previously underwent stripping and
excision from the left leg who now presents with symptomatic
varicosities in the right lower extremity, in the thigh and
calf anteriorly, medially, laterally and posteriorly as well
as reflux in a very large accessory saphenous vein running
parallel to the main saphenous vein.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: HTN, NIDDM II, Phlebitis, 
PSH: Cholecystectomy ___, LLE varicose veins ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge
VS: Temp 97.5, HR 65, BP 119/57, RR 18, O2 100%RA
Gen: Well, NAD, A&O
CV: RRR, No R/G/M
RESP: CTAB
ABD: Soft, NT, Obese
Right Leg with coban/ace from foot to groin. Some patchy strike 
through of dark/dried blood, no sign of active bleeding

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt underwent varicose and saphenous vein striping of right leg 
on ___. Pt admitted to ___ ___ for post-operative pain 
control, anticoagulation due to extensive thromboplebitis, and 
post-operative glycemic control. Pt did well overnight and was 
discharged home on ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
Byetta 10mcg BID, Glyburide 5", HCTZ 25', Lasix 20'
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed.  
2. Glyburide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
4. Furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
5. Byetta 10 mcg/0.04 mL Pen Injector Sig: One (1) Dose 
Subcutaneous twice a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Varicose Veins Right Leg

 
Discharge Condition:
Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your surgeon if you develop chest pain, shortness of 
breath, fever greater than 101.5, foul smelling or colorful 
drainage from your incisions, redness or swelling, severe 
abdominal pain or distention, persistent nausea or vomiting, 
inability to eat or drink, or any other symptoms which are 
concerning to you.

No tub baths or swimming. You may shower on ___ after 
you remove your dressings. Keep wrap on right leg until ___. 

Activity: No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds until the 
follow up appointment with your doctor. 

Medications: Resume your home medications. You should take a 
stool softener, Colace 100 mg twice daily as needed for 
constipation. Pain medication may make you drowsy. No driving 
while taking pain medicine.

Check your blood sugar at least twice daily until they are 
normalized. If your sugars remain elevated call your primary 
care physician to adjust your hypoglycemic medications as 
indicated.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
elevated BPs at home, decreased fetal movement
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ G3P1 at 34w2d presenting today for elevated BPs at home as 
well as DFM. 

She reports that her BPs at home were in the 140s/80-90s today 
and she was told to call if they were high. Reports intermittent 
headaches, epigastric pain, and blurry vision over the past 
week. No SOB.

Fetal movement has been decreased since approximately 28wks 
gestation. Today she reports that she continues to feel movement 
but that it is less than normal.

Also feels that her tachycardia has been worsening, as she has 
been measuring it at home. Feels that this is due to the fact 
that the baby is lower in her pelvis. No SOB as above. Denies CP 
though reports some intermittent right shoulder pain.

 
Past Medical History:
PNC:   
- Dating: EDC ___ by ___
- Labs: O+/Ab neg/RPRNR/rubella immune/HbsAg neg
- U/S ___: 2938gm, 86%
- Issues:
 * h/o LTCS, desires repeat
 * GDMA1 (elevated GLT, declined GTT)
 * sinus tachycardia: s/p Cardiology c/s and Holter monitor,
prior echocardiogram at ___
 * h/o gestational hypertension, neg baseline labs 
 * left calf pain at 29wks, neg ___
 * admission at 30wks for nephrolithiasis

OB Hx: G3P1
- SAB x1
- LTCS x1

Gyn Hx: denies

PMH: scoliosis, fibromyalgia, palpitations (normal echo in past,
normal Holter this year)

PSH: cesarean section, adenoidectomy, tonsilectomy,
cholecystectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
(on admission)

 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-13.0 RBC-3.78 Hgb-10.5 Hct-32.1 MCV-85 Plt-267
___ Creat-0.6 ALT-11 AST-23

___ URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG Glucose-NEG 
Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-7.0 Leuks-NEG
___ URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-46 TotProt-<6 Prot/Cr-<0.___ G3P1 with GDMA1 admitted at 34w2d with gestational HTN and 
decreased fetal movement. Her blood pressures remained in the 
normal to mild range and she had a negative 24 hour urine (<6). 
Preeclampsia labs were normal. Fetal testing also remained 
reassuring during this admission. Her fetus was well grown (86%) 
on her last growth scan. She was discharged home in stable 
condition and will continue to have close outpatient follow up.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
gestational hypertension
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with elevated blood pressures. 
You started a urine collection to help assess if you have 
pre-eclampsia. You will finish this collection at home and bring 
it back to the office when finished. It is now safe for you to 
be discharged home.

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
bright red blood per rectum
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
OPERATIONS:
Roux en Y, revision gastrectomy
Esophagealgastrodudenoscopy (EGD)

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ man with h/o AAA s/p open repair ___, h/o bleeding 
gastric ulcer s/p partial gastrectomy, p/w melena and anemia. 
Initially developed melena ___ AM, with associated 
lightheadedness, and then BRBPR ___ night. Yesterday AM went 
to OSH after speaking with PCP. There, initial CBC showed Hct 24 
(? baseline 30), so received 2units PRBCs with repeat Hct 25, so 
got an additional 4units PRBCs. EGD there reportedly showed 
bleeding at gastrojejunal anastamosis but no active visible site 
to treat. Colonoscopy was also attempted, which reportedly 
showed red blood to the ascending colon, but pt became 
bradycardic requiring atropine, so the procedure was aborted. 
Concern was
raised for aorto-enteric fistula, so he was transferred here. 
Hct prior to transfer was 28, after receiving a total of 6units 
PRBCs over the last 2 days. This morning he was also tachycardic 
to the 140s in atrial fibrillation, after receiving the 
atropine, and he was treated with IVF. Cardiology was consulted, 
who recommended digoxin, but this was not given. Here, he denies 
any abdominal
pain, nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, chest pain, or dyspnea. He 
takes a baby aspirin at home daily, and denies any recent NSAID 
or EtOH use.
 
Past Medical History:
- AAA s/p open repair ___
- diabetes
- hypertension
- hyperlipidemia
- tobacco use
- h/o bleeding gastric ulcer
- s/p partial gastrectomy
- pernicious anemia
- h/o injury to left eye s/p left eye lens implant
- glaucoma
- s/p CCY

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/c
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals:

AOx3, NAD
RRR
CTAB, good respiratory effort
Abd soft, NT/ ND
Incision well healed with staples in place, no drainage, no 
erythema or edema
no pedal edema
Pt able to ambulate without assistance
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission labs:

___ 01:40PM BLOOD WBC-7.7 RBC-3.02* Hgb-9.2* Hct-25.9* 
MCV-86 MCH-30.6 MCHC-35.6* RDW-16.4* Plt ___
___ 01:40PM BLOOD Neuts-76.1* ___ Monos-4.6 Eos-0.7 
Baso-0.5
___ 01:40PM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.1 ___
___ 01:40PM BLOOD Glucose-118* UreaN-16 Creat-0.6 Na-140 
K-3.6 Cl-115* HCO3-21* AnGap-8
___ 01:40PM BLOOD ALT-9 AST-16 LD(LDH)-131 CK(CPK)-61 
AlkPhos-34* Amylase-44 TotBili-0.5
___ 01:40PM BLOOD Albumin-2.9* Calcium-6.7* Phos-1.8* 
Mg-2.0 Iron-151
___ 01:40PM BLOOD calTIBC-272 Ferritn-148 TRF-209
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was transferred from an OSH and admitted to the 
vascular service on ___ preop for his:

He was made NPO after midnight and four units pRBCs crossmatched 
in preparation for the procedure. After his procedure, he was 
readmitted to the vascular surgery service , made NPO on IVF, on 
a PPI drip, and IV medications. He received a transfusion of 2 
units pRBCs. A PICC was placed for access on ___

He was then transferred to general surgery west 3 service with a 
GI bleed. He was continued on a PPI drip, on IV medications, 
kept NPO on IVF, with telemetry for monitoring.

On ___, he triggered after a large bloody bowel movement. He 
received 2uPRBCs, IVF boluses, and an EKG showed he was 
tachycardic to the 140s-150s in a fib which resolved after 
resusitation and a dose of lopressor. GI service performed an 
endoscopy which did not show a distint bleeding vessel or ulcer. 
Sulcrafate was added and he was transfused a unit of 
platelets.Biopsy from the bleeding area showed high grade 
dysplasia.  

His hematocrits were followed and he stayed on the floor. During 
this time he stayed NPO on telemetry. On ___, he was taken 
to the OR for a revision gastrectomy. Post operatively he was 
kept NPO on IVF, on cipro for a UTI, with a foley for urine 
output mgmt, an NGT, a PPI drip, and on IV medications.

He received several LR boluses while in the PACU and had a 
dilaudid PCA for pain control. He was switched to mIVF on 
___ and he was able to ambulate without assistance. On 
___ his cipro for his UTI was d/ced after completing a three 
day course and his oxygen supplementation was d/ced. His PCA was 
also d/ced and his pain well controlled on intermittant IV 
morphine. His NGT was d/ced on ___.

His IVF were discontined on ___ after he tolerated clears 
diet. On ___ he was advanced to full liquids. He was also 
switched to PO pain medications.  He was discharged home with 
glipizide and his metformin was held. His PCP, ___, was 
called to schedule an appointment ___ at 1pm for close 
follow up.
 
Medications on Admission:
- aspirin 81mg daily
- atorvastatin
- glipizide
- metformin
- timolol

 
Discharge Medications:
1. timolol maleate 0.5 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic 
DAILY (Daily).  
2. pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day for 1 months.
Disp:*30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*1*
3. metoprolol tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day) for 2 weeks: Please hold your dose if you 
experience any dizziness. .
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain for 40 doses: Please hold if you are dizzy or 
feel more sedated. .
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. glipizide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. atorvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage
High grade dysplasia of the stomach- probable invasive cancer-  
path pending

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
    It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization. You were admitted for an upper GI bleed and you 
had a procedure, called a Roux-en-Y and revision gastrectomy to 
manage your upper GI bleed. We have prescrbed  You tolerated the 
procedure well and you are now ready to return home. 

Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ if you have:
-fevers greater than 101.5, chills or shakes
-worsening cough or shortness of breath
-drainage, swelling or redness from incisions
-uncontrolled surgical pain
 
Walk several times a day. While on narcotics for pain do not 
drive, and take stool softeners to avoid constipation. Please 
resume your home medications except for your aspirin. We 
encourage you to discuss resuming aspirin with Dr. ___ 
your primary care physician, ___. Please hold your 
metformin and discuss when to restart this medication with your 
primary care physician, ___. 
 
No tub bathing or submerging in water until incisions fully 
healed (usually ___ weeks). You may shower after your discharge.

You will need to have your staples removed in 7 - 10 days. 
Please call Dr. ___ office to schedule an appointment 
for staple removal. His office phone number is ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

resume your home medications except for your aspirin. We
encourage you to discuss resuming aspirin with Dr. ___
your primary care physician, ___. Please hold your
metformin and discuss when to restart this medication with your
primary care physician, ___.
No tub bathing or submerging in water until incisions fully
healed (usually ___ weeks). You may shower after your discharge.
You will need to have your staples removed in 7 - 10 days.
Please call Dr. ___ office to schedule an appointment
for staple removal. His office phone number is ___.
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ returns to clinic today. Her orthopedic history 
is well documented. She has known tricompartmental 
osteoarthritis of both knees. She presents today with ongoing 
right knee pain. She states that she walks ___ times
a day to walk her dog and though she is not limping when she 
walks, she has pain. Previous cortisone injections to the right 
knee helped alleviate her pain. Unfortunately, her right knee 
pain has returned.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
Patient developed asymptomatic bradycardia on postoperative day 
0.  An EKG was obtained, which revealed sinus bradycardia.  A 
troponin was sent, which returned negative.  No further work-up 
indicated.  The rest of her hospitalization was unremarkable.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Aspirin 81 mg twice 
daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The 
surgical dressing will remain on until POD#7 after surgery. The 
patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked 
throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the 
time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and 
feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. 
 The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact.

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. No ROM restrictions. 
Please use walker or 2 crutches, wean as able. 
 
Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Losartan Potassium 50 mg PO DAILY 
2. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg PO DAILY 
3. Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY 
4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3.  Gabapentin 100 mg PO TID 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
5.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
Continue while on 4-week course of ASA 81 mg twice daily. 
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
7.  Aspirin 81 mg PO BID 
Return to ASA 81 mg daily dosing after 4-weeks of ASA 81 mg 
twice daily. 
8.  Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Losartan Potassium 50 mg PO DAILY  
10.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right knee arthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by 
your physician.

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 81 twice daily 
with food for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein 
thrombosis (blood clots).  Continue Pantoprazole daily while on 
Aspirin to prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks).  If you were taking 
Aspirin prior to your surgery, take it at 81 mg twice daily 
until the end of the 4 weeks, then you can go back to your 
normal dosing.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment in two (2) weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at three weeks 
after surgery.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
lifting until follow up appointment.  Mobilize frequently.

Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
ROMAT
Wean assistive device as able (i.e. 2 crutches or walker)
Mobilize frequently 

Treatments Frequency:
Remove aquacel POD#7 after surgery
apply dry sterile dressing daily if needed after aquacel 
dressing is removed
wound checks daily after aquacel removed
staple removal and steri strip application at ___ clinic 
visit

 
Followup Instructions:
___

pre-operative testing.   The patient was taken to the OR on

undertaken:

Laparoscopically-assisted sigmoid
colectomy with end-to-end anastomosis

The patient recovered well from this surgery, regaining full

minimal pain by the fourth post-operative day.  on the ___ he 
was determined as being completely stable for discharge and was 
discharged appropriately home.

Home

recurrent diverticulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, tolerating usual oral diet without difficulty, 
ambulating independently without difficulty, having bowel 
movements without difficulty, urinating independently without 
difficulty, pain well-controlled on an oral pain regimen

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or becoming 
progressively worse, or inadequately controlled with the 
prescribed pain medication.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY

aspirin / Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
post operative bleeding 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
bleeding stopped in ER with electrocautery 

 
History of Present Illness:
 ___ yo M w/ prior history of posterior anal fissure and
external hemorrhoids s/p sphinectorotomy today by Dr. ___. 
He
has been bleeding since the surgery and even though he has been
wearing 2 diapers at a time for protection, he's had to change
them 3 times already filled with clot each time.  He also 
dirtied
his pants with blood and so he comes back in for further
evaluation. He denies lightheadedness, palpitations, cP, SOB or
fevers.

We attempted to stop the bleeding in the ED but there was brisk
bleeding from the anus that was difficult to stop, ultimately 
had
to get stitches and cauterization in the ED by Dr. ___ to
successfully stop the bleeding. Got 1 pRBC for brisk bleeding.

 
Past Medical History:
Psychiatric Problems: depression 
Other: anal fissure

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Inflammatory Disease no  
Colon Cancer  no       
Cancer (other) no  
 
Physical Exam:
afebrile, vss 
Gen: somewhat anxious in bed
P: CTAB
RRR: tachycardic, regular, no m/r/g
Abd: soft, nontender, nondistended
Rectum: clean, dry, intact, hemostatic 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:50AM   WBC-18.4*# RBC-4.83 HGB-14.1 HCT-40.9 MCV-85 
MCH-29.2 MCHC-34.5 RDW-13.8 RDWSD-42.5
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the ED secondary to rectal bleeding 
from the surgical site. The bleeding was controlled in the 
emergency department and H/H was rechecked in the morning. The 
patient's foley was removed, they voided spontaneously, and they 
were advanced to a regular diet. They were discharged home on 
hospital day 1 with plan to follow up as previously scheduled. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Post operative bleeding from fistulotomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for post operative bleeding. Your bleeding has 
been controlled. You should continue with all post operative 
instructions that you were given prior to your surgery 
yesterday. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
