text:
Name:  ___                        Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
fire ants
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Left foot synovial sarcoma
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Resection of left foot sarcoma
 
History of Present Illness:
 The patient has been presenting
symptoms since late ___ and ___ and received a
corticosteroid in the dorsal aspect of her foot trying to
palliate her symptoms.  The patient refers that her pain is a
level 7 in a scale from 0 to 10 ___nd with activity as 
high
as a level 10.  The patient refers that toe flexion and
extension, palpation and abduction of the foot increase her
symptoms.  The pain radiates distally and proximally.  The
patient currently is in treatment with gabapentin to help to
control her symptoms.  The patient has a significant medical
history for neuroma that was treated surgically between the
second and third digits in ___. 
She had a biopsy of the left foot mass that confirmed the 
diagnosis of synovial sarcoma. The patient had neoadjuvant 
radiotherapy, followed by resection of the left foot sarcoma on 
___.

 
Past Medical History:
negative
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Her family history is significant for the death of her father
secondary to a chondrosarcoma and subsequently a lung cancer.

 
Physical Exam:
On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. 
She is awake, alert, oriented to time, person, location and 
fully
cooperative to the physical exam.  
Left foot 
- Wound clean
- Intact ___ / FHL
- Patient too cautious and limited Ankle dorsi and plantar
flexion
- Sensation intact in SP, DP, Sural, Tibial. Allodynia response
to touch
- WWP

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service on 
___ and underwent a resection of the left foot sarcoma. 
They were transferred from the ___ to ___. On the day 
of discharge, pain was well controlled and they had passed 
physical therapy. 
 Musculoskeletal: After the procedure, patient's weight-bearing 
status was transitioned to weight bearing as tolerated. 
Throughout the hospitalization, patient worked with physical 
therapy
 Neuro: post-operatively, patient's pain was controlled by IV 
and then PO pain medications with good effect and adequate pain 
control.
 CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
 Hematology: The patient was transfused 0 units of blood for 
acute blood loss anemia.
 Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
 GI/GU: A po diet was tolerated well. Patient was also started 
on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and 
output were closely monitored.
 ID: The patient received routine perioperative antibiotics 
following the procedure. The patient's temperature was closely 
watched for signs of infection.
 Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. NuvaRing (etonogestrel-ethinyl estradiol) 0.12-0.015 mg/24 hr 
vaginal monthly 
2. Gabapentin 400 mg PO QHS 

 
Discharge Medications:
Oxycodone
Gabapentin
Aspirin
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left foot synovial sarcoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weight bearing as tolerated of the left lower extremity, using 
a short walking boot for comfort. Boot can come off when not 
ambulating. Use crutches for comfort.

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take 81mg aspirin daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower but make sure to cover your foot with dry 
sterile dressing, a plastic bag, and tape. No baths or swimming 
for at least 4 weeks.
- You may remove your dressing on post operative day 4 (___). 
You can leave it open to air or cover with a dry sterile 
dressing. 
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Use your post operative boot while ambulating

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. <<<<<>>>>>. 
You will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days post-operation for evaluation. 
Call ___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"A pill is stuck in my throat"
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PMH significant only for osteopenia/osteoporosis 
presenting with odynophagia. Patient reports she felt in her 
usual state of health until six days prior to admission when she 
took a bisphosphonate for the first time, without water, and 
promptly laid down. She felt as though the pill had become stuck 
in her throat, and this sensation persisted until four ___ prior 
to admission when she presented to the emergency room. At that 
time she also developed a low-grade fever. She had a chest X-ray 
performed, which was within normal limits, and was sent home 
with the diagnosis of pill esophagitis. She continued to 
experience pain with swallowing to the degree that she was 
unable to take any PO's. She continued to have low grade fevers 
as well, but denies cough, muscle aches, or other URI symptoms. 
Due to the pain and her inability to take PO's she returned to 
the ___ emergency room and was admitted to medicine.

ROS: As noted above. In addition,patient denies chest pain, 
shortness of breath, diarrhea, constipation, lightheadedness, 
dizziness, or change in vision.
 
Past Medical History:
Osteopenia/osteoporosis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Denies esophageal disease.
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T=100.1, BP=120/90, HR=88, RR=16, 96% RA
General: Awake, alert, comfortable appearing
HEENT: No palpable lymphadenopathy, NCAT, EOMI
CV: RR, no m/r/g
Pulm: CTA B
Abd: Soft, NTND
Ext: No edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:00AM   GLUCOSE-140* UREA N-9 CREAT-0.5 SODIUM-134 
POTASSIUM-3.5 CHLORIDE-99 TOTAL CO2-22 ANION GAP-17
___ 05:00AM   CK-MB-1 cTropnT-<0.01
___ 05:00AM   WBC-5.2 RBC-4.62 HGB-13.4 HCT-40.4 MCV-88 
MCH-29.0 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.2
___ 05:00AM   ___ PTT-22.6 ___. Pill esophagitis: Thought to be due to bisphosphonate. Chest 
CT was negative for perforation; EGD significant for erosions in 
the bottom ___ of the esophagus as well as inflammation. Patient 
had good symptomatic response to carafate and 
diphenhydramine/lidocaine/maalox. She was tolerating full 
liquids at the time of discharge. Esophageal biopsies will 
require follow-up; in addition, GI recommends checking HSV ___ 
and CMV to rule out other causes of esophagitis.

2. Osteoporosis/osteopenia: Will hold bisphosphonate until 
patient's symptoms completely resolve; okay to re-start calcium 
when patient tolerating pills.

3. Fever: No systemic symptoms; chest CT with no evidence of 
pneumonia; white blood count normal. Flu swab was ordered but 
had insufficient cells; flu culture is pending and will need to 
be followed up. Clinical suspicion for flu is low.

4. Pulmonary nodules: Two small 4mm pulmonary nodules were 
noted, as was an abnormal mediastinal soft tissue mass, both of 
which will require a repeat CT in one year.
 
Medications on Admission:
Calcium
Bisphosphonate

 
Discharge Medications:
1. magic mouthwash  Sig: ___ mL  four times a day as needed 
for pain for 2 weeks: Diphenhydramine/Benadryl/Lidocaine.
Disp:*2 weeks supply* Refills:*0*
2. Sucralfate 1 gram Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QID (4 times 
a day) as needed for pain for 2 weeks.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*2*

You may resume your calcium.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Pill esophagitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status:Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness:Alert and interactive
Activity Status:Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with throat pain and a fever. 
It is thought that your throat pain is from irritation to your 
esophagus from the pill you took last week. Your fever is likely 
from a viral infection, for which no treatment is necessary.

You are being started on three new medications. One of them, 
omeprazole, should be taken indefinitely. The other two, 
carafate and lidocaine/diphenhydramine/maalox, is for your 
throat pain and can be stopped when your symptoms resolve.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Due to the pain and her inability to take PO's she returned to
the ___ emergency room and was admitted to medicine.

shortness of breath, diarrhea, constipation, lightheadedness,
dizziness, or change in vision.

Osteopenia/osteoporosis

___

POTASSIUM-3.5 CHLORIDE-99 TOTAL CO2-22 ANION GAP-17
___ 05:00AM CK-MB-1 cTropnT-<0.01
___ 05:00AM WBC-5.2 RBC-4.62 HGB-13.4 HCT-40.4 MCV-88
MCH-29.0 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.2
___ 05:00AM ___ PTT-22.6 ___. Pill esophagitis: Thought to be due to bisphosphonate. Chest
CT was negative for perforation; EGD significant for erosions in
the bottom ___ of the esophagus as well as inflammation. Patient
had good symptomatic response to carafate and
diphenhydramine/lidocaine/maalox. She was tolerating full
liquids at the time of discharge. Esophageal biopsies will
require follow-up; in addition, GI recommends checking HSV ___
and CMV to rule out other causes of esophagitis.
2. Osteoporosis/osteopenia: Will hold bisphosphonate until
patient's symptoms completely resolve; okay to re-start calcium
when patient tolerating pills.
3. Fever: No systemic symptoms; chest CT with no evidence of
pneumonia; white blood count normal. Flu swab was ordered but
had insufficient cells; flu culture is pending and will need to
be followed up. Clinical suspicion for flu is low.
4. Pulmonary nodules: Two small 4mm pulmonary nodules were
noted, as was an abnormal mediastinal soft tissue mass, both of
which will require a repeat CT in one year.

Bisphosphonate

You were admitted to the hospital with throat pain and a fever.
It is thought that your throat pain is from irritation to your
esophagus from the pill you took last week. Your fever is likely
from a viral infection, for which no treatment is necessary.
You are being started on three new medications. One of them,
omeprazole, should be taken indefinitely. The other two,
carafate and lidocaine/diphenhydramine/maalox, is for your
throat pain and can be stopped when your symptoms resolve.

of outpatient betamethasone as planned, given shortening cervix

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: DENTAL
 
Allergies: 
Gluten
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
punch to face
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ORIF of R mandibular body fracture and MMF (arch bars on lower 
teeth and 4 maxillary screws on upper teeth), teeth are wired 
shut.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ who was punched in the left side of his face. Had pain and 
swelling of his jaw. No lacerations on his face, but had thmem 
in the oral cavity. Was seen at OSH where he was given augmentin 
and percoset. He came to the emergency ward today because of 
continuing pain. Complains that he can't fully clench his teeth
on the left side.

 
Past Medical History:
celiac disease
 
Social History:
smoker, college student
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: A&O, NAD
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist
Face: Teeth are wired shut. Mild swelling of jaw.
CV: RRR, No M/G/R
PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R
ABD: Soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding,
normoactive bowel sounds, no palpable masses
Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused

 
Brief Hospital Course:
PAtient was admitted for surgery on ___ for his mandibular 
fractures. He underwent R mandibular body fracture and MMF (arch 
bars on lower teeth and 4 maxillary screws on upper teeth. He 
was seen by nutrition and advanced to full liquid diet. He had 
instructions on care for his teeth wires, including bone wax. He 
will use a clorhexidine moutwash for hygiene. His pain was 
controlled with liquid oral pain medication. He is stable for 
discharge and will follow up with ___ in 1 week.
 
Medications on Admission:
augmentin
percoset
 
Discharge Medications:
1. lansoprazole 30 mg Tablet,Rapid Dissolve, ___ ___: One (1) 
Tablet,Rapid Dissolve, ___ ___.
Disp:*50 Tablet,Rapid Dissolve, ___ Refills:*2*
2. acetaminophen 650 mg/20.3 mL Solution Sig: One (1)  ___ Q4H 
(every 4 hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*60 * Refills:*0*
3. oxycodone 5 mg/5 mL Solution Sig: One (1)  ___ Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 * Refills:*0*
4. chlorhexidine gluconate 0.12 % Mouthwash Sig: One (1) ML 
Mucous membrane QID (4 times a day) as needed for after meals 
and at bedtime.
Disp:*100 ML(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Augmentin 250-62.5 mg/5 mL Suspension for Reconstitution Sig: 
Three (3)  ___ twice a day for 7 days.
Disp:*42 * Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Mandibular fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory 

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were brought in to the hospital for surgical repair of your 
mandibular fractures. This was accomplished by a combination of 
open reduction and internal fixation, maxillary screws, and 
wiring your teeth.
Specific Instructions:
Your teeth are wired, so you are to be on a full liquid diet. 
This is what you were given in the hospital and the 
nutritionists spoke to you about what this entails. Please 
adhere to this diet and call if you have questions regarding it.
You have to use bone wax given the wiring in your teeth, this 
was also explained to you while you were admitted.
You  have a mouth cleanser (chlorhexidine) that is to be used 4 
times ___.
You have to take antibiotics: Augmentin for 7 more days.
You have to follow up with ___ within 1 week.

General Instructions
Medications: 
* Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. 
* You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  
* Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
* Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the 
prescription pain medication to prevent constipation. You may 
use a different over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

CV: RRR
Pulm: unlabored respirations
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service following 
ORIF of mandible, left ZF, lateral buttress, inferior orbital 
rim and orbital floor.  For full details of this procedure, 
please refer to the operative report.  He was monitored 
postoperatively with Q1 hour vision checks, which remianed 
stable, without any changes in vision or color perception.  He 
was started on a diet of clear liquids which he tolerated well.  
He was given unasy for antibiotic prophylaxis.  He had good pain 
control with oral medication.  On the monring of POD 1, his exam 
remained stable and he was feeling well.  His JP drain was 
discontinued.  He was deemed appropriate for discharge at this 
time, with scheduled follow up with Dr. ___ in one week.

RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875 mg-125 mg 1 Tablet by mouth 
Q12HRS Disp #*14 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Chlorhexidine Gluconate 0.12% Oral Rinse 15 mL ORAL TID 
RX *chlorhexidine gluconate 0.12 % Rinse with 15 mL three times 
a day Disp #*1 Bottle Refills:*0

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left mandibular angle, right ZMC and orbital floor fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital following ORIF of your 
mandible, ZF, lateral buttress, inferior orbital rim and orbital 
floor fractures.  You were observed overnight and remained 
stable.  Your vision is unchanged, you are tolerating a diet of 
clear liquids, and your pain is adequately controlled.  You may 
now return home to finish your recovery.

Please continue to take any home medications as you were prior 
to your hospital stay.  You are being perscribed oxycodone for 
pain.  Please take as directed.  You may also take tylenol for 
pain.  You should not drive or consume alcohol while taking 
oxycodone.  

You should take only a liquid diet for the first two days after 
surgery to allow your mouth incisions to heal.  Then you may 
transition to a diet of soft foods until follow up with Dr. 
___.  You should continue to sleep with your head propped up 
on pillows, sneeze with your mouth open.  You should use 
chlorahexadine gluconate mouth wash ___ times per day to 
maintain hygiene.

If you have any sudden changes in your vision or perception of 
color, please call the officie immediately or come into the 
emergency department for evaluation.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

surgery to allow your mouth incisions to heal. Then you may
transition to a diet of soft foods until follow up with Dr.
___. You should continue to sleep with your head propped up
on pillows, sneeze with your mouth open. You should use
chlorahexadine gluconate mouth wash ___ times per day to
maintain hygiene.
If you have any sudden changes in your vision or perception of
color, please call the officie immediately or come into the
emergency department for evaluation.
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ who presented to the ED one dya prior to 
admission after approximately 4 hours of noticeable left leg 
pain with associated swelling. He described his left leg as 
becoming twice the size of teh right, with pain worsening with 
ambulation. The pain was in the posterior portion of the calf 
from the ankle to the knee. He did not take any analgesia. He 
denies recent travel history, immobilization or trauma. He was 
found on LENIs to have a left common femoral DVT and was started 
on Lovenox bridge and Coumadin. He was able to go home.

This morning he had an episode of blood in his sputum after 
waking up. The sputum was initially bright red and progressed to 
clear. At the urging of his son, a ___, he 
re-presented to the ED where he had a CTA, significant for 
Pulmonary embolism. To note, he had not yet filled his previous 
prescriptions for Lovenox or Coumadin. He denies associated 
sypnea, orthopnea, chest pain, palpitations, impending sense of 
doom, pain with swallowing, headache or dizziness, or LOC.

In the ED, initial vitals:  T-98.6 P-77 Bp-156/76 RR-16 O2-100% 
RA. He was started on a heparin drip and admitted for 
observation.

ROS: per HPI, denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, 
vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, 
shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, 
dysuria, hematuria.

atraumatic
NECK - supple, no JVD

MRG

rebound/guarding  
EXTREMITIES - WWP, 2+ peripheral pulses (radials, DPs), left 
calf swolen from ankle to knee with pitting edema, left leg 
erythematous, warm & dry without ulcerations, Negative ___ 
sign   
SKIN - no rashes or lesions  
NEURO - awake and conversant, A&Ox3, muscle strength ___ 
throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout, cerebellar exam 
intact, steady gait  

Exam Prior to discharge:
T-98.1, P-79, BP-145/90, RR-20, O2-95%
Gen: well-appearing, NAD, appears stated age
HEENT: moist mucouc membranes, EOMI, neck supple without nodal 
enlargement, oropharyn clear & pink without exudate or 
laceration
Cardiac: RRR, No MRG, PMI not-displaced
Lungs: CTAB, symmetric expansion of chest wall, good air 
movement without rubs or crackles
Abdomen: soft, NT, ND, without organomegaly
Extremities; left leg larger than right, but reduced swelling 
compared to yesterday, lefty leg warmer than right leg with mild 
erythema, ___ Negative, strong radial and DP pulses, no 
evidence of skin breakdown

intact

___ GLUCOSE-90 UREA N-14 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-139 POTASSIUM-4.2

___ cTropnT-<0.01 proBNP-45

___ WBC-11.7 RBC-5.31 HGB-15.5 HCT-45.3 MCV-85 MCH-29.2 
MCHC-34.2 RDW-12.6 PLT COUNT-190
___ NEUTS-73.0 ___ MONOS-5.5 EOS-2.4 BASOS-1.0
___ ___ PTT-34.7 ___

___ Chest CTA: 
1. Segmental right lower lobe pulmonary embolus without 
associated pulmonary abnormality or evidence for right heart 
strain. 
2. Fatty liver.    
3. Heterogeneous left lobe of the thyroid. Further evaluation is 
recommended with non-urgent ultrasound. 

___ Chest X-Ray:
No acute cardiopulmonary process

___ Unilateral lower Extremity Noninvasive Study:
1.  Extensive nearly to completely occlusive deep venous 
thrombosis from the distal common femoral vein extending to the 
level of the calf veins. 
2.  No evidence of DVT in the right lower extremity. 
3.  No ___ cyst 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with a PMH significant for HTN presents with acute onset 
left leg pain and swelling found to be a DVT with associated 
right lower lobe PE complicated by hemoptysis. Patient 
clinically stable without repeat episode of hemoptysis

# Unprovoked pulmonary embolism/DVT: The patient originally 
presented to the ED for leg pain and swelling one day prior to 
admission where has was found to have a left leg DVT and was 
sent home on a Lovenox bridge to therapeutic Coumadin. Less than 
24 hours later, he had an episode of hemoptysis without chest 
pain or dyspnea, re-presenting to the ED with CTA evidence of R 
lung Pulmonary Embolism. He was admitted for observation and IV 
heparin sliding scale for anticoagulation therapy. The patient 
was  hemodynamically stable and non-toxic appearing during his 
entire hopsitalization. This unprovoked hypercoagulable state 
warrants minimum 3 months of COumadin with INR of ___ with 
reassessment and potential life-long anticoagulation (patient is 
a low bleed risk). His ECG on admission with in regular rate and 
rhythm with evidence of mild right heart strain consistent with 
his serum tropnonin levels were undetected and BNP of 45.  He 
was discharged with coumadin 5 mg daily and lovenox ___ mg BID 
bridge.  He will follow up with his PCP on ___ for INR 
check.

#Hypertension: The patient has a personal history of HTN family 
history of CVD. He is managed as an outpatient on Lisinopril. 
Due to his recent PE and DVT, his Lisinopril was held to monitor 
for hemodynamic compromise. he remained stable throughout his 
hospitalization, with SBP ranging from 112-143 and DBP ranging 
from 60-88. He has discharge instructions to restart home 
Lisinopril 20mg.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
3. Vitamin D 50,000 UNIT PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. Enoxaparin Sodium 100 mg SC Q12H DVT Duration: 5 Days 
RX *enoxaparin 100 mg/mL 100 mg injection twice a day Disp #*10 
Syringe Refills:*0
3. Warfarin 5 mg PO DAILY16 
RX *warfarin [Coumadin] 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp 
#*10 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Deep Venous Thrombosis
Pulmonary Embolism

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were evaluated and observed in the hospital for a recent 
pulmonary embolus with hemoptysis (coughing blood). You were 
treated in the hospitla with a blood thinner as prophylaxis for 
a recurrent event. You have bene instructed to begin Wafarin 
therapy as an outpatient and have an appointment with your 
primary care provider to discuss the role of this blood thinner 
and the ongoing management of your blood levels.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Iodine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Respiratory failure
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o M h/o CAD s/p CABG, ___, CRI, AFib on coumadin, CHB s/p 
pacer, ___ transferred from ___ s/p tracheostomy for 
management of respiratory failure and septic shock. According to 
reports he was in ___ with his wife where they live part 
of the year when he suffered a fall.  Following that he had 
progressive dyspnea.  He presented to the local hospital ___ 
where he had a chest xray that showed complete white out of the 
left lung.  He was seen by the surgical consultant in the ED who 
performed a thoracotomy and chest tube placement with a small 
amount of red blood.  CT scan was reportedly suggestive of a 
hemothorax.  His VS at that time were T 97 BP 85/49 WBC 5.2 Hgb 
8.6 PLT 106 PTT 28.2 INR 1.49  Na 136 K4.2 AST 22 ALT 32 CKMB 
1.6 Trop <0.05  ABG 7.5 pCO2 32.7 PO2 63, BUN 25 creat 2.4.  
Chest CT from ___ reportedly with complete opacification of 
the left lung with air bronchograms.  Findings suggestive of 
extensive pneumonic consolidation vs malignancy.   According to 
physician notes felt most likely to be hemothorax ___ pneumonia 
with supratheraputic INR of 4.4.
.
He was subsequently transferred to a hospital in ___ on 
___ for treatment by a pulmonologist.  He was treated with 
levophed, imipenem/cilastin, vancomycin, Intropin?. He was 
mechanically ventilated with settings CMV 50% 500 20 7.   During 
his course he had bronchoscopy which showed LL atelctasis and 
pneumonia.  He had an Echo ___ which showed EF 60%, dilated 
left atrium, mild MR, trivial TR, calcific aortic valve, severe 
LV diastolic dysfunction, no pericardial effusion, no 
intracardiac thrombus.  On ___ he had tracheostomy given 
severity of underlying lung process.  Levophed was weaned 
starting on ___.  CXR from ___ reportedly showed 
bilateral perihilar and basal opacities with obscuration of the 
diaphragm and costophrenic angles most likely pleural effusion.  
On ___ he was transfused 10 units platelets.  Sputum CX from 
___ with ___ albicans, urine culture from ___ with 10,000 
___.  Blood culture ___ with no growth.  Labs on ___ with 
Vanco T 29.6, ___ WBC 15.2 HCT 26.3 PLT 55, creatinine 1.4, BUN 
85, Na 149, CL 129, CO2 19.
.
During his mediflight transfer to ___ his V/S were stable with 
blood pressure 112/46 - 135/69, uneventful per report.    
.

 
Past Medical History:
CAD s/p CABG ___
CHB s/p pacemaker
___ (EF 55% in ___
AFib
Tachy-brady syndrome
CLL 
CRI b/l Cr 1.5
Anemia b/l Hct ___
HTN
COPD
Hyperlipidemia
s/p hernia repair
s/p tonsillectomy
BPH
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
unknown

 
Physical Exam:
V/S T 97.5 HR 86 BP 94/45 RR 18 96% on AC 500/20/5/40% CVP 9
GEN: intubated, sedated
HEENT: PERRL, poor dentition; NGT
NECK: tracheostomy; R subclavian
CV: RRR nl S1S2 no m/r/g
PULM: asymmetric chest wall with sunken-appearing left 
hemithorax; absent BS on left, coarse BS with scattered end-exp 
wheeze on right
ABD: soft, NTND +BS
EXT: warm, dry; DP pulses + with doppler; extensive bandages 
cover all 4 ext
SKIN: multiple areas of skin breakdown, friability, ecchymosis; 
2 cm R lateral arm ulceration
NEURO: withdraws to painful stimuli 

 
Pertinent Results:
CXR: near-complete white-out of left hemithorax with some 
aeration of LUL field; RLL field with mild interstitial markings 

.
EKG: V-paced HR 60, underlying rhythm is AFib; old TWI in I,L; 
old J-point elevation in anterior precordial leads
.
TTE ___ - The left and right atria are markedly dilated. There 
is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal 
cavity size and systolic function (LVEF>55%). Regional left 
ventricular wall motion is normal. Transmitral Doppler and 
tissue velocity imaging are consistent with Grade II (moderate) 
LV diastolic dysfunction. Right ventricular chamber size and 
free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Moderate 
(2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is a trivial/physiologic 
pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Symmetric LVH with preserved global and regional 
biventricular systolic function. Moderate diastolic dysfunction. 
Moderate mitral regurgitation. Mild pulmonary hypertension.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M h/o CAD s/p CABG, dCHF, CRI, AFib on coumadin, CHB s/p 
pacer, CLL, s/p tracheostomy transferred for management of 
respiratory failure and septic shock. On admission patient was 
s/p tracheostomy.  The records incomplete but suspect hypoxic 
resp failure in the setting of septic shock, airway collapse.  A 
bronchoscopy revealed friable airways, bronchomalacia, mucous, 
and old blood consistent with severe hemorrhagic aspiration PNA. 
 Patient's repiratory status was supported with mechanical 
ventilation.  A chest CT was performed which showed a loculated 
pleural effusion concerning for emphyema. The patient's family 
decided not to persue thoracocentesis to drain abscess.  The 
patient septic shock did not improve after several days of 
pressors and fluid boluses.  The patient was treated with broad 
spectrum antibiotics. Given the patient's poor overall prognosis 
the family eventually decided to make the patient CMO.  He 
passed away peacefully and his family was notified of the 
patient's passing. 

 
Medications on Admission:
amlodipine 2.5 mg daily
norvasc 7.5 mg daily
metoprolol 25 mg BID
spironolactone 25 mg daily
lasix 60 mg qAM, 20 mg qPM
coumadin 2.5 mg daily
ASA 81 mg daily
lipitor
flomax 0.4 mg daily
finasteride 
zantac 150 mg BID
vit D 1000 U daily
FeSO4
B12 1000 mcg 
citracel
dulcolax 
MVI
 
Discharge Medications:
NONE
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Septic Shock likely secondary to aspiration PNA
 
Discharge Condition:
Expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
Expired
 
Followup Instructions:
___

and old blood consistent with severe hemorrhagic aspiration PNA. Patient's repiratory status was supported with mechanical
ventilation. A chest CT was performed which showed a loculated
pleural effusion concerning for emphyema. The patient's family
decided not to persue thoracocentesis to drain abscess. The
patient septic shock did not improve after several days of
pressors and fluid boluses. The patient was treated with broad
spectrum antibiotics. Given the patient's poor overall prognosis
the family eventually decided to make the patient CMO. He
passed away peacefully and his family was notified of the
patient's passing.
Medications on Admission:
amlodipine 2.5 mg daily
norvasc 7.5 mg daily
metoprolol 25 mg BID
spironolactone 25 mg daily
lasix 60 mg qAM, 20 mg qPM
coumadin 2.5 mg daily
ASA 81 mg daily
lipitor
flomax 0.4 mg daily
finasteride
zantac 150 mg BID
vit D 1000 U daily
FeSO4
B12 1000 mcg
citracel
dulcolax
MVI
Discharge Medications:
NONE
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
Discharge Diagnosis:
Septic Shock likely secondary to aspiration PNA
Discharge Condition:
Expired
Discharge Instructions:
Expired
Followup Instructions:
___

___ her on ___ and agreed with inpatient pain 
service recommendations of Oxycontin 10mg BID and PRN Oxycontin

BID.  After counseling with Dr. ___ patient requested to 
speak with Social Work for psycho-social issues.  Physical 
Therapy consult was also obtained and they encouraged ambulation 
and recommended discharge to home.

At the time of discharge she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating with a walker assistive device, afebrile with stable 
vital signs. The patient's strength was ___ but due to periodic 
___ pain associated with back spasms the patient was given a 
walker with recommendations for physical therapy at home. The 
patient complains of decreased sensation over the entire left 
leg in no detmatomal distribution.  The patient had not yet seen 
social work and will be dispo to home with consult to social 
work as an outpatient.  It was also recommended that the  
patient have a home safety evaluation.  The patient will follow 
up with Dr ___ and with Dr ___ pain management.  There

time.

Discharge Instructions:
Do not smoke.
Take your pain medication as instructed; 
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, and drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F. 
Any change in your bowel or bladder habits (such as loss of 
bowl or urine control).

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo male with hx HTN, hyperlipidemia, GERD, presented from 
___ with complaints of 1 day of fevers, and he was 
found to have significantly elevated LFTs which was concerning 
for biliary obstruction, cholangitis, and cholestatic hepatitis. 
 Pt underwent ERCP, where he was found to have a 10 mm filling 
defect in the distal CBD c/w choledocolithiasis and associated 
pus was noted.  The pt underwent sphincterotomy and biliary 
stent placement.  The stone was NOT removed from the duct, given 
the patient's active cholangitis and he had a desaturation to 
the 50's which required brief intubation.  He was treated with 
IV ciprofloxacin and flagyl during the hospitalization, and he 
will continue oral antibiotics for 2 weeks for his cholangitis, 
given the stone remaining in his bile duct.  He will undergo 
repeat ERCP on ___, with stone extraction.  His 
Lovastatin is currently being held due to his elevated LFT's, 
and this should be resumed once his LFT's normalize. 
 
  
Coagulopathy, NOS  
Pt was noted to have a mild coagulopathy of unclear etiology.  
Possibly due to above liver disease.  He was provided an Vitamin 
K challenge, without improvement in his coagulation profile.  
Please consider rechecking coags at follow up. 
.

Pt was continued on atenolol, but his HCTZ and irbesartan were 
held during the admission given his acute infection. These were 
resumed at the time of discharge.  
.  
GERD: continued PPI  
.  
HLD: his lovastatin was held during this admission due to his 
cholestatic hepatitis. Please follow his LFT's as an outpatient 
and resume once his LFT's normalize.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain and shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Retrievable IVC filter placement
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with hx of Crohns disease, SBos, atrial fibrillation, 
COPD, CAD, CHF who presented to ___ with 
abdominal pain x 3 days, found to have PE and was transferred to 
___ for consideration of IVC filter.  

Patient is a poor historian. Most of the history is provided 
from ___ records and from daughter. Patient initially 
presented to ___ with abdominal pain primarily in RLQ 
and decreased po intake. He also reported shortness of breath 
over the last few months prior to admission that had worsened in 
the 2 to 3 weeks prior to admission.  

At ___ he underwent a CT of his abdomen and pelvis which 
showed persistent small bowel dilation and bowel wall thickening 
of the ileocolic anastomoses site and fistula between the 
residual right colon or distal ileum in the region of 
anastomoses and the duodenum. A small PE was incidentally noted 
in the right lower lobe. he then underwent bilateral LENIs which 
should bilateral DVTs. They elected not to start anticoagulation 
as patient has GI bleeds in the past and he was on Coumadin at 
one point and had melanotic stools so this was stopped. Given 
that he is a poor candidate for anticoagulation and that there 
was no interventional radiology at ___ he was transfered 
here for consideration of IVC filter placement.  
Of note he had a EGD 2 weeks prior to admission that showed that 
he had esophageal ulcers that were not actively bleeding. He was 
noted to be in Afib with RVR at that time however it was 
determined not to start on anticoagulation at that time due to 
heme positive stools and known ulcers.  
Vital signs prior to transfer were T: AF BP: 102/50 HR: 110 RR: 
16 O2 Sat: 94% 2.  
Currently, he has no complaints.  
 
On the floor,  
Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or 
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or 
congestion. Denied cough. Denied chest pain or tightness, 
palpitations. Denied nausea, vomiting, constipation. No recent 
change in bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied arthralgias or 
myalgias. 
 
Past Medical History:
Crohn's diseaes s/p 2 bowel resections  
hernia repair  
coronary artery disease s/p MI ___ years ago  
COPD - recently given home oxygen  
?CHF  
atrial fibrillation  
hypertension  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
EXAM ON ADMISSION: 
------------------
Vitals: T: 97.5 BP: 96/62 P: 67 R: 18 O2: 98% 2L  
General: comfortable in NAD  
HEENT: sclera anicteric, MMM. OP clear  
Neck: supple, no cervical lymphadenopathy  
CV: Irregular. normal s1/s2. no murmurs appreciated  
Lungs: clear to auscultation. no wheezes, crackles.  
Abdomen: +BS, soft. tender to palpation in RLQ. no rebound 
tenderness.  
Ext: warm and well perfused. no edema  
Neuro: A&Ox person, ___, year. Able to follow commands. CN 
II-XII grossly intact. strength ___ in upper and lower 
extremities  
Skin: warm and dry  

EXAM ON DISCHARGE: 
------------------

 
Pertinent Results:
LABS ON ADMISSION
-----------------

LABS ON DISCHARGE
-----------------

MICROBIOLOGY
-------------

___ MRSA SCREEN: Negative.
___ URINE CULTURE: No growth.
___ Stool Culture: No growth. Negative for C diff, 
salmonella, shigella, campylobacter.
___: Blood Culture x2: No growth to date.
___: MRSA Screen: 
___: Pleural Fluid Cx and gram stain: No growth. No 
microorganisms.
___: Blood culture: 

IMAGING
-------

___ CXR: No acute cardiopulmonary process.  Biapical streaky 
opacities. Recommend PA and lateral views for further evaluation 
prior to discharge. 

___ KUB: Dilated loops of small bowel are consistent with 
partial small bowel obstruction.  There is a visualized 
narrowing (due to stricture?) of the distal neo-terminal ileum.

___ EGD: Nodularity and edema in the gastroesophageal 
junction (biopsy). Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the 
duodenum

___ CT Chest w/ contrast: 1.  Upper and lower lobe pneumonia 
with an adjacent moderate right pleural effusion and reactive 
lymphadenopathy.  2.  Bilateral segmental pulmonary emboli.  3.  
Moderate emphysematous changes.  4.  Small left pleural 
effusion. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with past medical history 
including Crohns disease, atrial fibrillation on aspirin, COPD, 
CAD complicated by MI, and CHF who presented with 3 days of 
abdominal pain and was found to have enteric fistula, partial 
SBO, as well as a segmental right lower lobe PE on ab/pelvis CT 
with  DVTs found on subsequent lower extremity ultrasound. Found 
significant RUL pneumonia on CXR on ___ and aggressively 
treated with broad-spectrum empiric therapy antibiotics and 
chest tube to drain a right-sided transudative pleural effusion. 
He had several episodes of respiratory distress, and had two 
admissions to the medical ICU. Despite bronchoscopy, no pathogen 
was identified. Additionally, he was in a fib with RVR 
intermittently which was difficult to control however responded 
to diltiazem, metoporol, and digoxin. Given his long course with 
minimal improvement, he was made DNR/DNI on ___. He continued 
to desat and require high amounts of O2 and suctioning. His 
family was notified and he was made CMO. The family and patient 
requested to remove the NRB and oxyngen masks as they were 
uncomfortable. A morphine drip was started in the early morning 
of ___ for comfort. He continued to progressively desat to 
the ___ without oxygen and died on ___.  
  

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
2. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 
hold for SBP<100, HR<60 
3. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
hold for SBP<100 
4. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO DAILY 
Hold for K > 
5. Cardizem CD *NF* 300 mg Oral daily 
hold for SBP<100, HR<60 
6. Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY 
7. PredniSONE Dose is Unknown  PO DAILY 
8. Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q4H:PRN SOB 
9. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
10. Acyclovir 400 mg PO 5X/D 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Deceased- Respiratory failure 
 
Discharge Condition:
Deceased
 
                             ___ MD ___
 
Completed by: ___

Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Dapsone / Sustiva / Sulfa (Sulfonamides)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"I feel like I'm having a nervous breakdown"
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with HIV (CD4 reportedly >500 
and VL reportedly undetectable 7 months ago; no OI history; on 
HAART) and depression who presented to the ___ ED for 
evaluation due to several months of worsening fatigue and weight 
loss as well as recent suicidal ideation. He was formerly 
followed by Dr. ___ his HIV but moved to ___ in 
___. Because of these recent symptoms, he has come to ___ to 
be evaluated by Dr. ___ was planning on trying to get an 
appointment for ___, but felt he couldn't wait any longer). 
He says that he has had gradually worsening malaise and a 15 lbs 
weight loss over the past 3 months. He has had frequent, new 
nighttime bifrontal headaches without any neck stiffness or 
photophobia. He has also had new numbness and tingling in both 
hands and feet. He has been travelling around frequently to ___, ___, and ___. He denies any fevers, chills, or 
arthralgias. He has had mild myalgias and calf cramping. He has 
had mild sweating at night over the past few weeks. His appetite 
has been normal. He also reports having intermittent loose 
stools for several weeks now without any blood; he is having 
approximately 6 BMs per day, usually at least 3 are loose. He 
was in ___ yesterday and said that he ___ getting so depressed 
that he felt like jumping off of a highrise that he was staying 
in. Because of this, he and his partner came to ___ to be 
seen at ___. He reports that he has been drinking "too much" 
recently (at least a bottle of wine daily, sometimes with 
vodka), though he hasn't had a drink in two days. He has also 
been taking non-prescribed Xanax and Ritalin because of his 
depression.  
.  
He says that his symptoms make him think that his ARVs are no 
longer working and that his CD4 count is low. He has been 
compliant with his meds.  
.  
In the ED, he was afebrile with normal vital signs. A head CT 
and CXR were normal.  

 
Past Medical History:
# HIV diagnosed in ___, on HAART, no OIs, CD4 count never <200; 
CD4 count reportedly >500 7 months ago, VL reportedly 
undetectable at that time too  
# depression  
# EtOH abuse
# h/o IVDU in ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory 
 
Physical Exam:
T 96.4 BP 122/70 HR 56 RR 18 Sat 97% on room air  
General: well-appearing, mildly anxious middle-aged man in NAD  
HEENT: no icterus, OP clear  
Neck: supple, no LAD, no meningismus  
Chest: CTA b/l, no w/r/r  
CV: rrr, nl s1s2, no m/r/g  
Abdomen: soft, NTND, nl BS, no HSM  
Extremities: warm, 2+ ___ pulses, no edema  
Skin: no rashes or jaundiec  
Neuro: alert, orient x3, ___ strength in all extremities except 
4+/5 left ankle dorsiflexion, CN ___ intact  

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS
.
CBCs:
___ WBC-3.0* RBC-4.97 Hgb-15.7 Hct-44.6 MCV-90# MCH-31.5 
MCHC-35.1* RDW-13.3 Plt ___ Neuts-72.3* Lymphs-20.5 
Monos-6.0 Eos-1.0 Baso-0.1
___ WBC-2.5* RBC-5.13 Hgb-16.1 Hct-46.1 MCV-90 MCH-31.4 
MCHC-35.0 RDW-13.3 Plt ___
.
CHEM:
___ Glucose-119* UreaN-17 Creat-0.9 Na-142 K-3.8 Cl-104 HCO3-28 
AnGap-14 Calcium-9.3 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.0
___ Glucose-119* UreaN-17 Creat-0.9 Na-142 K-3.8 Cl-104 HCO3-28 
AnGap-14
.
ALT-38 AST-38 AlkPhos-88 TotBili-0.8
.
Serum Tox:
ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG 
Tricycl-NEG
.
TSH-1.3
VitB12- 258
.
DIFFERENTIAL:
Abs ___ CD3%-85 Abs CD3-537* CD4%-25 Abs CD4-160* CD8%-58 
Abs CD8-366 CD4/CD8-0.4*
.
HIV GENOTYPING-PND
.
___ 8:05 pm URINE     Site: NOT SPECIFIED

                            **FINAL REPORT ___

   URINE CULTURE (Final ___: 
      MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT 
WITH SKIN
      AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. 
.
___ 10:01 am SEROLOGY/BLOOD      Source: Venipuncture. 

                            **FINAL REPORT ___

   RAPID PLASMA REAGIN TEST (Final ___: 
      NONREACTIVE. 
      Reference Range: Non-Reactive. 
.
___ 9:43 am STOOL     CONSISTENCY: FORMED      Source: 
Stool. 

                            **FINAL REPORT ___

   CYCLOSPORA STAIN (Final ___:    NO CYCLOSPORA SEEN. 

   Cryptosporidium/Giardia (DFA) (Final ___: 
      NO CRYPTOSPORIDIUM OR GIARDIA SEEN. 
___
CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST
IMPRESSION:
1. No acute intracranial abnormality, or evidence of 
space-occupying lesion.

2. Acute-on-chronic inflammatory changes involving the left 
maxillary sinus, as on the ___ MR study.
.
___
CHEST (PA & LAT)
FINDINGS: Two views with no comparisons on record. The lungs are 
well- inflated and clear. The cardiomediastinal silhouette and 
pulmonary vessels are within normal limits with no pleural 
effusion or evidence of central adenopathy. The regional 
skeleton is unremarkable.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with HIV presenting with weight loss, anorexia, 
paresthesias, as well as suicidal ideation.  
.  
# Suicidality: Denied active SI, but endorsed SI as ecently as 
previous week. This is what prompted him to come to ___ for 
reinstitution of HIV care. He stated that just the act of coming 
up to ___ has been therapeutic for him and he was feeling 
much better. Psychiatry was consulted and recommended 
discontinuing 1:1 sitter. Also recommended beginning Cymbalta. 
Given prn seroquel for instances of extreme anxiety. Per psych 
recs he was set up with ID social work followup for the day 
after discharge.
.
# HIV - pt stated he had been taking his HAART regimen very 
inconsistently. A CD4 count and HIV genotype were sent which 
were pending at time of d/c (note: CD4 count subsequently came 
back at 160). Dr. ___ on pt and accepted ___ back 
into outpatient clinic for followup, which was arranged for the 
day of discharge. We did not change his current HAART regimen of 
nevirapine and lamivudine.
.
# L foot "neuropathy" -  Seemed that exam findings were somewhat 
related to effort, but nonetheless checked TFTs, B12, RPR. All 
were normal or negative. Unlikely to be related to current HAART 
regimen per ID.
.
# Polysubstance abuse - Reports alcohol abuse recently. Last 
drink was ___ ___. Also recent non-prescribed xanax and 
ritalin. Covered with ativan per CIWA scale with checks q2h. No 
evidence of withdrawal was seen.
.
# Diarrhea - none in house. Stool sent for Giardia, Crypto, esp 
given recent travel. These returned negative.  
.
# FEN: ate a regular diet  
.
# DVT prophylaxis: pt was ambulatory  
.
# Code: full  
 
Medications on Admission:
nevirapine 200 mg bid  
lamivudine 300 mg daily  
recently taking ___ of a xanax and ritalin daily", 
non-prescribed
prn ambien
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Zolpidem 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) 
as needed for insomnia.  
2. Nevirapine 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
3. Lamivudine 150 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. Citalopram 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Seroquel 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day as 
needed for insomnia or anxiety.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
HIV infection
.
Secondary:
Depression/Anxiety
Polysubstance abuse

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, not a risk to himself or others, cleared by psychiatry

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for weight loss, anxiety, and 
thoughts of suicide. You were seen by our psychiatrists who 
recommended starting an antidepresant called Celexa. They are 
also giving youa pill called Seroquel to take in case you are 
very anxious. They would like you to follow up with social 
workers at the infectious disease clinic.
.
You were also seen by our infectious disease team including Dr. 
___. You should followup with him after discharge.
.
Please keep your outpatient appointments. Please take all your 
medicines as prescribed. If you experience any further symptoms 
which concern you, including thoughts of causing harm to 
yourself or others, please call your doctor as soon as possible.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Exploratory laparotomy.
2. Enterotomy with removal of gallstone.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old male with a 3 day history of abdominl 
pain, nausea, and vomiting. He presented to ___ and 
was found to have a gallstone ileus with a small bowel 
obstruction. He was transferred here for further care. He 
reported no fever or chills. His last BM was 3 days ago.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Atrial fibrillation, CAD s/p MI, CHF, Prostate CA s/p XRT  
PSH: Right arm surgery for fracture  

 
Social History:
Lives alone, wife died ___ years ago. Has family in the area.

 
Physical Exam:
99.1, 98.9, 72, 121/64, 22, 100% RA
Gen: A+O x 3, NGT in place.
CV: RRR, no bruits
Chest: CTA bilat
Abd: +BS, obese, Nontender, - ___ sign, no peritoneal 
signs.
rectal: guiac negative
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:45PM BLOOD WBC-15.4* RBC-4.29* Hgb-13.7* Hct-38.3* 
MCV-89 MCH-31.9 MCHC-35.7* RDW-13.6 Plt ___
___ 09:55AM BLOOD WBC-10.3 RBC-3.51* Hgb-11.2* Hct-32.6* 
MCV-93 MCH-31.9 MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.7 Plt ___
___ 09:55AM BLOOD Glucose-131* UreaN-24* Creat-1.2 Na-140 
K-4.0 Cl-106 HCO3-26 AnGap-12
___ 06:45PM BLOOD ALT-30 AST-29 LD(LDH)-251* AlkPhos-67 
TotBili-0.8 DirBili-0.2 IndBili-0.6
___ 06:50AM BLOOD ALT-25 AST-22 AlkPhos-60 Amylase-18 
TotBili-0.8 DirBili-0.2 IndBili-0.6
___ 06:50AM BLOOD Lipase-11
___ 09:55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-2.0* Mg-2.3
___ 06:50AM BLOOD Digoxin-0.3*
.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old male who presented to ___ and 
was found to have gallstone pancreatitis. Imaging including a 
CAT scan, which demonstrated a stone in the distal ileum with 
bowel obstruction behind it in and a transition point in that 
area. There was also pneumobilia in the hepatic biliary tree

He was admitted and was NPO, IVF and a NGT in place. He was 
started on Levofloxacin and Flagyl.

Gallstone Ileus: He went to the OR on ___ for:
1. Exploratory laparotomy.
2. Enterotomy with removal of gallstone.

He remained NPO with a NGT in place. The NGT was removed on POD 
2. He was started on clears on POD 4. His diet was advanced as 
he had return of bowel function.
His incision was C/D/I with staples in place. The staples were 
removed and steri strips placed.

Chronic diastolic heart failure: He continued on his home 
medications and was stable throughout. His digoxin level was 
subtherapeutic at 0.3. Dr. ___ was OK with this as he did 
not want to approach toxicity levels.

Atrial fibrillation: He was on chronic Coumadin for A-fib. His 
INR was monitored and Coumadin restarted on POD 3. I spoke with 
his cardiologist, Dr. ___ ___, on ___ 
___ and he informed me that it was OK to stop his Warfarin.
 
Medications on Admission:
Coreg 6.25'', Zestril 5', Coumadin 2', Lasix 40', Digoxin 0.125' 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Carvedilol 6.25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
2. Digoxin 125 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

3. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

4. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
5. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One 
(1) Tablet Sustained Release PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
___ Diagnosis:
Abdominal Pain

 
Discharge Condition:
good, tolerating a diet, incision C/D/I, pain well controlled.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please follow-up with your PCP ___. ___ 
regarding a work-up for your pancreatic cyst.

H0ME MEDICATION: We have stopped your **COUMADIN (BLOOD 
THINNER)**(this has been approved by your PCP). Do not take your 
COUMADIN at home unless directed to by your PCP. Please continue 
taking all of your other home medications as directed.

DIET: Please continue a Soft Consistency (dysphagia) and Thin 
liquid diet,unless your PCP instructs you to advance your diet.

Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
* Continue to eat several small meals throughout the day. 
* You may shower and wash your incision. Keep clean and dry.
* No heavy lifting >10 lbs for ___ weeks.
* No driving or operating machinery while taking strong pain 
medication. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

medications and was stable throughout. His digoxin level was
subtherapeutic at 0.3. Dr. ___ was OK with this as he did
not want to approach toxicity levels.
Atrial fibrillation: He was on chronic Coumadin for A-fib. His
INR was monitored and Coumadin restarted on POD 3. I spoke with
his cardiologist, Dr. ___ ___, on ___
___ and he informed me that it was OK to stop his Warfarin.
Medications on Admission:
Coreg 6.25'', Zestril 5', Coumadin 2', Lasix 40', Digoxin 0.125'
Discharge Medications:
1. Carvedilol 6.25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times
a day).
2. Digoxin 125 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
3. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
4. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
5. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One
(1) Tablet Sustained Release PO once a day.
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___
___ Diagnosis:
Abdominal Pain
Discharge Condition:
good, tolerating a diet, incision C/D/I, pain well controlled.
Discharge Instructions:
Please follow-up with your PCP ___. ___
regarding a work-up for your pancreatic cyst.
H0ME MEDICATION: We have stopped your **COUMADIN (BLOOD
THINNER)**(this has been approved by your PCP). Do not take your
COUMADIN at home unless directed to by your PCP. Please continue
taking all of your other home medications as directed.
DIET: Please continue a Soft Consistency (dysphagia) and Thin
liquid diet,unless your PCP instructs you to advance your diet.
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid
heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a
bowel movement.
* Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
* Continue to eat several small meals throughout the day.
* You may shower and wash your incision. Keep clean and dry.
* No heavy lifting >10 lbs for ___ weeks.
* No driving or operating machinery while taking strong pain
medication.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cardiac catheterization - ___
 
History of Present Illness:
___ F with history of HTN, dCHF, severe AS, HLD who presented 
initially to ___ from ___ office with complaint of chest 
pressure anteriorly. She described it as substernal, constant 
since last night. She felt exhausted and lightheaded and also 
had some diarrhea last night. Also noticed some numbness in her 
right leg whihc comes and goes. Was found to have EKG changes at 
the ___ ___.  She had no prior cardiac history.  Had been 
seen last week at ___ ED and ruled out with -ve sets after 
"strained muscle in her chest moving her arm". A CTA of the 
chest showed mild emphysema, but no evidence of PE.  
.
In ___, initial VS were 97.8, HR 109, BP 121/84, RR 
22, 02 sat 78% and pain ___. In ED she was noted to have an o2 
sat of 80% and was lightheaded. Found to be guaiac positive. She 
got ASA and was started on a heaprin gtt (w/o bolus). 
Transferred from ___ for STEMI.  IN cath lab,  they went in 
through the lt radial huge and found a thrombus in lcx, mild 
right disease. She got 600 plavix after cath, bival, bms in lcx, 
and had a hematoma in lt radial. Transferred to CCU after 
procedure. 

 
Past Medical History:
HTN
HL
dCHF
Severe AS
GERD
Osteoprosis:  Pseudoclaudication, likely because of spinal 
stenosis, history of falls and shoulder injury, s/p ORIF right 
patellar fracture ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On transfer to CCU
VS: 98.4, 103, 131/87, 19, 90% on NRB
GENERAL: NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or 
S4.  
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.  
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. 
NEURO: AAOx3, CNII-XII intact, ___ strength biceps, triceps, 
wrist, knee/hip flexors/extensors, 2+ reflexes biceps, 
brachioradialis, patellar, ankle. 
PULSES:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:22PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-___*
___ 05:22PM BLOOD CK-MB-114* MB Indx-6.2* cTropnT-5.97*

Cardiac Cath (___)
1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system 
demonstrated one vessel disease. The LMCA had no 
angiographically 
apparent disease. The LAD had a ___ mid vessel stenosis. The 
Cx had a 
100% mid vessel thrombotic occlusion. The RCA had a ___ mid 
vessel 
stenosis. 
2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed a central aortic 
pressure of 
132.86 mmHg. 
3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid Cx with a 2.25x8mm 
INTEGRITY 
stent which was postdilated to 2.75mm. Final angiography 
revealed no 
residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and 
TIMI II 
to III flow (see ___ comments). 
  
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
1. One vessel coronary artery disease. 
2. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid Cx woth a BMS. 

Bedside TTE (___)
Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed 
(LVEF= 15X %). with depressed free wall contractility. The 
number of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. The aortic 
valve leaflets are moderately thickened. The mitral valve 
leaflets are structurally normal. Moderate to severe (3+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. There is a trivial/physiologic 
pericardial effusion. 

CXR (___)
Wide spread bilateral dense reticular opacities with relative 
left lower lung and right mid lung sparing, likely representing 
flash pulmonary edema due to acute cardiac decompensation in the 
setting of ischemia/infarct. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ F with history of HTN, dCHF, severe AS, HLD who presented 
from ___ with chest pain due to STEMI
.
#. STEMI/CAD - EKG at ___ concerning for STEMI, transferred 
here for cardiac cath.  Pt went straight to cath lab, was found 
have an occluded LCX, and had a BMS deployed with good 
restoration of flow.  She had no previous history of coronary 
artery disease and a recent echo did not show any evidence of 
wall motion abnormality or significant valvular disease.  
Arrived to CCU for further observation following procedure.  She 
shortly thereafter developed worsening oxygen requirement.  Stat 
CXR was performed which showed significant bilateral pulmonary 
edema, likely flash pulmonary edema from acute cardiac 
decompensation.  Patient had initially said that she did not 
want to be intubated, but wanted to have cardiac resuscitation.  
Upon seeing CXR results, her son/HCP was immediately called to 
discuss new findings and what this might represent.  In light of 
the fact that she had just undergone cardiac cath, the thought 
that what was going on was likely ___ her STEMI and potentially 
reversible if we pursued intubation and aggressive diuresis.  
Code status was reversed from DNI to full code.  As patient's 
respiratory status worsened, she became more bradycardic and 
more hypotensive.  Anesthesia was called for elective 
intubation, however patient quickly became hemodynamically 
stable.  Dopamine, then levophed were started peripherally as 
patient did not have central access.  Stat bedside TTE was 
performed to evaluate valves as she just had STEMI.  Mitral 
valve was widely regurgitant, which is acutely changed from the 
TTE she had at ___ a few weeks ago.  Patient continued to 
become more bradycardic, transcutaneous pacing was started.  
Hemodynamics and respiratory status worsened.  Code blue was 
called.  On holding transcutaneous pacing, patient was shown to 
be in PEA arrest.  Patient was coded with CPR, a total of 5 
rounds of epinephrine, 3 rounds of atropine, 2 rounds of bicarb, 
1 round of vasopressin.  CCU and interventional attending was 
called, decision was made not to bring patient back to the cath 
lab.  Pulse could not be recovered at any point during the code. 
 After 14 minutes, decision was made to stop code.  Time of 
death was 9:04 ___ on ___.  Family was present and updated 
by the CCU team, they declined autopsy.  Medical examiner waived 
autopsy as well.
 
Medications on Admission:
- Dilt SR 180 qd
- Zetia 10 qd
- VitA-VitC-VitE-Min qd
- Ca-citrate 2g qd
- Brimonidine eye drops BID 
- Latanoprost eye drops 
- lasix 20 qd
- Diovan 160 qd
- Simvastatin 40
- Ranitidine 150 BID 
 
Discharge Medications:
patient expired
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
STEMI
 
Discharge Condition:
Patient expired
 
Discharge Instructions:
Patient expired
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left kidney tumor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with left 6 cm renal mass, bilateral renal cysts, on 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Atrial fibrillation, CAD s/p MI, CHF, Prostate CA s/p XRT  
PSH: Right arm surgery for fracture  

 
Social History:
Lives alone, wife died ___ years ago. Has family in the area.

 
Physical Exam:
General: comfortable
Abd: soft, non tender, non distended
Incisions: clean, dry, intact; no signs of infection
Voids: clear yellow urine

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to Urology after undergoing 
laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the 
PACU in stable condition.  On POD0, pain was well controlled on 
PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and 
ambulated once. On POD1, the patient was restarted on home 
medications (except coumadin, lasix, and lisinopril), basic 
metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain 
control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was 
advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and 
urethral catheter (foley) were removed without difficulty and 
diet was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital 
course was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged 
in stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, 
voiding without difficulty, and with pain control on oral 
analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with 
no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was 
given explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. 
___ in 3 weeks.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Kidney cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your incision. 


-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids. 

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by Dr. ___ in follow-up.  

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics.  

-Resume all of your home medications. Restart coumadin this 
___.

-Call Dr. ___ today to schedule a follow-up 
appointment in 3 weeks AND if you have any questions.  

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest ER.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Demerol / shellfish derived
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
CBD Stones s/p ERCP
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ERCP with sphincteroplasty and stone removal
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PMH of cholecystectomy and ERCP w/CBD stone in ___, as 
well as anemia, colonic adenomas, and a herniated disc, now 
admitted for observation following an ERCP with sphincteroplasty 
and stone removal. Patient was in her usual state of health 
until 3 weeks ago when she developed intermittent, severe 
epigastric pain. Work-up by GI with MRCP showed a 4mm CBD stone, 
for which she was referred to ERCP. On the day of admission she 
underwent an ERCP with sphincteroplasty and removal of several 
CBD stones. Following the procedure she developed severe 
epigastric pain that radiated to the back. For this reason she 
was admitted to the general medicine service for observation 
overnight. 

Currently she reports good response to the Dilaudid she 
received, with ___ pain. She otherwise feels well and denies 
fevers, chills, chest pain, or shortness of breath. 
 
ROS: 10 point review of systems performed and negative except as 
noted.  
 
Past Medical History:
CCY ___
CBD stones ___ s/p ERCP
Anemia
Colonic adenomas
Herniated disc
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother has a history of gallstones s/p CCY
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: Awake, alert, NAD, mother and father at bedside  
HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, anicteric  
CV: RR, no m/r/g  
Pulm: CTA B  
Abd: Soft, very mildly TTP in epigastrium, positive bowel sounds 
 
Ext: No edema or calf tenderness  
Psych: Affect appropriate, good insight into own health  
Neuro: Speech fluent 

Discharge Exam:
Well-appearing
Abdomen soft, NTND 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:20AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-3.66* Hgb-11.3* Hct-34.2* 
MCV-94 MCH-30.8 MCHC-32.9 RDW-12.9 Plt ___
___ 09:20AM BLOOD UreaN-17 Creat-0.6 Na-138 K-3.9 Cl-102 
HCO3-29 AnGap-11
___ 09:20AM BLOOD ALT-140* AST-79* AlkPhos-89 TotBili-0.4 
DirBili-0.1 IndBili-0.3
___ 09:20AM BLOOD Lipase-27

Discharge Labs:

___ 05:25AM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-8 Creat-0.5 Na-140 K-3.8 
Cl-105 HCO3-29 AnGap-___ctive Issues:
1. CBD stones s/p ERCP: Patient treated supportively with NPO, 
IVF, Dilaudid and Zofran. Diet advanced in the morning without 
difficulty. LFT's should be re-checked as an outpatient to 
ensure they return to normal.

Chronic Issues:
1. Colonic adenomas: Next colonoscopy due in one year.

2. Anemia: Chronic, mild, stable. Further work-up per PCP.
 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications

 
Discharge Medications:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Common bile duct stones s/p ERCP
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for observation following your 
ERCP. Your pain improved overnight and you were able to advance 
your diet without difficulty. Please maintain a low-fat diet for 
___ days as you continue to recover.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___         ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
history of colon cancer and positive ___ mutation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
total laparoscopic hysterectomy
bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
cystoscopy
 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ G1, P1 with a history of colon 
cancer treated with right colectomy in ___.  She did not 
receive any adjuvant therapy and has been disease-free since 
then.  Her family history is significant for a maternal uncle 
with colon cancer and a father who had metastatic colon cancer.  
She was found to have a deleterious mutation in ___.  Because 
of this, she has elected to undergo prophylactic hysterectomy 
and BSO.  She has completed her childbearing and is now 
perimenopausal.  She is oligomenorrheic. 
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Significant for hypertension.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Right colectomy.

OB HISTORY:  Vaginal delivery x1.

GYN HISTORY:  Last Pap smear was in ___ and normal, last
mammogram in ___.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Significant for colon cancer in maternal uncle and a father who 
had metastatic colon cancer. 
 
Physical Exam:
GENERAL APPEARANCE:  Well developed, well nourished.
HEENT:  Sclerae anicteric.
LYMPHATICS:  Lymph node survey was negative.
LUNGS:  Clear to auscultation.
HEART:  Regular without murmurs.
ABDOMEN:  Soft and nondistended and without palpable masses.  
There was a well-healed vertical midline incision with no 
evidence of hernia.
EXTREMITIES:  Without edema.
PELVIC:  The vulva and vagina were normal.  The cervix was 
normal.  Bimanual and rectovaginal examination revealed a normal 
cervix and uterus with no palpable adnexal masses.  There was no 
cul-de-sac nodularity and the rectal was intrinsically normal.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ was admitted after total laparoscopic hysterectomy and 
bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for history of colon cancer and 
MSH6 mutation.  She received routine post-op care and was 
discharged home in good condition on POD#1.  
 
Medications on Admission:
HCTZ
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4-6H () as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
history of colon cancer
___ mutation
 
Discharge Condition:
good
 
Discharge Instructions:
- Please call your doctor if you experience fever > 100.4, 
chills, nausea and vomiting, worsening or severe abdominal pain, 
heavy vaginal bleeding, chest pain, trouble breathing, or if you 
have any other questions or concerns.  Please call if you have 
redness and warmth around the incision, if your incision is 
draining pus-like material, or if your incision reopens.
- No driving for two weeks and while taking narcotic pain 
medication as it can make you drowsy.
- No heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 4 weeks to allow 
your incision to heal adequately. 
- Nothing per vagina (no tampons, intercourse, douching for 6 
weeks.
- Please keep your follow-up appointments as outlined below.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

cancer and HNPCC (___ mutation).  She has had some 
serosanguinous, non-foul discharge since her surgery, but last 
night at 11pm began having bright red bleeding.  She has since
soaked through 3 pads, and passed a baseball-sized and a 
plum-sized clot.  No dizziness or lightheadedness with 
ambulation.  No fever/chills, foul or purulent discharge, or 
significant abdominal pain, no abdominal distention.  Tolerating 
regular diet, no N/V.  

 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Significant for hypertension.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Right colectomy.

mammogram in ___.

___
Family History:
Significant for colon cancer in maternal uncle and a father who 
had metastatic colon cancer. 
 
Physical Exam:
97.9  93  142/90  18  
NAD - ambulating without difficulty
Abd obese, soft, ND, non-tender, no rebound/guarding
Incisions healing well, no erythema/exudate
SSE: Clot removed from vault, BRB oozing from vaginal cuff,
predominantly along medial and left aspect of cuff.  The cuff 
was
very gently probed with a small sterile q-tip, and felt to be
intact.  Monsel's solution was placed, with some improvement but
some slow oozing still.  Surgicel placed against the cuff, and
Betadyne soaked sterile vaginal packing placed.  Total EBL for
procedure 50 cc. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:43AM   PLT COUNT-423
___ 03:43AM   WBC-11.7*# RBC-4.34 HGB-12.8 HCT-35.3* 
MCV-81* MCH-29.5 MCHC-36.3* RDW-12.5
___ 12:50PM   HCT-34.1*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ G1P1 ___ s/p prophylactic TLH-BSO for HNPCC/colon 
cancer, admitted to the gyn oncology team for observation in the 
setting of bleeding from the vaginal cuff. Vaginal pack with 
surgicell was applied in gyn triage. Patient was monitored 
overnight. Her hematocrit remained stable. She did not have any 
more vaginal bleeding. Patient felt comfortable removing the 
vaginal packing by herself and was discharged with a plan to 
self-remove the packing in 24 hours. She was instructed to 
monitor for signs of bleeding. 

 
Medications on Admission:
HCTZ, ibuprofen, percocet
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.  
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
bleeding from vaginal cuff, vaginal pack placed

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have been admitted for vaginal bleeding. There is a vaginal 
pack that was placed inside the vagina. It should be removed in 
___ hours (morning of ___. You may remove it 
yourself. Please monitor for bleeding and call your physician if 
you experience vaginal bleeding. 

Other symptoms of bleeding include but are not limited to ligght 
headedness, dizziness, chest pain, shortness of breath, 
difficulty voiding, loss of consiousness. if you experience any 
of these, please clal your physician. 

Call your physician if you experience temperature > 100.4

Do not drive while taking narcotics
 
Followup Instructions:
