Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was evaluated by the Acute care service in the 
Emergency Room and based on his physical exam and Abdominal CT 
he was taken to the Operating Room for  laparoscopic 
appendectomy.  He tolerated the procedure well and returned to 
the PACU in stable condition. he maintained stable hemodynamics 
and his pain was well controlled.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor he continued to make 
good progress.  His diet was slowly advanced to regular and he 
tolerated it well.  His pain was well controlled and his 
surgical sites were dry. He was up and walking independently and 
after an uncomplicated recovery he was discharged to home on 
___ and will follow up in the Acute Care Clinic in ___ 
weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute gangrenous appendicitis.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:

* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.  

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal 
exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

AST: 56 LDH:  Dbili:  TProt:  
___:  Lip: 57     

9.4>37.9<424 
  
N:68.2 L:20.7 M:7.7 E:2.2 Bas:1.3 

___: 16.4  PTT: 25.7  INR: 1.5

___ CT Abd/Pelvis
Three fluid collections with a thin enhancing rim. RLQ inferior 
to the cecum- 6.4 x 2. 4 cm, RLQ close to the ant abdominal wall 
4.6 x 1.8 cm 
Pelvis- two componenents of the collection measure 2.7 x 1.5 cm 
& 2.8 x 1.4 cm, this is closely apposed to the sigmoid, which 
contains multiple diverticulae No air pockets within the fluid 
collections. Stranding in the pelvis and RLQ with reactive 
mesenteric adenopathy. No bowel obstruction.  

___ CT guided drainage:
CT-guided attempted aspirations of the right lower quadrant 
collections. No aspirate was retrieved despite aggressive 
suctioning. No 
drainage catheters were left in place and no specimens were sent 
to 
microbiology.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service with low 
grade fevers and abdominal pain 5 days after undergoing 
laparoscopic appendectomy for gangrenous appendicitis.  He was 
found to have three small fluid collections.  On hospital day 2 
an attempt was made at ___ aspiration of the two largest 
fluid collections.  Despite multiple attempts aspiration was 
unsuccessful.  The plan then was to treat him with 2 weeks on 
antibiotics.  

Pain was well controlled and diet was advanced to regular 
post-procedure.  He remained afebrile and abdominal pain had 
improved.  At time of discharge his pain was well controlled, he 
was voiding spontaneously, tolerating a regular diet and 
ambulating.
 
Medications on Admission:
Cipro
Flagyl
Percocet

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
abdominal fluid collection s/p laparoscopic appendectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / ACE Inhibitors / amoxicillin / 
cephalexin / erythromycin base / hydralazine / Hytrin / Isordil 
/ levofloxacin / losartan / Macrobid / olmesartan / simvastatin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right knee pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ORIF Right distal femur ___ ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ presented with Right distal femur fracture.
 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Hypothyroidism
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
General: no acute distress
CV: well-perfused
Resp: non-labored
Abd: non-distended

RLE: brace in place, incisional dressing clean, dry, and intact; 
SILT distally, fires TA, ___, ___, EDL/FDL; warm and 
well-perfused
 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent lab/radiology data.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have Right distal femur fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for ORIF Right distal femur, which the 
patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please 
see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was 
taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after 
satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the 
floor. She received 2 units of PRBCs on the floor for immediate 
post-operative Hct of 19. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that 
discharge to rehab was appropriate. The ___ hospital 
course was otherwise unremarkable.

Of note, patient had poor PO intake and was refusing medications 
on POD1. This was further complicated by IV infiltration and 
several unsuccessful attempts to replace peripheral IV or draw 
blood for morning labs. It was decided that long-term access (at 
least until patient was discharged home) was the best course of 
action. A PICC was placed on ___. 

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
NWB in the right lower extremity in locked ___ w/ no ROM, 
and will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. TraMADol 50 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
2. Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY 
3. Ondansetron ODT 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea  
4. Metoprolol Tartrate 100 mg PO BID 
5. irbesartan 75 mg oral BID 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
Take for baseline pain control. 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours as 
needed Disp #*100 Tablet Refills:*1 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
This is a new medication to prevent post-operative constipation. 
Hold for diarrhea or loose stools. 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 2 capsule(s) by mouth twice daily 
Disp #*80 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY 
Take for 4 weeks post-operatively to prevent blood clots. 
RX *enoxaparin [Lovenox] 40 mg/0.4 mL 1 syringe subcutaneously 
daily Disp #*26 Syringe Refills:*0 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
Don't take before driving, operating machinery, or with alcohol. 

RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours as 
needed Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0 
5.  Senna 8.6 mg PO DAILY 
This is a new medication to prevent post-operative constipation. 
Hold for diarrhea or loose stools. 
RX *sennosides 8.6 mg 2 tablets by mouth every evening Disp #*40 
Tablet Refills:*0 
6.  irbesartan 75 mg oral BID  
7.  Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY  
8.  Metoprolol Tartrate 100 mg PO BID  
9.  Ondansetron ODT 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea   
10.  TraMADol 50 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Moderate  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right distal femur fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- NWB RLE in locked ___, no ROM

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks post-operatively.

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with Dr. ___ in the ___ Trauma 
Clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Please call 
___ to schedule appointment.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Physical Therapy:
TDWB RLE in locked ___, no ROM of Right knee
WBAT LLE (knee immobilizer provided for comfort when out of bed 
as patient has non-acute tibial plateau fracture--but bracing 
with immobilizer is not required)
NWB + ROMAT LUE 

Treatments Frequency:
Incision may be changed as needed. Please keep covered with dry 
sterile dressing and tape until follow-up. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Uncontrolled pain s/p Duputryen's surgery on ___
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None this admission

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M w longstanding h/o Duputryen's disease and multiple 
prior procedures who is ___ s/p left IF and RF fasciectomy for 
recurrent Duputryen's and presents to the ED w/ pain after the 
block wore off. Yesterday, he underwent an extensive resection 
including excision of skin on the RF and placement of integra. 
Both neurovascular bundles in both digits were dissected 
intraoperatively and preserved. He was discharged home with a 
splint and the pain became intolerable after the block wore off. 


 
Past Medical History:
___'s

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Alert, oriented, well appearing
L hand is in splint. Fingers are warm, with normal cap refill.
There is decreased sensation in the tip of both IF and RF. The 
ACE
wrap around the splint was removed, and a looser wrap was
replaced without change in his symptoms. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ for observation and treatment of uncontrolled pain s/p 
Duput___'s surgery. 
.
Neuro: The patient was admitted for pain control and started on 
Tylenol around the clock, toradol IV, dilaudid ___ po Q3H prn 
and IV dilaudid for breakthrough.  On hospital day #2, patient 
felt that the PO dilaudid was not holding him long enough and he 
was using IV dilaudid for breakthrough.  MS contin 15mg po Q12h 
was added to the regimen with patient report of good pain 
control.
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: The patient tolerated a regular diet and intake and 
output were closely monitored.
.
ID: The patient was maintained on PO keflex while inpatient and 
discharged to home with instructions to finish up the 
prescription for keflex that he was discharged home with. The 
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection.
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible.
.
At the time of discharge on Hospital day#2, the patient was 
doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a 
regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled.  Left hand remained in splint.
 
Medications on Admission:
Keflex
dilaudid 
toradol
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
RX *acetaminophen 325 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Cephalexin 500 mg PO Q6H 
3. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q3H 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nasuea 
RX *ondansetron 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours 
Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Morphine SR (MS ___ 15 mg PO Q12H

Home

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Dupuytren contracture of left hand with severe diathesis

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Right radial forearm free fascial flap to left palm and
    ring finger.
2. Revascularization right forearm with reverse cephalic
    vein graft.
3. Split-thickness skin to graft, left hypothenar eminence,
    left ring finger.
4. C-wire fixation, left ring finger x2.
5. Application of short-arm splint, bilateral.
6. End-to-side neurorrhaphy, left ring finger.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w longstanding h/o Du___'s disease and multiple prior 
procedures s/p left IF and RF fasciectomy for recurrent 
Duputryen's. The radical fasciectomy on ___ required removal of 
a significant amount of skin from the distal palm in the volar 
aspect of the ring finger. Neurovascular bundles were kept
anatomically intact. The patient is scheduled for vascularized 
fashion resurfacing to cover the hypothenar graft.
 
Past Medical History:
___'s

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
General: comfortable, NAD
Extremities: 
RUE: splint in place, SILT over ulnar/radial digital nerve 
distributions of all digits, FPL/EPL/DIO intact, good CR in all 
digits
LUR: splint in place, SILT over SILT over ulnar/radial digital 
nerve distributions of all digits, unable to test motor function 
___ splint, good CR in all digits
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had the following:
1. Right radial forearm free fascial flap to left palm and
    ring finger.
2. Revascularization right forearm with reverse cephalic
    vein graft.
3. Split-thickness skin to graft, left hypothenar eminence,
    left ring finger.
4. C-wire fixation, left ring finger x2.
5. Application of short-arm splint, bilateral.
6. End-to-side neurorrhaphy, left ring finger.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient had issues with pain 
control. He was switched to a regimen of MS ___, 
Tylenon, PO/IV dilaudid, which gave him good relief. He was able 
to be transition to PO pain medication with good relief by the 
time of discharge.  
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His/Her diet was advanced when 
appropriate, which was tolerated well. She was also started on a 
bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output 
were closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO Keflex for discharge home. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#3, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:

CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint;
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint;
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until
tolerating oral intake. His/Her diet was advanced when
appropriate, which was tolerated well. She was also started on a
bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output
were closely monitored.
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin,
then switched to PO Keflex for discharge home. The patient's
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection.
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate
as early as possible.
.
At the time of discharge on POD#3, the patient was doing well,
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet,
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled.

artery to left anterior descending artery, and saphenous vein 
graft to distal right coronary artery and diagonal arteries
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history diabetes 
mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Over the past six 
months he has noted left sided heaviness with exertion such as 
walking up an incline. Earlier this month, he had an episode of 
hypertension associated with headache and left chest heaviness 
at rest. Blood pressure on his home sphygmomanometer was 
190/105. He contacted his primary care provider and was 
instructed to report to the emergency department. At ___ 
___, he ruled out for myocardial infarction by enzymes. He 
was referred for a stress test which was markedly abnormal. He 
developed chest pain associated with ST depressions that 
persisted late into recovery. A cardiac catheterization 
demonstrated severe three-vessel atherosclerosis, with diffuse 
disease not amenable to PCI. He was referred to Dr. ___ 
consideration of surgical revascularization in ___ and now 
presents for preadmission testing for surgery ___.
He stated that in addition to chest heaviness, he has also noted 
palpitations. He otherwise denied syncope, dizziness, 
lightheadedness, shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, 
orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or lower extremity 
edema.
 
Past Medical History:
Adhesive capsulitis s/p cortisone injection
Coronary Artery Disease
Diabetes mellitus 
Erectile Dysfunction
Hyperlipidemia
Hypertension
Kidney Stones
Neuropathy
Proteinuria

___
Family History:
Grandfather - history of myocardial infarction in his late ___

2.21 m2

Skin: Warm, dry, intact

Neck: Supple, full ROM

Neuro: Grossly intact

Carotid Bruit:  None appreciated
 
Pertinent Results:
___ Echo: Pre-CPB: No spontaneous echo contrast is seen in 
the left atrial appendage. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). Right ventricular chamber 
size and free wall motion are normal. There are simple atheroma 
in the descending thoracic aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (3) 
appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no 
aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 
Post-CPB: The patient is paced, on no inotropes. Unchanged 
biventricular systolic fxn. Trace MR, no AI. Aorta intact.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was a same day admit and on ___ he was brought 
directly to the operating room where he underwent a coronary 
artery bypass graft x 3. Please see operative note for surgical 
details. Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for 
invasive monitoring. Later this day he was weaned from sedation, 
awoke neurologically intact and extubated. He developed rapid 
afib his first post-op night and was started on amiodarone gtt 
and transitioned to oral dosing. Returned to ___ within couple of 
hours and has remain in SR. He stayed in unit due to 
hyperglycemia but was eventually transitioned off the insulin 
gtt to his home dose of lantus and glucophage. He transferred to 
the floor. His pacing wires and chest tubes were removed. He was 
noted to have a small left pneumothorac on post pull CXR that 
remained stable. He was started on lopressor and lasix. He 
continue to do well. He was seen by the physical therapy 
department and deemed safe for dishcarge. His lasix was 
discontinued at discharge as he is below his pre-op weight and 
without edema. He was seen by the nutritionist to help with meal 
planning. All patient questions and concerns addressed. All 
follow-up appointments arranged. He was discharged to home on 
POD#4 in stable condition.

Simvastatin 80 mg tablet Qpm

6. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
to be increased back to 80mg daily once amiodarone discontinued

hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

every four (4) hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0

Do Not Crush

mouth daily Disp #*30 Packet Refills:*0

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

Coronary Artery Disease s/p Coronary artery bypass graft x 3

Adhesive capsulitis s/p cortisone injection
Diabetes mellitus 
Erectile Dysfunction
Hyperlipidemia
Hypertension
Kidney Stones
Neuropathy
Proteinuria
 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and oriented x3 nonfocal 
Ambulating with steady gait
Incisional pain managed with Percocet
Incisions: 
Sternal - healing well, no erythema or drainage 
Leg Left - healing well, no erythema or drainage
Edema none

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please shower daily including washing incisions gently with mild 
soap, no baths or swimming until cleared by surgeon. Look at 
your incisions daily for redness or drainage
Please NO lotions, cream, powder, or ointments to incisions

**Please call cardiac surgery office with any questions or 
concerns ___. Answering service will contact on call 
person during off hours**

___ yo F on alendronate for osteoporosis presents to the ED w/ Rt
thigh pain and Rt subtrochanteric femur fracture after bending
over to pull off sock last night. While bending over she felt
sudden onset of pain and has not been able to ambulate without
severe pain since then.  She has minimal pain at rest and with
ROM of hips, knees.
 
Past Medical History:
HTN
osteoporosis

vein graft

asthma

LLE: SILT, motor intact. pulses 2+

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ presented to the ___ on ___ after a pain in her 
right hip after bending over to pull up a sock. She was 
evaluated by the orthopaedic surgery service 
and found to a right subtrochanteric stress fracture.  She was 
admitted, 
consented, and prepped for surgery.  ___ he was taken to 
the operating room and underwent aright TFN.  She tolerated the 
procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery room, 
and then to the floor.  On the 
floor she was seen by physical therapy to improve her strength 
and mobility.  

The rest of her hospital stay was uneventful with her lab data 
and vital signs within normal limits and her pain controlled.  
She is being discharged today in stable condition.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. verapamil 120 mg Tablet Extended Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Extended Release PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
2. simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: Three (3) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. vitamin A 10,000 unit Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: Two (2) 
Spray Nasal DAILY (Daily).  
6. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
8. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
9. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
10. enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.
Disp:*30 * Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

Right subtrochanteric stress fracture from phosphomax

AAO X 3
Regular diet

Right lower extremity: Weight bear as tolerated

Bilateral upper extremities: WBAT

Pain: You have been prescribed a narcotic pain medication.  
Please take only as directed and do not drive or operate any 
machinery while taking this medication.  There is a 72 hour 
___ through ___, 9am to 4pm) response time for 
prescription refil requests.  There will be no prescription 
refils on ___, or holidays.  Please plan 
accordingly.    

Wound Care:
- Keep Incision clean and dry.
- Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.

Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet.
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing.
-If you have any increased redness, drainage, or swelling, or if 
you have a temperature greater than 101.5, please call the 
office or come to the emergency department.

RLE: WBAT

BUE: WBAT

Right hip surgical site: dry dressing change daily for 5 days 
after discharge.

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / progesterone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
EIN
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
s/p total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman seen in consultation for endometrial 
intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN). 

She has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding, which over the 
past one year has become worse. She reports that her periods 
used to be ___ days in duration, but in the last year have 
sometimes extended up to 10 days and become exceptionally heavy. 
She denies intermenstrual or post-coital bleeding.

Pelvic ultrasound ___ showed a bulky uterus measuring 10.3 x 
5.6 x 7.8 cm; with focal areas of irregularity possibly 
representing adenomyosis; one solitary myometrial fibroid;; a 
normal appearing endometrium measuring 11 mm; and no polyps.  
She underwent an endometrial biopsy on ___ that demonstrated
EIN/complex hyperplasia with atypia with focal squamous morule 
formation.

She endorses occasional right sided groin and back pain for the 
past ___ years, as well as urinary frequency. She reports 
unintentional weight gain of 20 pounds in the past ___ years, 
with no significant changes in diet or exercise. She denies 
constipation. 

She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, 
bloating, increased abdominal girth, early satiety, 
constipation, diarrhea, dysuria, or abnormal discharge. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH:
- Depression
- Generalized anxiety disorder
- Migraines
- Tinnitus
- Denies hypertension, diabetes, asthma, thromboembolic disease

PSH: 
- Wisdom teeth

POB: 
- G2P1011
- SVD, ___
- SAB, ___, spontaneous, no procedures

PGYN: 
- LMP ___
- Menses monthly, heavy flow lasting 10 days
- Endorses menorrhagia; had Mirena IUD placed ___ at time of
endometrial biopsy, which showed EIN
- Currently sexually active 
- Denies history of abnormal Pap smears
- Denies history of pelvic infections or sexually transmitted
infections
- Denies history of fibroids or cysts
- Current contraception: Mirena
- History of OCPs x ___ year
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- ___ cancer in maternal ___ cousin
- ___, endometriosis, fibroids in many female family
members
- Diabetes in father, maternal uncle
- HTN in father, mother, brother
- Heart condition in maternal grandmother, maternal uncle
- No known family history of uterine, ovarian, cervical or colon
cancer
- No known history of bleeding or clotting disorder
 
Physical Exam:
On day of discharge:
Afebrile, vitals stable
No acute distress
CV: regular rate and rhythm
Pulm: clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abd: soft, appropriately tender, nondistended, incisions 
clean/dry/intact, no rebound/guarding
___: nontender, nonedematous
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:54AM BLOOD WBC-10.4* RBC-3.27* Hgb-10.5* Hct-31.0* 
MCV-95 MCH-32.1* MCHC-33.9 RDW-12.7 RDWSD-44.0 Plt ___
___ 06:54AM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-10 Creat-0.6 Na-137 
K-3.8 Cl-106 HCO3-23 AnGap-12
___ 06:54AM BLOOD Calcium-8.9 Phos-3.2 Mg-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service 
after undergoing a total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral 
salpingectomy for ___. Please see the operative report for full 
details.  

Her post-operative course is detailed as follows. Immediately 
postoperatively, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid and 
toradol. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was 
transitioned to PO oxycdone, ibuprofen and tylenol for pain 
control. On post-operative day #1, her urine output was adequate 
so her Foley catheter was removed and she voided spontaneously. 

By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
Bupropion HCL
Citalopram
Clonazepam
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
pathology pending

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
.
You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after 
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well 
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be 
discharged home. Please follow these instructions: 
.   
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 8 
weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 4 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.
* It is safe to walk up stairs.   
.
Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* You should remove your port site dressings ___ days after your 
surgery. If you have steri-strips, leave them on. If they are 
still on after ___ days from surgery, you may remove them.  
.
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

gastrointestinal stomal tumor

___
Laparoscopic resection of gastrointestinal stomal tumor

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with GIST found on CT. patient presented for resection of 
GIST on ___
 
Past Medical History:
h/o diverticulitis, anxiety
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory 
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: NC/AT 
HEENT: PEERL 
Cor: RRR NL, S1, S2
Lungs: CTAB bilat 
Abd: Soft tender to deep palpation  
Ext: wwp bilat 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the trauma service and taken to the OR. 
Post-op pain was well controlled on IV pain medications. She was 
NPO overnight and advanced to a regular diet on POD1. Patient 
continued to do well, with pain well controlled. Patient stable 
for discharge on POD 2. 
 
Medications on Admission:
___: klonipin, prozac 20'
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain .
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Prozac 40 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Submucosal mass of the stomach,probable gastrointestinal stromal 
tumor.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status:Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness:Alert and interactive
Activity Status:Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.

 Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.  

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while
taking these medications.
Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you
have any of the following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) degrees or 38(C) degrees.

meds as ordered.

clean, dry gauze.

remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

nc

Well appearing in no acute distress

* Incision healing well with staples  
* Scant serosanguinous drainage  
* Thigh full but soft  
* No calf tenderness  
* ___ strength

* Toes warm  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:50AM BLOOD WBC-10.8 RBC-3.76* Hgb-12.2 Hct-37.3 
MCV-99* MCH-32.5* MCHC-32.8 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 06:25AM BLOOD WBC-14.2*# RBC-4.07* Hgb-12.9 Hct-39.0 
MCV-96 MCH-31.8 MCHC-33.2 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 06:25AM BLOOD Glucose-140* UreaN-15 Creat-0.7 Na-134 
K-4.1 Cl-100 HCO3-26 AnGap-12
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

******

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD *** and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.
 
Ms ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H:PRN SOB, wheezing 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right knee osteoarthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
recurrent diverticulitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman who has had multiple episodes 
of recurrent diverticulitis. The last episode was in early ___.  She has had several episodes this year and has multiple 
prior episodes, which have all resolved with antibiotic therapy. 
Colonoscopy in ___ showed diverticulosis in the sigmoid to the 
ascending colon.  Prior scans have shown the majority of the 
flares to be in the sigmoid colon. A recent CT scan showed 
diverticulitis in the
sigmoid colon with widespread diverticulosis. Ms. ___ 
presented to ___ for surgical management of her disease in 
order to prevent future recurrences of diverticulitis.

 
Past Medical History:
diverticulitis, anxiety, depression, C. diff colitis

*Surgical history: gastrointestinal stromal tumor s/p 
laparoscopic resection ___ right parotid tumor s/p resection 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory 
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T 97.3 HR 61 BP 104/62 RR 18 O2sat 96% RA
Gen: NAD
CV: RRR no n/r/g
Pulm: clear bilaterally
Abd: soft, tender to palpation at surgical sites, non-distended
Wound: c/d/i with steri-strips
Ext: warm, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:03PM   HCT-38.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient underwent laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy for 
recurrent diverticulitis on ___. Please see the operative 
report for further details. She tolerated the procedure well, 
was extubated in the operating room, and recovered in the PACU 
briefly before being transferred to the floor. 

* Neuro: Her pain was initially controlled with parenteral 
narcotics, and she was transitioned to oral narcotics 
supplemented with acetaminophen and ketorolac. She eventually 
stopped using narcotics secondary to "nightmares" and did not 
want to take narcotics as an outpatient. She was discharged with 
tylenol and ibuprofen and her pain was well controlled. Her 
anxiety was initially treated with lorazepam prior to starting 
her home dose of alprazolam. She was continued on her home dose 
of fluoxetine.
* CV: She remained stable during this hospitalization without 
issues
* Resp: She was easily weaned from supplemental oxygen therapy 
to room air and excellent oxygen saturations and no respiratory 
issues.
* GI: She was initially NPO and her diet was slowly advanced 
from clears until she was tolerating a regular diet at time of 
discharge. She was placed on a bowel regimen and at time of 
discharge was passing flatus. Her laparoscopic incisions were 
clean and in tact with steri-strips in place.
* GU: Her foley was removed post-operatively and she voided 
without difficulty
* Heme: The patient's hematocrit was stable during this 
hospitalization
* Derm: The patient developed an itchy rash on the evening of 
POD#1 that she reported she routinely gets. She was treated with 
benadryl with improvement of the itching
* Dispo: The patient was discharged home on ___ (POD#3) with 
prescriptions for pain and anxiety medications and instructions 
to follow-up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient.
 
 
Medications on Admission:
xanax, prozac 20'
 
Discharge Medications:
1. fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): hold for loose stools.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
3. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q 8H 
(Every 8 Hours).
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
4. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day for 1 weeks.
Disp:*21 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. alprazolam 1 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO at bedtime as 
needed for anxiety.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy
recurrent diverticulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call the surgery clinic or go to the Emergency Department for 
the following: Temperature greater than 101.4; increased 
redness, swelling, pain, or discharge from the incsion sites; 
inability to tolerate food or drink; bloody or black tarry 
stools; chest pain; shortness of breath; or any other concerns.

General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drink alcohol, drive, or operate heavy machinery while 
taking narcotic analgesic medications.  You may also take 
acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg 
in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous 
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 20 
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct 
you further regarding activity restrictions.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.
 
Incision Care:
*Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your surgeon.
*You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap and warm 
water.  Gently pat the area dry.
*Your steri-strips will fall off on their own
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal and back pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ ___ at 23'5 weeks by LMP c/w 7 wk US who presented
yesterday with one hour of worsened abdominal and back pain 
while
at work. She reports that in the past 2 weeks she has been 
having
significant lower abdominal and low back pain when she gets up
and is walking. She works as a ___ in a busy 
___
office. She also has been having a few contractions per day. 

Yesterday on ultrasound she had a new finding of a short cervix
of 18mm. Her cervix was closed on spec exam. She had a fetal
heart tracing and had a contraction on tocometry. On further
monitoring, there were no regular contractions and an AGA FHT.
She has not had any further pain or discomfort overnight or
today. She reports good fetal movement with no bleeding or fluid
leaking.

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx: G1 first tri TOP, D&C
G2 ___ FT SVD at ___, 8 lb
G3 SAB, D&C
G4 ___ SVD at 38 wks, 6 lb at ___, had arrested preterm labor
at 33 wks
G5 ___ MAB, D&C
G6 current

GYNHx: no h/o STIs

PMHx: urinary retention due to ?stricture

PSHx: urethral dilation
Breast augmentation
Tonsillectomy
D&C x3

 
Physical Exam:
 Physical Exam on Discharge:  
 CONSTITUTIONAL: normal  
 HEENT: normal, MMM  
 NEURO: alert, appropriate, oriented x 4  
 RESP: no increased WOB  
 HEART: extremities warm and well perfused  
 ABDOMEN: gravid, non-tender  
 EXTREMITIES: non-tender, no edema  
 FHR: present at a normal rate  
 
Pertinent Results:
Labs on Admission:

___ 07:11PM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.93 Hgb-12.6 Hct-36.7 MCV-93 
MCH-32.1* MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-45.1 Plt ___
___ 07:11PM BLOOD Neuts-71.2* ___ Monos-5.7 Eos-1.5 
Baso-0.3 Im ___ AbsNeut-6.50* AbsLymp-1.86 AbsMono-0.52 
AbsEos-0.14 AbsBaso-0.03
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital for observation after a 
newly diagnosed short cervix. She had an ultrasound at ___ for 
history for preterm labor. Her cervix was found to be 18.3mm 
with funneling present. Her cervix was found to be long, closed, 
and posterior. She was started on vaginal progesterone. A workup 
including vaginal cultures and urine culture were all negative. 

She was observed and her cervix was not dilating. She did not 
have any signs of vaginal bleeding or rupture of membranes. 
After a period of observation, she was deemed stable for 
discharge home with precautions. 
 
Medications on Admission:
PNV
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
2.  proGESTerone micronized 200 mg vaginally QHS  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
short cervix, on vaginal progesterone

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital with a short cervix. You were 
observed in the antepartum service with no signs of labor. You 
were started on vaginal progesterone. It is now safe for you to 
be discharged home. Please continue pelvic rest (nothing in the 
vagina, no sex, no douching, no tampons) and vaginal 
progesterone. Please take all medications as prescribed.

Please call the office for:  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding  
 - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke  
 - Abdominal pain  
 - Nausea/vomiting  
 - Fever, chills  
 - Decreased fetal movement  
 - Other concerns  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

history for preterm labor. Her cervix was found to be 18.3mm
with funneling present. Her cervix was found to be long, closed,
and posterior. She was started on vaginal progesterone. A workup
including vaginal cultures and urine culture were all negative.
She was observed and her cervix was not dilating. She did not
have any signs of vaginal bleeding or rupture of membranes.
After a period of observation, she was deemed stable for
discharge home with precautions.
Medications on Admission:
PNV
Discharge Medications:
1. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY
2. proGESTerone micronized 200 mg vaginally QHS
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
short cervix, on vaginal progesterone
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital with a short cervix. You were
observed in the antepartum service with no signs of labor. You
were started on vaginal progesterone. It is now safe for you to
be discharged home. Please continue pelvic rest (nothing in the
vagina, no sex, no douching, no tampons) and vaginal
progesterone. Please take all medications as prescribed.
Please call the office for: - Worsening, painful or regular contractions - Vaginal bleeding - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke - Abdominal pain - Nausea/vomiting - Fever, chills - Decreased fetal movement - Other concerns
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
bph
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TURP
 
History of Present Illness:
___ M with BPH s/p TURP

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Urology service after transuretral 
resection of prostate. No concerning intraoperative events 
occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. He 
patient received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis. 
Patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated. He received 
intravenous antibiotics and continous bladder irrigation 
overnight. On POD1, the CBI was discontinued.  His urine via 
catheter was clear yellow without clots. He remained afebrile 
throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, patient's pain well 
controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating regular diet, 
ambulating without assistance. He is given oral pain medications 
on discharge, without antibiotics. He is given explicit 
instructions to call for follow-up.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Carbidopa-Levodopa ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 
TID (3 times a day).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
You may shower and bathe normally.  Do not drive or drink 
alcohol if taking narcotic pain medication.  Resume all of your 
home medications, but please avoid aspirin/advil for three 
weeks.   Call Dr. ___ for appointment (___) 
AND if you have any urological questions.  If you have fevers > 
101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, or inability to 
urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.

 

The operation you have experienced is a "scraping" operation. 
Bleeding was controlled with electrocautery which has produced a 
"scab" in the channel through which the urine passes (the 
urethra). About ___ weeks after the operation, pieces of the 
scab will fall off and come out with the urine. As this occurs, 
bleeding may be noted which is normal. You should not worry 
about this. Simply lie down and increase your fluid intake for a 
few hours. In most cases, the urine will clear. If bleeding 
occurs or persists for more than 12 hours or if clots appear 
impairing your stream, call your surgeon. Because of the 
potential for bleeding, aspirin (or Advil) should be avoided for 
the first 3 weeks after surgery.

You will be given a prescription for antibiotics to be taken for 
a few days after surgery. This is to help prevent infection. If 
you develop a fever over 101°, chills, or pain in the testicles, 
call your surgeon. Although not common, this may indicate 
infection that has developed beyond the control of the 
antibiotics that you have taken.

*** Call Dr. ___ office to schedule followup appointment 
for removal of catheter in 1 week.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                ___ No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right knee OA
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
right knee replacement ___, ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ man right knee pain and arthritis refractory to 
conservative measures presenting for definitive treatment of a 
right total knee replacement
 
Past Medical History:
MI with stents, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prostate cancer, 
TIA, left tibial fracture, renal calculi
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Well appearing in no acute distress  
 Afebrile with stable vital signs  
 Pain well-controlled  
 Respiratory: CTAB  
 Cardiovascular: RRR  
 Gastrointestinal: NT/ND  
 Genitourinary: Voiding independently  
 Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits  
 Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3  
 Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity:  
 * Incision healing well with staples
 * Thigh full but soft  
 * No calf tenderness  
 * ___ strength  
 * SILT, NVI distally  
 * Toes warm
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:49AM BLOOD Hgb-10.9* Hct-32.1*
___ 06:53AM BLOOD Hgb-12.2* Hct-37.1*
___ 06:53AM BLOOD Creat-1.0
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
POD#0, the patient had to be straight catheterized for a bladder 
scan over 500 mL. Overnight, patient was given Flomax x 1 for 
urinary retention.
POD #1, patient was voiding independently.  Drain was removed.  
Ultrasound was performed for worsening calf pain.  This showed 
no evidence of blood clots.  He was also given a one-time dose 
of oral Hydralazine for an elevated BP of 189/74 with 
appropriate effect. 
POD #2, BPs remained stable 130-140s/60s.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Aspirin 325 mg twice 
daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The 
surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision 
was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with 
stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with no range of motion 
restrictions.
  
Mr. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
4. Vitamin D 400 UNIT PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  Gabapentin 100 mg PO TID 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
5.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
Continue while on 4-week course of Aspirin 325 mg twice daily.  
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID  
7.  Aspirin 325 mg PO BID 
Take 325 mg twice daily for 4 weeks, then return to normal 81 mg 
daily.  
8.  Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM  
9.  Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY  
10.  Vitamin D 400 UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right knee OA

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.

7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by 
your physician.

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 325 mg twice 
daily for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis 
(blood clots).  Continue Pantoprazole daily while on Aspirin to 
prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks). If you were taking Aspirin prior 
to your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose 
after the four weeks is completed.  
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment in two weeks.

10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks.

11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize.  ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or 
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
ROMAT
Wean assistive device as able (i.e. 2 crutches or walker)
Mobilize frequently 
Treatments Frequency:
daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice
staple removal and replace with steri-strips at follow up visit 
in clinic 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

pain medications. The patient received Aspirin 325 mg twice
daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The
surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision
was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating
a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with
stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.
The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as
tolerated on the operative extremity with no range of motion
restrictions.
Mr. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable
condition.
Medications on Admission:
1. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY
2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY
4. Vitamin D 400 UNIT PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
3. Gabapentin 100 mg PO TID
4. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain -
Moderate
5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H
Continue while on 4-week course of Aspirin 325 mg twice daily.
6. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID
7. Aspirin 325 mg PO BID
Take 325 mg twice daily for 4 weeks, then return to normal 81 mg
daily.
8. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM
9. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY
10. Vitamin D 400 UNIT PO DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
right knee OA
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5,
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this
admission and any new medications and refills.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent
this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you
are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your
home.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your
surgeon.
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your
follow-up appointment.
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time,
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex,
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by
your physician.
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 325 mg twice
daily for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis
(blood clots). Continue Pantoprazole daily while on Aspirin to
prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks). If you were taking Aspirin prior
to your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose
after the four weeks is completed.
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths,
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4)
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air.
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up
appointment in two weeks.
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as
instructed, wound checks.
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative
extremity. Mobilize. ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
ROMAT
Wean assistive device as able (i.e. 2 crutches or walker)
Mobilize frequently
Treatments Frequency:
daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice
staple removal and replace with steri-strips at follow up visit
in clinic
Followup Instructions:
___

findings.

<1%). He was given ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and atovaquone
after consultation with ID. He was transferred here for further
evaluation. He denies any complaints here.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male with a history of hyperlipidemia who presented 
to ___ with increased weakness, fever, lower 
extremity rash, found to have babesiosis. 

ACUTE ISSUES
------------

# Babesiosis: 
Found to have babesiosis on smear at <1% parasitemia. Patient 
with risk factor of gardening though no known tick bites. 
Complicated by mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, mild acute kidney 
injury, and mild transaminitis. Continued Azithromycin and 
Atovaquone for Babesia treatment and added doxycycline for 
suspected coinfection (anaplasma PCR and lyme serology pending 
on discharge). Plan for likely 10 days of therapy though will 
have ID follow up prior to end to ensure that patient remains 
clinically well and to repeat labs.

repeat labs within 2 weeks to ensure resolution.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
right laparoscopic nephrectomy
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with paranoid personality disorder with right renal mass 
now s/p right lap hand assist nephrectomy. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Obesity, Personality Disorder, Gerd, OA/Gout, Dyspnea with 
TOB 80+ ppy, 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing hand assisted 
right laparoscopic radical nephrectomy. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the 
PACU in stable condition.  On POD0, pain was well controlled on 
PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and 
ambulated once. On POD1, the patient was restarted on home 
medications, basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were 
checked, pain control was transitioned from PCA to oral 
analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast and crackers 
diet. On POD2, urethral catheter (foley) was removed without 
difficulty and diet was advanced as tolerated. Patient developed 
left arm swelling after and IV infiltrated and developed some 
erythema and had a UENIS that was negative for DVT and was 
started on vancomycin for presumed thrombophlebitis and was 
discharged with keflex x 1 week. The patient was discharged in 
stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding 
without difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On 
exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit 
instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___ in ___ weeks.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4-6H () 
as needed for fever.  
2. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for break through pain only (score 
>4) .
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): use while taking narcotics.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for 
Nebulization Sig: One (1)  Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as 
needed.  
5. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Ipratropium Bromide 0.02 % Solution Sig: One (1)  Inhalation 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed.  
7. Risperidone 2 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
8. Trazodone 100 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime) as needed.  
9. Keflex ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO four times a 
day for 1 weeks.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
renal mass
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your incision. 


-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids. 

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up.  

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics.  

-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin, advil, motrin, ibuprofin) until you see your urologist 
in follow-up. 

-Call your Urologist's office today to schedule a follow-up 
appointment in 3 weeks AND if you have any questions.  

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest ER.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___           Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Crush injury to bilateral index fingers consistent with a flexor 
tendon laceration
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Bilateral IF flexor tendon repairs 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ otherwise healthy male s/p work accident on ___ when his 
hands were pulled into conveyor belt.  He is here today for 
repair of bilateral index finger crush injuries.
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Pre-procedure physical exam as documented in Dr. ___ 
___:
___:  He is well appearing.
CARDIAC:  He has palpable pulses without arrhythmia.
LUNGS:  He is breathing room air without shortness breath or 
cough.
MUSCULOSKELETAL:  Focused of upper extremity examination, hands 
are well perfused bilaterally with palpable radial artery with 
good cap refill in all five digits including lacerated digits 
with volar lacerations overlying the P2 of the left index finger 
and as well as the P2 and P3 of the right index finger with 
segmental lacerations transversely.  He denies paresthesias in
the radial and ulnar border of the index, middle, ring, small or 
thumb bilaterally.  He is unable to make a composite fist with 
no active motion demonstrated at the PIP of either index finger 
or DIP of either index finger.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had operative repair of bilateral index finger 
crush injuries.  Please see operative note for further details 
of procedure.  The patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received IV pain medication 
with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. He was also started on a bowel regimen 
to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were closely 
monitored.  
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Patient had bilateral splints in place.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
bilateral index fingers crush injury consistent with bilateral 
flexor tendon lacerations

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent. ___ Speaking)
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Followup Instructions: ___

light-headedness

EPS ___
- No inducible ventricular tachardia.
- Multiple runs of SVT occured after infusion of atropine and 
isoproterenol; most likely focal, catecholamine-sensitive AT 
originating in the RA. This degenrated into a disorganized 
rhythm before spontaneously terminating; further episodes were 
easily suppressed with low dose metoprolol.
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with history of HTN presented with 1 day of lightheadedness
that started suddenly while patient was standing. He was 
standing
at work at construction site and looked up and suddenly felt
light-headed and held on to the wall to keep his balance. Also
started having palpitations. The light-headedness improved when
he lied down and drank some water, though the palpitations
continued and he felt unwell so called an ambulance. 

Has recent history of weight loss on purpose, ___ lb per
patient, from dieting and exercising. 

Denies any nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, chest pain/pressure at 
rest
or on exertion. No prior episodes of pre-syncope, syncope, or
palpitations.

You were hospitalized at ___ for an abnormal heart rhythm.

- You underwent an electrophysiology procedure which found no

___ URINE 24Creat-900 24Prot-___ G2P1 admitted at 32+2 weeks gestation with nausea and 
vomiting; likely viral gastroenteritis.
.
Mrs ___ was admitted for IV hydration and antiemetics due to 
her persistent nausea and vomiting. Labs were significant for 
elevated transaminases, (ALT 140 and AST 91), otherwise labs 
were normal. She had normal platelets and no evidence of 
preeclampsia/HELLP. A RUQ ultrasound was negative for 
gallbladder or liver abnormalities. Repeat LFTs were slightly 
improved with ALT 133 and AST 62. Although she had normal blood 
pressures (90/50), a 24 hour urine was collected to rule out 
preeclampsia as she had elevated LFTs and RUQ pain.
.
By HD#2, she was able to tolerate pos and was feeling better. 
LFTs continued to trend downward. Hepatology was consulted and 
felt that her nausea/vomiting from a viral illness was the 
likely etiology of her transaminitis and recommended repeating 
labs in one week. The 24 hour urine was negative.
.
Fetal testing was reassuring during this admissison and she had 
no preterm contractions. The NICU was consulted. 
.
She was discharged home on hospital day #3 and will have close 
outpatient followup.
 
Medications on Admission:
Zantac 75mg BID PRN for heart burn

1. Ondansetron 4 mg Tablet, Rapid Dissolve Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Rapid Dissolve PO Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed.

hours as needed for nausea.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

transaminitis
nausea and vomitting of pregnancy
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
routine
 
Followup Instructions:
___
