text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right adnexal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, peritoneal and omental biopsies, 
appendectomy, R ureterolysis, and cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is a ___ gravida 0 woman who initially 
presented with increasing abdominal girth. Her primary care 
physician performed ___ pelvic ultrasound which revealed a 12 cm 
complex right adnexal cyst.  She then developed severe pain and 
presented to the emergency room, where a repeat ultrasound 
revealed a 10 cm right adnexal complex cystic structure with 
less fluid component and new free pelvic fluid, consistent with 
rupture of the cystic
components.  Her left ovary appeared to be within normal limits. 
 Her CA-125 was 31, which is normal.  She was counseled on her 
options and agreed with the recommendation to proceed with 
surgical evaluation of her right adnexal
mass.  She was counseled that if the intraoperative pathology 
was suggestive of malignancy further staging procedure would be 
performed with the assistance of a Gynecologic Oncology surgeon. 
 All questions were answered and all consents were signed prior 
to going to the operating room.

 
Past Medical History:
OB Hx: G0; IVF x 2 unsuccessful, one adopted daughter is ___ yo

GYN Hx:
Menstrual Hx: Menarche age ___
LMP ___, reg pds q 28 days x 5days (mod flow), no 
significant dysmenorrhea
PAP Hx:  No h/o abnormal Pap smears; Last Pap ___ neg per pt
STI Hx: none
Sexually active: yes-    

___:  last ___ normal per pt
PMH:
1. none

PSH:
1. breast biopsy ___ - atypical ductal hyperplasia without
recurrence

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother: Living, age ___, DEEP VENOUS THROMBOPHLEBITIS 
HYPERLIPIDEMIA                          
Father: Living, age ___, PROSTATE CANCER, BENIGN BRAIN TUMOR      
                
Maternal Aunt: Living, BREAST CANCER
  
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: WNL, Stable
Gen: Comfortable, NAD
Heart: RRR, S1 S2 nl
Lungs: CTA b/l
Abd: Soft, non-distended, appropriately tender to palpation, 
+BS, four trocar insertion sites bandaged C/D/I
Ext: No edema, Non-tender

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:05AM BLOOD WBC-10.8 RBC-3.33* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.3* 
MCV-97 MCH-33.2* MCHC-34.2 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
after undergoing a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, omental and peritoneal biopsies, 
appendectomy, right ureterolysis, and cystoscopy for a complex 
right adnexal mass with intra-op pathology consistent with 
borderline mucinous cystadenocarcinoma. The GYN Oncology service 
performed an intra-op consult for this case. Please refer to the 
respective operative reports for full details of each portion of 
the case.  

Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately 
post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid and toradol. 
On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her 
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was 
advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to percocet 
and motrin.

By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain 
when tolerating PO. do not give with toradol 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Every 6 hours Disp 
#*50 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
start when tolerating sips 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth 
Every ___ hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Likely borderline mucinous ovarian tumor, final pathology 
pending

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing the 
procedures listed below. You have recovered well after your 
operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be discharged 
home. Please follow these instructions below:

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics. 
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation 
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex), no 
heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 3 months  
* You may eat a regular diet  

Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.  
 
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  


Call your doctor for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

physician performed ___ pelvic ultrasound which revealed a 12 cm
complex right adnexal cyst. She then developed severe pain and
presented to the emergency room, where a repeat ultrasound
revealed a 10 cm right adnexal complex cystic structure with
less fluid component and new free pelvic fluid, consistent with
rupture of the cystic
components. Her left ovary appeared to be within normal limits. Her CA-125 was 31, which is normal. She was counseled on her
options and agreed with the recommendation to proceed with
surgical evaluation of her right adnexal
mass. She was counseled that if the intraoperative pathology
was suggestive of malignancy further staging procedure would be
performed with the assistance of a Gynecologic Oncology surgeon. All questions were answered and all consents were signed prior
to going to the operating room.

OB Hx: G0; IVF x 2 unsuccessful, one adopted daughter is ___ yo
GYN Hx:
Menstrual Hx: Menarche age ___
LMP ___, reg pds q 28 days x 5days (mod flow), no
significant dysmenorrhea
PAP Hx: No h/o abnormal Pap smears; Last Pap ___ neg per pt
STI Hx: none
Sexually active: yes-
___: last ___ normal per pt
PMH:
1. none
PSH:
1. breast biopsy ___ - atypical ductal hyperplasia without
recurrence
Social History:

Family History:

HYPERLIPIDEMIA
Father: Living, age ___, PROSTATE CANCER, BENIGN BRAIN TUMOR
Maternal Aunt: Living, BREAST CANCER
Physical Exam:
Vitals: WNL, Stable
Gen: Comfortable, NAD
Heart: RRR, S1 S2 nl
Lungs: CTA b/l
Abd: Soft, non-distended, appropriately tender to palpation,
+BS, four trocar insertion sites bandaged C/D/I
Ext: No edema, Non-tender
Pertinent Results:
___ 08:05AM BLOOD WBC-10.8 RBC-3.33* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.3*
MCV-97 MCH-33.2* MCHC-34.2 RDW-13.5 Plt ___
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service
after undergoing a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral
salpingo-oophorectomy, omental and peritoneal biopsies,
appendectomy, right ureterolysis, and cystoscopy for a complex
right adnexal mass with intra-op pathology consistent with
borderline mucinous cystadenocarcinoma. The GYN Oncology service
performed an intra-op consult for this case. Please refer to the
respective operative reports for full details of each portion of
the case.
Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately
post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid and toradol.
On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her
foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was
advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to percocet
and motrin.
By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet,
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
Medications on Admission:
Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:

#*50 Tablet Refills:*0

start when tolerating sips

Every ___ hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice
a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0

Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Likely borderline mucinous ovarian tumor, final pathology
pending
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing the
procedures listed below. You have recovered well after your
operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be discharged
home. Please follow these instructions below:
General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to
prevent constipation
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex), no
heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 3 months
* You may eat a regular diet
Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on
their own or be removed during your followup visit.
To reach medical records to get the records from this
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / latex
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Left lower extremity weakness 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
L3-L4 re-exploration

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with Waldenstrom
macroglobulinemia c/b iron deficiency anemia post-op day 2 
status
post L3-L4 discectomy by Dr. ___ presenting to the ED with
left lower extremity weakness and shooting pain in her LLE.  

She reports feeling relief immediately following surgery and 
upon
discharge yesterday. When she got home she felt sudden increase
in the pain and had an episode of feeling like her left leg was
giving out causing her to fall to the ground. She also
experienced shock-like pain down her left buttock radiating down
her leg up to the knee.

She denies any fevers, chills, urinary incontinence, or bowel
incontinence. She further denies any drainage from the incision
site or other signs and symptoms of infection. 

 
Past Medical History:
___ macroglobulinemia 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
None on file. 
 
Physical Exam:
Exam: AAOx3, reports complete improvement in her leg pain. No
sensory deficits in bilateral lower extremities. 

Motor:
TrapDeltoidBicepTricepGrip
Right 5         5      5        5      5 
Left 5         5      5        5      5
IPQuadHamATEHLGast
Right5         5      5       5       5       5 
Left5         5      5       5       5       5 

Wound: 
  [X]Clean, dry, intact - very mild amount of serosanguinous
drainage, dressing removed in AM. 

 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for relevant results and imaging. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ admitted ___ s/p L3-L4 discectomy, p/w recurrent LLE 
weakness w disc herniation and stenosis at L3-L4 on ___. On 
___, she went to the OR for re-exploration of L3-L4 with 
evacuation of epidural surgiflo/hematoma. She was extubated and 
taken to the PACU in stable condition. 

#L3-L4 re-exploration
Pain was controlled with oxycodone and Tylenol. The patient 
received perioperative vancomycin for 3 doses, in the setting of 
a penicillin allergy. She reported significant improvement in 
her pain symptoms following surgery. SQH was started 24 hours 
postop. Dressing was removed 2 days postoperatively with mild 
serosanguinous drainage and intact steri strips over a 
well-healing incision. 

#Physical Therapy
Physical therapy was consulted on POD1 and determined that 
placement in a rehab facility following discharge would be most 
appropriate. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine 50mcg 
Oxycodone
 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Re-exploration L3-L4

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Surgery
Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath 
the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture removal. Do 
not remove your steri strips, let them fall off. Please keep 
your incision dry for 72 hours after surgery.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the surgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

Follow-up Instructions:
___

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Embolization 

Activity
You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we 
recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours to avoid 
bleeding from your groin.
Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise 
should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding 
from your groin.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) 
days after your procedure.
You make take a shower.
Medications
Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
You may be instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a day 
and/or Plavix. If so, do not take any other products that have 
aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain 
Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again 
three (3) days after your procedure.
Care of the Puncture Site
You will have a small bandage over the site.
Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and 
gently peeling it off.
Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
You may use a band-aid if you wish.

What You ___ Experience:
Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few 
weeks.
Fatigue is very normal
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the puncture 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Constipation
Blood in your stool or urine
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Cervical Dysplasia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total Laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman who underwent a LEEP excision of the cervix 
for
high-grade dysplasia.  Endocervical curettings were negative. 
She had extensive four-quadrant disease and the recommendation 
was to proceed with hysterectomy. 
 
Past Medical History:
Past Medical History:  She reports a history of hypertension 
that
is fairly well controlled at this point.  She reports a history
of alcoholism, sober for ___ years.  

Past Surgical History:  ___, she underwent an appendectomy.

OB/GYN History:  She is a gravida 0 woman.  She denies any
history of postmenopausal bleeding and has been postmenopausal
for three to ___ years.  She denies any history of abnormal Pap
smears, but she admits herself that her medical care has been
somewhat sporadic and limited.  She is not sexually active.  She
denies any history of pelvic infections.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
She reports that her mother had multiple myeloma and a second 
cousin had colon cancer.  There is no family history of breast 
cancer, ovarian cancer, or uterine cancer.

 
Physical Exam:
(Post-Op)
Afebrile, VSS
CV: RRR
Pulm: CTAB
Abd: Soft, appropriately tender, incision C/D/I
Ext: NT
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:20AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.55* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.6* 
MCV-92 MCH-31.3 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of high grade 
cervical dysplasia status post LEEP who presented for schedule 
laparoscopic total hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy. Her case was uncomplicated. Please see 
the operative report for full details.

Post-operatively, the patient was admitted to the Gyn Oncology 
service for post-operative monitoring. She did well 
post-operatively. Her diet was advanced, she was voiding 
spontaneously, ambulating and her pain was controlled with oral 
pain medication. Ms. ___ was discharged home in stable 
condition on POD#1.
 
Medications on Admission:
Fluoxetine 20mg QD
Amlodipine 5mg QD
Trazadone 50mg QHS

 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  


 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical dysplasia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no 
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 3 
months
* You may eat a regular diet.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision.  No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* You have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit. You may 
remove the outer dressing from your incisions if this has not 
already been done today.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ext: NT
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:20AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.55* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.6*
MCV-92 MCH-31.3 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of high grade
cervical dysplasia status post LEEP who presented for schedule
laparoscopic total hysterectomy, bilateral
salpingo-oophorectomy. Her case was uncomplicated. Please see
the operative report for full details.
Post-operatively, the patient was admitted to the Gyn Oncology
service for post-operative monitoring. She did well
post-operatively. Her diet was advanced, she was voiding
spontaneously, ambulating and her pain was controlled with oral
pain medication. Ms. ___ was discharged home in stable
condition on POD#1.
Medications on Admission:
Fluoxetine 20mg QD
Amlodipine 5mg QD
Trazadone 50mg QHS
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day) as needed for constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY
(Daily).
5. amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical dysplasia
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs
* No strenuous activity, nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no
douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 3
months
* You may eat a regular diet.
Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* You have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on
their own or be removed during your followup visit. You may
remove the outer dressing from your incisions if this has not
already been done today.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with ___ notable for ___ dementia 
(minimally verbal at baseline) living in a group home 
transferred to ___ from ___ for extensive RLE DVT, without 
surgical indications at this time currently managed on apixaban. 


#Provoked RLE DVT: Transferred to ___ from ___ for vascular 
surgery evaluation for extensive RLE DVT, confirmed by LENIs at 
the time of presentation.  She has no previous history of DVTs 
or PEs and no known personal or family history of 
hypercoaguability.  Based on collateral from ___ sister 
and group home, she has had increasingly limited mobility over 
the past couple of months but no other clear precipitants for 
DVT formation.   At the time of transfer, she was managed on 
heparin gtt.  Patient was evaluated by vascular surgery with 
recommendation for ACE wrap, leg elevation, and anticoagulation 
but no indication for surgical management.  Anticoagulation was 
switched from heparin gtt to Apixaban 10mg BID on ___ and was 
discharged on this dose with plan to decrease to 5mg BID after 
one week of treatment.

# Parkinsons/Dementia: Patient with history of ___ 
dementia. Patient was not verbal at time of admission interview 
and, per ___ home staff and ___ sister, this is 
approximately the ___ baseline.  Her sister believes that 
her verbal comprehension is intact despite her being 
___. She was minimally verbal on day of discharge.  
During admission, her home doses of entacapone and sinemet were 
continued.

# Depression/Agitation: As above, patient not verbal at time of 
admission interview which is her approximate baseline.  Patient 
did have tears in eyes and end of admission interview. Home 
doses of abilify and paxil were continued throughout admission.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
- Patient should continued taking apixaban 10mg two times per 
day for a total of 7 days. Day 1 = ___. Day 7 = ___. 
- After 7 days, decrease the apixaban dose to 5mg two times per 
day. She will need to continue taking this medication for at 
least 3 months at the discretion of the ___ PCP 
- ___ aspirin was held in the setting of anticoagulation 
on apixaban. This should be restarted when apixaban is stopped.
- Vaginal estrogen cream were stopped because of the DVT. Use 
caution if considering restarting.

- You were transferred here from another hospital after you were 
found to have a blood clot in your right leg.

- We maintained you on an IV blood thinner (heparin). 
- We changed this blood thinner to an oral blood thinner 
(apixaban) before you were discharged. 

What do you need to do?

- It is important that you CONTINUE taking apixaban 10mg two 
times per day for a total of 7 days. Day 1 = ___. Day 7 = 
___.

times per day. You will need to continue taking this medication 
for at least 3 months (As determined by your primary care

doctor. Please call their office to schedule an appointment. 
(Information below)

return to the hospital if you have any chest pain or shortness 
of breath. 

It was a pleasure caring for you. We wish you the best!

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Medicine Team

and onset of spontaneous labor, the decision was then made to

procedure.

spontaneous rupture of membranes but not in labor. She was 
evaluated for augmentation of labor and the fetus was found to 
be in breech presentation, and ultrasound confirmed that the 
fetus was in breech presentation.  Given fetal malpresentation 
and onset of spontaneous labor, the decision was then made to 
proceed with a primary low transverse cesarean section for 
breech presentation. For full detail see operative note.

Post partum, Ms ___ recovered well however on post partum day 4 
she developed a fever to 102. Patient had mild uterine 
tenderness, incision was clean dry intact with no erythema, 
patient had no breast tenderness or erythema, UA was negative. 
Patient was started on gent/clinda at that time for presumed 
endometritis. Patient was treated for 24 hours, and remained 
afebrile. Patient had a another low grade fever to 100.8 20 
hours after antibiotics were stopped. CBC and UA were normal, 
patient reported fever happened in setting of breast 
engorgement, patient was monitored for another 24 hours with no 
further fevers and was discharged home in stable condition with 
instructions to call if febrile, nausea, vomiting, or increased 
bleeding abdominal pain. Patient to follow up with ___ 
___ NP on ___.

PNV

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
___ generally healthy with obstructing 5mm Right mid-ureteral 
stone, seen in ED 5 days prior and D/C'd on trial of passage.  
Pt developed N/V with continued flank pain/colic.  Denies fever, 
chills, dysuria.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ R ureteroscopy, laser lithotripsy, stent

 
History of Present Illness:
___ generally healthy with obstructing 5mm Right mid-ureteral 
stone, seen in ED 5 days prior and D/C'd on trial of passage.  
Pt developed N/V with continued flank pain/colic.  Denies fever, 
chills, dysuria.

 
Past Medical History:
SBO s/p surgical repair

 
Physical Exam:
NAD
A&Ox3
Abd soft nt/nd
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ admited to urology service ___ with R ureteral stone.  He 
underwent laser lithotripsy and stent placement on ___.  Please 
see operative note for further details.  Pt tolerated the 
procedure well.  He was extubated in the OR and transferred to 
the PACU then the floor.  His pain was controlled with IV 
narcotics then transitioned to PO pain meds.  His diet was 
advanced.  He was deemed ready for discharge later on ___.  At 
the time of discharge his pain was controlled with PO meds, he 
was tolerating a PO diet, voiding spontaneously and ambulating 
without difficulty.  He will follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ 
days for stent removal.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).  
3. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day) 
as needed for constipation.  
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R ureteral stone

 
Discharge Condition:
condition - stable
mental status - alert & oriented x3, no acute distress
ambulatory status - independant

 
Discharge Instructions:
--No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequency over the next month.

You may experience some pain associated with spasm of your 
ureter. This is normal. Take IBUPROFEN as directed and take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.
-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.

-You may shower and bathe normally.

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics or operate 
dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.  Colace is a
stool softener, NOT a laxative

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service on ___ for 
her abdomino-pelvic pain. There is a concern that she may have 
an ectopic pregnancy as her hCG is low but no definite 
intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy could be identified by 
ultrasound. But as this is a highly desired pregnancy, her pain 
has improved and she has remained stable during her 
hospitalization the patient prefers expectant management. She 
has agreed to follow up with serial hCG levels in order to 
determine the location and viability of this pregnancy.
She has been counseled as to the warning signs of an unstable 
ectopic pregnancy including but not limited to severe pain, 
feeling faint or dizzy, loss of consciousness, increased 
cramping or vaginal bleeding. She was counseled to seek emergent 
care with any of these symptoms and to return for an hCG level 
on ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ and Delivery at 38 weeks 4 days 
with fever, maternal & fetal tachycardia, leukocytosis and 
diffuse abdominal TTP consistent with chorioamnionitis. She 
denied any significant GI symptoms and did not recall rupture of 
membranes. She was immediately started on IV fluids, and 
ampicillin, gentamicin and clindamycin for presumed 
chorioamnionitis and given antipyretics. The fetal heart rate 
decreased slightly from 200s to the 180s to 170s but given 
persistent fetal tachycardia despite significant intrauterine 
resuscitation, the recommendation was made to proceed with 
cesarean section given the duration of the category 2 fetal 
heart tracing was unknown, and the patient was remote from 
delivery with the cervix 1 cm dilated.  

Postpartum, blood cultures returned with gram positive cocci in 
chains on postpartum day #1, later speciating as group B 
streptococcus, pan-sensitive. Infectious Disease was consulted 
and recommended transition to IV pencillin which was started on 
postpartum day #1. Given inability to rule-out endocarditis as 
the source of infection, echocardiogram was obtained revealing 
mild biatrial enlargement without massess or vegitations, mild 
pulmonary hypertension and LEVF of > 55%. She remained afebrile 
throughout the course of her hospitalization. Daily blood 
cultures were obtained. She received IV pencillin until 
discharge on postpartum day #4. Per Infectious Disease, as daily 
blood cultures revealed no growth to date up to the day of 
planned discharge, no further antibiotics were indicated after 
discharge as the source of infection had been removed.

She otherwise received routine postpartum care. She was 
discharged on postpartum day #4 in stable condition. She was 
afebrile and hemodynamically stable at the time of discharge.

prenatal vitamin

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ and Delivery at 38 weeks 4 days
with fever, maternal & fetal tachycardia, leukocytosis and
diffuse abdominal TTP consistent with chorioamnionitis. She
denied any significant GI symptoms and did not recall rupture of
membranes. She was immediately started on IV fluids, and
ampicillin, gentamicin and clindamycin for presumed
chorioamnionitis and given antipyretics. The fetal heart rate
decreased slightly from 200s to the 180s to 170s but given
persistent fetal tachycardia despite significant intrauterine
resuscitation, the recommendation was made to proceed with
cesarean section given the duration of the category 2 fetal
heart tracing was unknown, and the patient was remote from
delivery with the cervix 1 cm dilated.
Postpartum, blood cultures returned with gram positive cocci in
chains on postpartum day #1, later speciating as group B
streptococcus, pan-sensitive. Infectious Disease was consulted
and recommended transition to IV pencillin which was started on
postpartum day #1. Given inability to rule-out endocarditis as
the source of infection, echocardiogram was obtained revealing
mild biatrial enlargement without massess or vegitations, mild
pulmonary hypertension and LEVF of > 55%. She remained afebrile
throughout the course of her hospitalization. Daily blood
cultures were obtained. She received IV pencillin until
discharge on postpartum day #4. Per Infectious Disease, as daily
blood cultures revealed no growth to date up to the day of
planned discharge, no further antibiotics were indicated after
discharge as the source of infection had been removed.
She otherwise received routine postpartum care. She was
discharged on postpartum day #4 in stable condition. She was
afebrile and hemodynamically stable at the time of discharge.

Right Thyroidectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female  with complaints of vague neck symptoms.  She 
had an ultrasound of her neck as a result and it showed a right 
thyroid mass.  She then went to ___ 
___ where she had an ultrasound guided biopsy of a nodule 
about 1 cm in size with irregular borders and calcifications. 
Final needle aspiration is interpreted as suspicious for 
papillary thyroid carcinoma.
 
Past Medical History:
Vit D deficiency
Chronic Headaches
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
A maternal cousin had a total thyroidectomy a year ago for
papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 
Physical Exam:
Vital signs: 98.1, 90, 105/64, 14, 99% Room Air
General:No acute distress, alert and oriented x3, no voice 
hoarsness, positive perioral tingling, no numbness
Cardiac: Regular rythmn and rate, no mumur, rubs or gallops
Lungs: clear to auscultate bilaterally
Abdomen: soft sontender, nondistended, no rebound guarding
Wound: neck incision with steri strips clean, dry and intact, no 
erythema or edema.
Extremities: + pulses no edema

 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:14AM BLOOD Calcium-9.___ year old female status post Right Thyroidectomy for a right 
nodule suspicious for papillary carcinoma.  She was admitted to 
___ Surgery inpatient unit under the care of Dr. 
___.  Posteroperative day 0 she had no events overnight. 
 On Postoperative day 1 she complaint of perioral tingling and 
no numbness.  She was given Calcium Carbonate 1000 milligram by 
mouth and a serum Calcium was checked and is 9.1.  Her perioral 
numbness has resolved and she has no further complaints.  She is 
otherwise doing well. She has no nausea or emesis and is 
tolerating a regular diet.  She is voiding and ambulating.  Her 
pain is adequately controlled with Vicodin.  She will be 
discharged home today without any Calcium.  She will follow up 
with Dr. ___ in ___ weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
Vitamin D weekly
Ibuprofen prn

 
Discharge Medications:
Vicodin ___ tabs PO Q6h 
Vitamin D weekly
Ibuprofen prn

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right Thyroid Nodule

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ inpatient unit and 
underwent a Right thyroidectomy for a right nodule suspicious 
for papillary carcinoma.   Your tissue was sent to pathology and 
you should have your results in 1 week.  Please monitor for 
voice hoarseness because of risk to the nerve that controls your 
voice during surgery. Watch for numbness or tingling around 
mouth or legs, confusion, muscle spasm,or changes in level of 
conciousness, these could be signs of low calcium which can 
happen after thyroid surgery.  If you have any of these symptoms 
please call Dr. ___ ___.  For severe 
symptoms please call ___.  Please monitor your neck incision for 
any drainage, swelling or redness.  You have steri strips on 
your neck incision, please keep clean and dry.  You may shower 
but avoid swimming or bathing.  You will be given a prescription 
for Vicodin for pain.  Each Vicodin tablet contains Hydrocodone 
5mg and 500 mg of acetaminophen (Tylenol). Please do not drink 
alcohol or drive while taking this medication as it may cause 
drowsiness.  Do not take more than 4000 mg of acetaminophen 
(Tylenol) in a 24 hour period. When you get home please call Dr. 
___ and schedule an appointment to be seen in ___ 
week.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

no labs
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with history of papillary thyroid carcinoma 
and status post secondary (left thyroidectomy) on ___  with 
Dr. ___.  She was admitted from the recovery room to the 
General Surgery Inpatient Unit. Postoperatively she had some 
nausea, no emesis. This morning she complained of heartburn 
which resolved with Tums.  Her diet was advanced to regular this 
morning which was tolerated well.  The voice is slight hoarse 
this morning and she had a mild sore throat. The transverse neck 
incision is clean, dry and intact with steri strips in place. 
There is mild neck edema at the neck incision,no erythema no 
drainage noted.She is tolerating a regular diet.  Her pain is 
adequately controlled on oral analgesia. She is voiding and 
ambulating independently.  She will be discharged home today on 
Cytomel and has been instructed to call and schedule an 
appointment with her endocrinologist.   She will call and 
schedule a  postoperative follow-up appointment with Dr. 
___ in 1 month.

none

(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

every six (6) hours as needed for pain: Do not drink alcohol or 
drive car while taking this medication as it may cause 
drowsiness. Do not exceed 4000mg acetaminophen (Tylenol) in a 24 
hour period.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

hours) as needed for pain: Do not take on an empty stomach.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

Home

Papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 
Discharge Condition:
Regular, no restrictions

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the General Surgery Inpatient Unit and had 
a left thyroidectomy. Your tissue was sent to pathology and you 
should have your results in 1 week. Please monitor your neck 
incision for any drainage, swelling or redness. You have steri 
strips on your neck incision, please keep clean and dry. These 
steri-strips will fall off on their own, please do not remove 
them. You may shower but avoid swimming or bathing. You will be 
given a prescription for Vicodin for pain. Each Vicodin tablet 
contains 5mg Hydrocodone and 500mg acetaminophen (Tylenol). 
Please do not drink alcohol or drive while taking this 
medication as it may cause drowsiness. Do not take more than 
4000 mg of acetaminophen (Tylenol) in a 24 hour period. you may 
also take Ibuprofen 600 mg every 8 hours as needed for pain. You 
will be given a prescription for Liothyroxine (Cytomel)take 
25mcg once a day. Please call and schedule a follow-up 
appointment with Dr. ___ in 1 month ___. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

your infection. You have recovered well and the team believes

below.

vaginal discharge, so went to be evaluated by PCP. In office, by
report exam notable for adnexal tenderness and wet mount c/w BV.
Urine HCG positive. Sent to ED for r/o ectopic.
Here, she mostly notes bilateral low back pain. She does feel
"tender" in midline pelvis. She felt very uncomfortable with
pelvic ultrasound, pain in midline with probe. She reports exam
in office quite painful, which is not typical for her. She does
note some urinary urgency/frequency. No hematuria or dysuria.
Has
had some constipation over last several week, improving, but
still straining with BM. No nausea/vomiting. No fevers/chills.
No
CP/SOB. No vaginal bleeding. Felt vaginal discharge subjectively
foul smelling x 2 days, white in color. Had unprotected
intercourse with new partner approximately 1 month ago.
Pregnancy
was unplanned, unsure if she would continue pregnancy.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service
for pelvic inflammatory disease in pregnancy.
.
She was treated with IV gentamicin and clindamycin for 24 hours
with improvement in symptoms and was given a dose of 1g oral
azithromycin prior to discharge. Gonorrhea, chlamydia, HIV,
hepatitis B, and RPR labs were collected.
.
By hospital day 2, she remained afebrile, her pain was improved,
she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, and
ambulating independently. She was then discharged home in stable
condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
Medications on Admission:
ibuprofen as needed

do not take more than 4000mg total per day

Home

Pelvic inflammatory disease

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service for treatment of
your infection. You have recovered well and the team believes
you are ready to be discharged home. Please call ___
with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions
below.
General instructions:
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
To reach medical records to get the records from this
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
